PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia
Respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 165 citizens), Gareth Evans (from 2,748 citizens) and McKiernan (from 394 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned whilst opposing tax evasion strongly reject the I.D. [Australia] Card as a means of increasing Government revenue. The I.D. Card, by its intrusive nature, will be an invasion of our historic rights to privacy and freedom for all Australians. No democratic nation has an I.D. Card with such detailed computer surveillance, which will be provided by this system known as PIN [Personal Identification Number] or SUI [Standard Universal Identification] where every Australian citizen will have a personal dossier on computer.

Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our privacy and freedom, and totally reject the ID [Australia] Card, which will not stop welfare fraud, nor deter organised crime, nor prevent illegal immigration, nor expose tax evasion.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 353 citizens) and McKiernan (from 222 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Imperial System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Canberra Institute of the Arts: Representation on the Board and Council
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate:
We the undersigned, express deep concern at the proposed governance arrangements for the Canberra Institute of the Arts.

We object to the absence of representation of staff, students and community members on both the Board and Council of the Institute. We also object to the situation where the Board can make a decision affecting students, with only a quorum of two members, and without having to consult the proposed Council.
We call on the Senate to review the Ordinance with the intention of including staff, student and community representation on both the Board and Council of the proposed Canberra Institute of the Arts.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest against the lowering of overseas aid to 0.36% of G.N.P.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that overseas aid be increased to the internationally agreed minimum of 0.7% of G.N.P.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office: Ballajura Region, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they call upon the Government of the Commonwealth to:

Establish a Post Office or Postal Sub-agency in the Ballajura region, noting that Ballajura is currently underserviced and distanced from major community facilities and we, the residents of the area feel it important to have enhanced communications.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HAINES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following copy of a petition from 112 petitioners praying that the Constitution be amended to allow Australian electors to initiate referenda and to extend the term of office of the House of Representatives from three to four years:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That although elector-initiated referendums are conducted successfully in such countries as Switzerland and the U.S.A., no such facility exists for Australian citizens.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Initiate the necessary action for a referendum to be held to amend the Constitution to provide for such an initiative on the following conditions:

If a specified percentage of voters (such as 2%) sign a petition asking that a referendum be held on a certain question the Federal Government would be obliged to hold that referendum and the result would become law.
And your petitioners further humbly pray that the referendum be timed to coincide with the referendum to be held to extend the term of office of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years.
And we humbly pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH PARLIAMENTARY ASSOCIATION CONFERENCE: COMMEMORATIVE STAMP

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Michael Baume and Senator Reid and on my own behalf, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with the utmost displeasure the gratuitous insult offered to the nine parliaments of Australia, to the Senate and its President and to the House of Representatives and its Speaker, by Australia Post in its refusal to issue a commemorative postage stamp for the 1988 Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference;

(b) further notes that this insult by a statutory authority, itself a mere creation of the Federal Parliament, is also an insult to all of the member nations and parliaments of the Commonwealth of Nations;

(c) records that such a commemorative stamp has been issued each year since 1961 whenever the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference has been hosted by a national parliament, and that to date some 18 nations have issued such a stamp;
(d) notes in addition that the 1988 CPA Conference will be the first official function held in the new Parliament House in Canberra, itself a matter worthy of commemoration;

(e) observes that Australia Post has, over a period of several years, dealt with requests from Mr President and Madam Speaker in a fashion which is cavalier and in which the excuses offered about the allocations of new issues in the 1988 stamp program are derisory;

(f) calls on Australia Post to at once accede to the request of the President, the Speaker and the Australian branch of the CPA to issue a commemorative stamp and desist in its persistent arrogant and insulting attitude towards the parliaments of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Commonwealth of Nations.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the procedures established by resolutions of the Senate on 25 February 1988, Senator Chaney has raised with me, by letter dated 11 March 1988, a matter of privilege. Under the resolutions I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges should have precedence over other business, having regard to the following criteria:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

The determination which I am required to make does not involve an assessment of the truth or merits of the matter raised, nor does it finally determine the matter. My decision is simply whether, having regard to the stated criteria, a motion concerning the matter should be given precedence so that the Senate is given an early opportunity to consider the matter. In applying the criteria laid down by the Senate, I think I ought to give precedence to a motion if the matter raised is such that it appears to be cap- able of being held by the Senate to meet criterion (a), and if another remedy is not clearly and readily available. The essence of the matter raised by Senator Chaney is not such that it can be treated as trivial or unworthy of the attention of the Senate within the meaning of criterion (a).

The matters in issue under criterion (b) are much more complex, involving difficult questions of principle about the interaction between judicial and parliamentary processes and legal and political avenues of redress. In all the circumstances, I think it appropriate that the Senate be given the opportunity to refer the issues to the Committee of Privileges. I have determined that the motion to refer the matter should have precedence accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, following the determination that the motion should have precedence, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following questions be referred to the Committee of Privileges: whether a petition to the Senate was suppressed in consequence of a threat of legal proceedings by the Hon. Brian Burke, and, if so, whether this constituted a contempt of Parliament.
Mr President, in light of your explanatory comments, and without wishing to cover the ground that I will cover in debate tomorrow, I seek leave to make a brief statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity that the Senate has had to look at this procedure and I do not intend--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Is this a point of order to enable Senator Chaney to have two bites at the cherry, or is it to make a general contribution to an understanding of the procedures that are applicable and available in this place? Perhaps I could ask Senator Chaney's intentions in this regard, before we make a decision on whether to give leave. We know the nature of the matter from the subject matter of the notice of motion and I do not think we need any further explanation of that. If Senator Chaney wishes to make some statement about the applicability of the procedures, obviously that is a matter for you, Mr President.
—There is no point of order. Senator Chaney sought leave and leave was granted, so my hands are tied.

—The point I wish to make relates to the fact that this is novel in the sense that it is the first time that the Senate has had to follow the procedures which were established by the resolution of February. In accordance with that resolution, before I made this matter public I raised it with you, Mr President. Paragraph 3 of resolution 7 adopted in February provides that a senator:

SPEECH.PARA: shall not take any action in relation to, or refer to, in the Senate, a matter which is under consideration by the President in accordance with the resolution.

Clearly, in its terms, that is a requirement that no one should take action in this chamber or outside this chamber until you, Mr President, had a chance to make the determination that you have made and told us of this afternoon.

When I wrote to you, Mr President, on 11 March, I indicated that in the light of the fact that public, as well as parliamentary, interest is involved, I proposed to make public my letter to you within a matter of a few days. The request which I received second hand was that I should hold action on that until you had had a chance to consider it and deal with the matter in the Senate. I indicate to the Senate that in deference to that request I have not, to this point, published the letter that I wrote to you seeking your consideration. In those circumstances, I wish to do no more now than to seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case I shall read the letter which I wrote to you. This is the letter of 11 March:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate on 25 February, I write to advise you of my intention to raise a matter of privilege.

The matter arises from the circulation of a petition in Western Australia requesting deferral of the appointment of the Hon. Brian Burke as Australian Ambassador to Ireland pending resolution of forthcoming legal proceedings involving the former chairman of the State Superannuation Board and a Perth businessman.

This petition was circulated at the instigation of a citizen who sought advice from the Liberal Party who, in turn, contacted my office about the way in which the petition might be phrased to ensure it complied with Standing Orders.

Mr Burke subsequently threatened legal proceedings against the person concerned, alleging that the words in the petition were defamatory. A legal settlement has since been concluded with the former Premier, on conditions which include collection and destruction of petition forms and an undertaking not to present the petition to Parliament.

It is my very strong view that the action taken by the former Premier is in breach of the right of citizens to circulate petitions for presentation to the Parliament. Any lingering doubts about this matters would appear to have been resolved by the passage of the Parliamentary Privileges Act (No. 21 of 1987) and in particular Section 16, sub sections 2 (b) (c) and (d) of that Act.

It is also my view that the Senate must be very ready to defend the availability of recourse to the Parliament by citizens of modest means against infringement by those who are comparatively rich and powerful.

I would appreciate your consideration of this matter and your early advice as to when I might move in the Senate for a reference to the Committee of Privileges. As the public as well as parliamentary interest is involved, I propose to make this letter public in the next few days.

That is the end of my letter. I note that both Senator Cook and Senator Walsh were attempting to interject during the course of my reading that letter. I am very glad that the Labor Party colleagues of Mr Burke have exposed their support for what I see as a bullying and pathetic attempt to prevent a citizen from exercising his rights in the community. Having read the contents of that letter, I point out that I bring this matter forward as a senator from Western Australia. Whilst I advised my party room this morning of my intention to do so, I add that this is not a matter which has had the consideration of my party room. I make that point because the Senate will be called upon to make a judgment on this matter if the motion is carried, as I believe it should be in light of the significance of any attempt to prevent a citizen from exercising his or her right to petition this Parliament. It may well be that Senator Cook and Senator Walsh wish to defend that sort of pressure being put upon a citizen, but I have no such wish to do so. If that is the stance they wish to take, no doubt they can indicate that in debate tomorrow.

For my part, I bring this matter forward because it is a matter of considerable public interest that individuals should not be put upon in this way. I believe it is something which warrants very early consideration by the Committee of Privileges. I will deal with the matter in more detail tomorrow when the motion comes on for debate. I hope it will be speedily considered and dealt with by the Senate.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement relating to Commonwealth Day, to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
MESSAGE BY THE LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT-COMMONWEALTH DAY 1988
Mr President,

Yesterday, 14 March, was Commonwealth Day. It has a particular significance for Australia in 1988, when Commonwealth nations are making such a significant contribution to our Bicentennial celebrations.
The quarter of the world's population comprising the Commonwealth is spread amongst small countries and large, developed and developing, from all continents and both hemispheres.

Within the framework provided by the Commonwealth, people from the widest range of cultures, races and religions imaginable meet on an equal footing, share their views and their friendship, and cooperate on matters of mutual concern.
This is what makes the Commonwealth a valuable and constructive international institution.
The Vancouver meeting of Commonwealth Heads of Government, which took place in October last year, provided a good example of such productive co-operation.
Commonwealth leaders agreed on a shared approach on issues ranging from world trade to disarmament. Constructive initiatives were taken in many of these areas.

The outstanding political issue continuing to confront the Commonwealth remains, of course, the situation in southern Africa. The recent deterioration there, caused by the further repressive measures introduced by the South African Government, only underlines the continuing tragedy and the need for every effort to be made to bring about peaceful changes.
Whether the Commonwealth's longstanding ambition to see a peaceful end to apartheid will be achieved will, of course, depend on many factors beyond our immediate control.
I have no doubt, however, that when the histories come to be written, the Commonwealth's role in providing an international lead in the struggle against apartheid will be acknowledged and commended.
Commonwealth Day provides a sobering reminder of the tragic denial of basic human rights to the majority in South Africa.
I should like to assure the Senate that, under this Government, Australia will continue to be at the forefront of Commonwealth efforts to promote peaceful change in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which was incorporated in Hansard by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button)-I am not surprised that he chose to incorporate it-was provided to the Opposition in the normal way a couple of hours ago. It is, I must say, a fairly extraordinary statement which warrants some comment from the Opposition. It represents a somewhat enthusiastic endorsement of the Commonwealth in terms which sit very oddly with past comments of the Australian Labor Party. I must say that, to the extent that it represents some affirmation of the value of the Commonwealth, I welcome it on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is pleased to express again its support for the positive ideals of cooperation and mutual respect that underpin the objectives and activities of the Commonwealth of Nations. It is possible at times to forget the significance of the Commonwealth and that it embraces over a quarter of the world's population. It embraces a great mixture of countries that are at very different stages of economic development. The Liberal and National parties have always regarded the association as of critical importance because it brings us into contact with countries with which we have a strong historical affiliation and it also brings us into contact with a multi- racial world; we believe that to be very important for the future of this country and important as far as our strategic position is concerned.

In our view the Commonwealth has proved itself to be an invaluable forum for the discussion of international political and economic issues. The extraordinary thing about the statement, or the message, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has put down in the other place, and which Senator Button has put down here, is that it concentrates entirely on the issue of southern Africa. We find in this statement no mention of matters much closer to Australia; in particular there is no mention of Fiji. There seems to be a fairly extraordinary lack of balance in the statement when we have the description of southern Africa as the outstanding political issue continuing to confront the Commonwealth in the context of a 12-month period in which Fiji has left the Commonwealth under extremely difficult circumstances. I think that tells us something about the attitudes of the Labor Party to it.

I also want to remind the Senate that when the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting was held in Melbourne in late 1981 the then Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Hayden, described it as `an extravagant indulgence of little relevance to international affairs or Australia's role in the world'. That was the view of the Labor Party in 1981. We now find in the statement that Senator Button has just brought into the Senate that he is saying that the Vancouver meeting of the Commonwealth Heads of Government, which took place in October last year, provided a good example of such productive cooperation-what he had earlier described as making the Commonwealth a valuable and constructive international institution. We welcome this conversion of the Labor Party to giving some emphasis to the Commonwealth, and its conversion to a view which was profoundly advanced in Australia, and indeed in the Commonwealth, by the previous Prime Minister, the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser.

We find the Prime Minister's assurance that his Government is at the forefront of Commonwealth efforts to promote peaceful change in South Africa, which is what is said in the statement, at stark variance with the Government's statements of November last year condoning violence to bring about political change in South Africa. We believe that, by adopting that stance, the Hawke Government certainly spoke at variance with the morality that most Australians would embrace and took a view which most Australians would have great difficulty supporting.

We note that in this statement there is no mention of Fiji, and this is at a time when we believe Fiji needs Australia's very careful policy attention. In the Opposition's view we should be encouraging, in a quiet way, the decisive return to constitutional government in that country with a strong commitment to effective representation of all the major communities. We believe that we should let the Fiji Administration know that, when such arrangements are completed, Australia would be willing to renominate Fiji for membership of the Commonwealth.

We reaffirm our commitment to the important international cooperative programs of the Commonwealth and we accept that it is a very positive way that Australia can contribute to world affairs. To the extent that the Government's statement represents some stepping back from its destructive anti-Commonwealth attitudes of the past, we welcome it; but we note that its emphasis is on southern Africa rather than on our own region and we believe that that is a continuing indication of this Government's failure to tackle those issues in foreign policy which are of most concern to the Commonwealth. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —A report appeared in the Sun-Herald newspaper on Sunday last suggesting that the Clerk of the Senate had been involved in deliberations about the propriety of a radio broadcast being made from the new Parliament House and in an attempt to prevent the broadcast being made. In so far as the report relates to the Clerk of the Senate, it is completely false. Neither the Clerk nor I was consulted about the proposed broadcast, nor did we engage in any consideration of it or attempt to make any determination on whether it should proceed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. When did the Minister become aware of the appointment of Mr Mick Young as a consultant to Qantas Airways Ltd and who told him about it? What is Qantas paying Mr Young and what does it expect him to do? Who suggested Mr Young as a candidate for the consultancy? Was Mr Young interviewed by the Qantas Board and were others considered for the position? When the Minister said on Friday that Mr Young would be `using his well-known persuasive skills' and his `knowledge of the operation of government' in his new job, did he mean that Mr Young would be having contact with the Government of which he was so recently a senior member? Does the Minister believe that it is proper that Mr Young's contacts within government and the Labor movement generally should be used to help Qantas achieve a change in policy to accord the injection of private capital which, on the Minister's own figures, it will so clearly need in the years ahead to avoid a severe drain on the Government's resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Opposition has demonstrated a willingness to get this entire issue over in one question.
—Don't you believe it.

—I can assure the Opposition that it is going to get only one answer. I first became aware of the actual appointment of Mick Young only last Friday. The source of my knowledge was a journalist who had just come into receipt of a Press release-issued two days earlier but through the mail-by the Qantas management indicating that the Board had made the decision on Wednesday. I did have some earlier knowledge that such an--
—Obviously they keep you well in touch as Minister.

—That is not a secret, Senator. I have been cheerfully willing to indicate that to anyone who has asked. Mick Young mentioned to me in passing about three weeks ago that he had been having exploratory discussions or consultations with Qantas, among others, about doing some consultancy work. I said that any arrangement he might enter into with Qantas was entirely one for him and Qantas to sort out.

ANSWER.PARA: I had some further information as a result of a conversation with the Chairman of Qantas, Mr Jim Leslie, who told me last Friday week, 4 March, in the course of, in fact, a very long conversation on a number of different topics, that Qantas was contemplating employing Mr Young as a consultant to improve its lines of communication in a number of areas, including with the union movement and State governments-State governments with which there had often been misunderstandings about Qantas's role in resisting new airline services from other carriers. I again responded by saying that consultancy arrangements of this kind were entirely a matter for Qantas itself to sort out. I interpolate there that some further information about the nature of the work that it was, and still is, intended that Mr Young do is contained in the news release issued by Qantas yesterday which identifies a number of different subject areas in which, as I can testify from my own experience in this portfolio-experience which, mercifully for the nation, is not likely to be replicated by Senator Messner-there is ample scope and opportunity for consultants with Mr Young's sort of background and skills to do a very useful job of work indeed.

Might I repeat that I had no knowledge of the detail of the proposal or of its having gone to the Qantas Board on Wednesday last week or of the appointment being made until, as I said, the Qantas Press release became the subject of publicity on Friday. In fact, I had been under the impression that any possible appointment was still some time away. I say further as to the terms and conditions of that appointment, I did not seek and have not sought detailed information about that. I regard it essentially as a matter for Qantas and Mr Young to sort out on commercial terms. Until the matter needs to be further pursued in some way that makes it necessary for me to do so, I shall not pursue that matter further. I simply note on the public record what Qantas has made the subject of public record, that is, that the suggestions that have been made-clearly, the reference there is to Mr Beale's suggestions concerning Mr Young's remuneration-are grossly exaggerated. I think that that point should be very clearly understood.

My judgment of or approval for the appointment was not sought at any stage; nor would it have been appropriate for Qantas to do so. Let me say, on the record, that Qantas is an organisation with an annual revenue of $2.45 billion, employing nearly 14,000 people, employing a very large number of consultants in a variety of areas, operating for all practical purposes an independent company with a very independently-minded board of directors and operating in an environment in which this Government is seeking to further disengage itself from most remaining external controls and constraints and that this is exactly the kind of decision which Qantas does make and should go on making for itself.

Let me deal further with the question contained in the latter part of Senator Messner's question about the alleged conflict of interest that was necessarily involved in Mr Young working for Qantas while President of the Australian Labor Party. There was no inherent conflict of interest in that particular relationship. I want to say three things in support of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is worthy of your time as Attorney-General-the same inability to understand conflict of interest.

—I appreciate that it is a bit too complex and subtle for a grandstanding vulgarian such as Senator Chaney to appreciate, nonetheless, let me say it for the record: there was no reason to assume that Mr Young's work for Qantas would have involved him in any activity directly related to the privatisation debate. As is clear from the Qantas statement made yesterday, a whole variety of tasks has been proposed for him only one of which, that is to say increasing public awareness of the constraints confronting Qantas in its current operations, could be said to be even indirectly relevant. Secondly, in the unlikely event that Mr Young did become involved in paid activity for Qantas which might have been perceived as committing him to one outcome or another in the privatisation debate, this situation could have been remedied in the usual way; that is to say, by publicly disclosing the interest in question and/or withdrawing from participation in that debate at the national conference.

ANSWER.PARA: The third thing I want to say, and I want to say it with some vigour, is that it is not reasonable to expect a party president, or any other national conference delegate for that matter, to refrain from paid employment simply on the ground that that employment might be perceived by someone as giving rise to a possible conflict of interest. It must be a matter of determining whether there is a conflict of interest in all the circumstances of a particular case as it arises. It would have been quite premature to make such a judgment in Mr Young's case at this stage.

Notwithstanding these considerations and the force of these considerations, and leaving aside for present purposes all the hypocrisy and cant that has come from the Opposition in this respect-we can come back to this later if it is necessary-Mick Young has now taken the view that this is just one more argument that he and the Party can do without and that he would prefer in all the circumstances to step down from the presidency. That has been his decision alone, and it ought to be respected as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving aside all of the hand-washing that the Minister for Transport and Communications has just engaged in, the point of the last part of the question was not so much about the position of Mr Young as President of the Australian Labor Party but rather the use of his contacts as a former senior Minister in this Government to put through the kinds of things that the Minister apparently wants with Qantas Airways Ltd. Will the Minister please answer that part of the question?
—The question is premised on a series of totally false assumptions.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of the inbound tourism figures which were released today by the Government Statistician? What are the implications for the Australian tourism industry of these figures, which follow closely upon the recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development assessment that Australia is the fastest growing tourist destination in the world? Is tourism now making a major contribution to our improving balance of payments position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. I am pleased to say that they continue to show the phenomenal growth that has taken place in tourism in Australia since the Hawke Government came to office and since it got a Minister in John Brown who got on with the job. Inbound tourism in Australia is booming, with a record of approximately 1.8 million overseas visitors to Australia in 1987. Of course, that is a phenomenal figure, representing a 25 per cent increase in inbound tourism during 1987 on top of what was already a 25 per cent increase in 1986. Of course, those figures substantiate the claims made only a couple of weeks ago by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development that Australia now is the fastest growing tourist destination in the world. The number of Japanese tourists to Australia in one year increased by 48 per cent to 216,000, and that increase is closely followed by the markets of the United States of America and Asia, which have gone up by 26 per cent and 25 per cent respectively. No doubt the industry's ties with the Japanese and Asian markets will be even more important in the years to come. I should point out that the surge in tourist numbers highlights the need for an increase in the standard of service which we can provide. Now we have the customers, we need to make sure that they go home satisfied customers. Forecasts by the Bureau of Tourism Research indicate that during 1988 we will top two million visitors for the first time.

ANSWER.PARA: To answer Senator Maguire's question about what contribution tourism can make to our balance of payments and, indeed, to our economy as a whole, it is worth noting that international tourists spent $2.7 billion in Australia in 1987. They created 15,000 new jobs and generated export earnings comparable to those of the wool industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Justice aware of a comprehensive legal opinion delivered to the Prime Minister this afternoon which asserts that the Minister for Community Services and Health broke the law in providing Health Insurance Commission information to the member for Canning? If that is so, will the Minister for Justice ensure that this opinion is immediately referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions?
—I am not aware of any such opinion.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister for Justice agree that, if senior counsel with more facts at his disposal than the Commonwealth Solicitor-General had to give his opinion which was published by the Government as a vindication of Dr Blewett, has advised-and I understand that he has-that Dr Blewett has broken the law, that is a matter that should go to the Director of Public Prosecutions? If the Minister does not agree with that I ask: Who should it go to? Who should consider that matter?

—I am not prepared to accept the premise in the supplementary question that the senior counsel referred to had access to further facts that were not available to Dr Gavan Griffith. Dr Griffith, the Commonwealth Solicitor-General, gave his opinion on the basis of those documents which had been placed before the House of Representatives chamber by Dr Blewett and on those documents alone. I cannot accept at the moment that the Queen's Counsel referred to by the honourable senator had access to any further information than was before the House of Representatives chamber. As I understand it, the matter is being investigated by the Australian Federal Police. They will come to some assessment of the factual situation and make their report available to the Director of Public Prosecutions. I will make inquiries about this legal opinion and seek advice as to what should be done with it.

—The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would be aware of media reports during the past six months or so concerning studies into the feasibility of a commercial space port at Cape York in Queensland. What role is the Commonwealth Government taking in this project? Additionally, what prospects exist for Australian industry participation in the project if it proceeds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government supports the Queensland Government's efforts to develop a commercial space port at Cape York. I have been asked by the Prime Minister to co-ordinate the Commonwealth's role in the current detailed feasibility studies for this major commercial project. The Commonwealth's role will be important in facilitating the project while safeguarding Australia's national and international obligations and objectives. There seems to be intense worldwide interest in the space port concept. This was evident during my recent trip to China, where the technical advantages of a launch site near the Equator were regarded as very important. It is also evidenced in the wide international acceptance of Australia by other nations and the growing trends towards fully commercial space launch activities. These factors all combine to make a strong case for a joint multinational launch facility at Cape York. Preliminary discussions about the space port have taken place with the Queensland Premier, Mr Ahern, and further detailed discussions will occur.

ANSWER.PARA: I will also be approaching Commonwealth Ministers asking them to identify all issues raised by the space port proposal and will set in train appropriate and speedy processes for resolving such issues. The ultimate benefit to Australia of building an international space port will depend on the extent of industrial development which results-a matter to which Senator Colston specifically referred. The Commonwealth Government will be seeking to maximise opportunities for industrial development which this can assist Australian industry to become internationally competitive. The Australian Space Board, which advises the Government on space industry matters, will be asked to provide an evaluation of these opportunities and/or appropriate arrangements for achieving maximum benefits. The Australian Space Office within my Department will have day to day responsibility for co-ordinating Federal Government activities in relation to the space port. I might add that the matter is subject to current feasibility studies. Those feasibility studies are being conducted in an environment of growing interest in the possible development of this facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, though the matter might be the responsibility of either the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade or the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to the Government's decision to grant visas to approximately 100 South African experts to attend a gold conference in Melbourne between 16 and 20 May. Why has the Government decided to support the actions of the South African white elite in the gold and mining circles to promote the interests of the apartheid system when only a matter of months ago the South African Government denied an exit visa to the secretary of the mineworkers union of South Africa to attend an international miners conference held in Sydney in November 1987? Does not this suggest that the Government's policy with regard to South Africa is shot through with inconsistencies?
—I am not familiar with the circumstances outlined in Senator Macklin's question--
—The answer is yes.

—Senator Chaney tells me that the answer is yes. Perhaps one day he will have an opportunity to sit on this side of the House, though he will be a very old man at that time. I shall seek advice and provide an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Can the Minister assure the Parliament that all remaining areas of rainforest on Christmas Island will be preserved, consistent with commitments given to that effect by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Gary Punch, in his Press release dated 11 February 1988, and as required to honour our commitments under the agreement between Japan and Australia for the protection of migratory birds and birds in danger of extinction and their environment? Can the Minister also assure the Parliament that proper management of the rainforest environment of Christmas Island will form the basis of what Mr Punch referred to as `the Government's long term strategy of the island as a tourism based economy'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time that we have heard of rainforests this week, though probably it will not be the last. Christmas Island, as Senator Vallentine said, is one of our nation's great environmental assets, and its rainforests make it even more so. There are an extraordinary number of endemic species of plants and animals, some of which are endangered. As an example, there are 16 species of land crabs, two of them endemic. The annual migration of the red crab, which all senators have probably seen in various news clips, is a phenomenon that is indeed spectacular. The island is also a nesting area for large populations of various Indian Ocean seabirds. It is the last breeding ground of the Abbott's booby bird. The Christmas Island bosun bird and the frigate bird are also endangered species.
—How are your boobooks going?

—No, these are not boobooks. This is not Norfolk Island; this is Christmas Island. There are six species protected under agreements between the Japanese and Australian governments for the protection of migratory birds and birds in danger of extinction. The island, with these natural environmental attractions and, of course, its tropical climate, is potentially a very attractive tourist destination. As Senator Vallentine would be aware, a Perth-based group is planning a multimillion dollar casino tourist development for the island, which should form some of the basis for the island's future economic life.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's strategy for the island is to facilitate the development of such industries, to provide an employment base to compensate for the wind-down of the island's phosphate mining. Over the past few years the Government has reluctantly allowed the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island to clear some rainforests to enable the mine to remain viable. Rainforest clearing programs were agreed to between the Corporation and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. To give examples of the last couple of clearances, no rainforest clearing has occurred since March 1987, when 2.3 hectares were cleared; and the previous clearance, in 1986, involved 10.5 hectares. By way of comparison, the Christmas Island National Park covers some 3,270 hectares, or 17 per cent of the island. In line with the unique environmental and tourist potential of the island, I am considering a further extension of the national park, which will almost double its size. Hopefully, I can announce that and a plan of management for the enlarged area very shortly. Now that the Government-owned mine has ceased operation, the Government is under no obligation to allow clearance of any environmentally significant areas for the benefit of private companies. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Gary Punch, has received several expressions of interest in future mining and has indicated to the companies concerned that rainforest clearing will not be permitted. Some companies are able to comply with this requirement in developing their feasibility studies, as there are significant stockpiles of mined phosphate which they can clear and remove in an environmentally sensitive manner that will probably help with some of the rehabilitation work which must go on.

Mr Punch has also received representations from environmental groups expressing concern at the possibility of environmental damage through future mining. Just yesterday he received a 14-page petition from Christmas Island residents commending his statement of 11 February concerning no further rainforest clearing. They expressed their delight at the Government's recognition of the importance of Christmas Island rainforests, and we see no reason why any more rainforest need go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his comprehensive answer. I just seek a further assurance from him that the heavy earth-moving equipment that would be required to carry out the necessary rehabilitation of mined-out areas will be available for this work before being handed over to the liquidators of the Christmas Island phosphate company for disposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it will be available but I will make doubly certain of that and will inform the honourable senator, hopefully tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer him to the attack by his colleague the Minister for Finance on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation campaign against funding cuts, which Senator Walsh described as an improper use of taxpayers' funds-I think quite justly so, if I may say so-and in particular to Senator Walsh's statement, `That an organisation allegedly strapped for cash can find money for these activities is bizarre'. Does the Minister agree that it is equally bizarre for Qantas Airways Ltd, a company which is 100 per cent owned by the taxpayers of Australia, to be devoting resources, through the employment of the Hon. Mick Young, to changing Government policy-that is, Australian Labor Party policy-on its ownership structure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question once again is based on a totally false premise-that Qantas was planning, contemplating or in any other way proposing to employ Mr Young for that purpose. Qantas has made it perfectly clear in its Press release of yesterday that Mr Young's role will include advice on the following matters: to improve communication with all governments within Australia, including State governments; to assist in human resources development within the company; and to increase public understanding and awareness of the constraints, both national and international, on Qantas, in a period of exceptional opportunity for the company and Australia. I have made a comment about the potential relevance of all of that for the privatisation debate.

ANSWER.PARA: Might I say from my own experience that many instances constantly arise where it would be advantageous to Qantas to have someone with the combination of skills and experience-in particular, communication skills-and a reputation and so on within State government circles, the trade union movement and elsewhere of the kind that Mr Young has.

Let me give the Senate three quick examples. One is the excitement that arose in the latter part of last year when, almost to a person, the tourist industry spokesmen and aviation and travel writers responded to a campaign of disinformation waged by a number of international carriers seeking preferred access rights to Australia, claiming that there was a massive shortfall in capacity and that Qantas was standing in the way of those additional service rights being granted by reason of a protective attitude by that company and by the Government towards it. That was an exercise that needed a response, as it got, at the political level and at managerial level within the company, but it was an exercise of public communication and industry communication that could have been much assisted by someone of Mr Young's skills. That is one example.

A second example is the kind of larger scale industrial relations issue which does not involve the resolution of particular disputes, which obviously can be well handled by the existing industrial relations machinery within a company such as Qantas, but which does involve larger issues of policy and an acceptance of change and so on on the part of the union organisations involved. Some of the productivity-based negotiations that Qantas, like everybody else, has been involved in in this respect suggest themselves as one such example. So, too, do the current issues that have arisen, both within the company and, indeed, in the community at large, about superannuation policy.

Let me give the honourable senator a third example, again drawn from my own experience in this portfolio; and it would be an experience familiar to a number of people who make representations of this kind on behalf of particular States or capital cities. Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth are constantly complaining that they have insufficient access to direct air services internationally because, they allege, of Qantas's passion for protecting its routes and services from any degree of competition. The reality is that it is much more complex than that-the national interest considerations that have to be weighed and balanced against the competing claims that are made by particular airlines and the difficulties and issues that arise when one is allocating and negotiating air service agreements and capacity entitlements of this kind.

There are issues that do involve input, not only from the Government and from the company in the sense of permanent personnel, but also from consultants who do have the kind of skills which Mr Young manifestly possesses in abundance. It is completely nonsensical to make the claim that has been made by Senator Stone, by Senator Messner earlier on and by a variety of other people, that the only conceivable justification for Mr Young's appointment was in the context of an issue which is not yet the subject of any Government policy, let alone Party policy, and which is not the subject of any particular view at this stage of Qantas itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's reply and, indeed, in the light of his earlier reply in Question Time this afternoon in answer to a question asked by Senator Messner, does he mean to tell us that he saw-and he said that he was first informed about this some weeks ago-and sees nothing at all improper in the course of action which was originally contemplated some weeks ago and, in due course, consummated, whether by Qantas or by his ex-ministerial colleague and at that time President of the Australian Labor Party, the Hon. Mick Young, in accepting a fee for providing the only services which the Hon. Mick Young could provide, namely, political services to Qantas?
—Again, Mr President, that supplementary question is based on a series of false premises which I simply do not accept. As such I will treat the question with the contempt that it deserves.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is it true that the buoyant state of the New South Wales economy has been an important factor in pushing the Commonwealth Budget into surplus? Will the Minister provide the Senate with information regarding the sensitivity of the Commonwealth Budget outcome to variations in the condition of the labour markets of the various States of the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question was whether the economic performance in New South Wales has helped push the Commonwealth Budget into surplus. The answer to that is very definitely yes. I will give Senator Messner some details because I am very sure he will be interested in what I have to say. In the year ended February, total employment in New South Wales grew by an astounding 5.4 per cent, which was, not surprisingly, the highest rate of increase for any State. The rate of increase was some 2.2 percentage points above the national average of 3.2 per cent. Of course, a national average of 3.2 per cent is, in itself, a very high figure-a figure rarely achieved in Australia but which has been eclipsed very substantially by the astounding 5.4 per cent growth in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: Had the growth of employment in New South Wales been on the national average, instead of 2.2 percentage points above it, 155,000 fewer people would have been in employment. If only half of those had been on unemployment benefit-and that is a very conservative assumption-unemployment benefit payments would have been more than half a billion dollars higher than they in fact will be. On that very conservative assumption of only half of these additional employed people being taken off or prevented from going on unemployment benefit, that saved the Commonwealth Budget more than half a billion dollars-that is, $500m-in Commonwealth expenditure. It is a very conservative assumption because the growth of employment in New South Wales has been spectacularly higher than the high national average.

We can look at this in another way. If New South Wales had the misfortune to be governed by the sort of government that Queensland has and consequently had a Queensland-style employment growth rate-that is, of 1.9 per cent-there would have been 90,000 fewer persons employed in New South Wales than there are today. The cost, if the whole 90,000 were on unemployment benefit, would be more than $600m. That does not tell the whole story as far as the Commonwealth Budget outcome is concerned. If people are employed instead of being on unemployment benefit there is a double whammy effect: first, they are paying taxes and, secondly, they are not drawing social security benefits. I have not attempted to quantify the amount of tax that those additional employed people in New South Wales would have paid, but it is likely to be very high-higher than one would expect-because of the extraordinary amount of overtime that is being worked in New South Wales. For the December quarter of 1987, compared with the December quarter of 1986, average overtime worked in New South Wales increased by nearly 25 per cent as against 3.9 per cent for the rest of Australia. Again, 3.9 per cent is not an unhealthy figure, but it looks a poor outcome compared with the spectacular growth in the overtime worked in New South Wales.

Between the September quarter of 1986 and the December quarter of 1987 private sector job vacancies in New South Wales increased by 26 per cent. In the rest of Australia-which is handicapped by having States such as Queensland and Tasmania-the number of private sector job vacancies declined by 6.2 per cent. Therefore, it is impossible to quantify with precision the degree to which the astonishing employment growth in New South Wales, relative to the rest of the country, has contributed to the Commonwealth Budget going into surplus. Even on the most conservative assumptions it would have to be of the order of $1 billion and probably it is as high as $1.5 billion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to the media statement by the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Temby, on 8 March in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: As a result of certain additional information which we received yesterday, it has been necessary to request the Australian Federal Police to undertake further investigations into the electoral donation by Harris Daishowa (Aust) Pty Ltd.

I ask the Minister: First, what additional information was Mr Temby referring to and why was it not available at the time of the original investigation by the Australian Federal Police? Secondly, was this information received from the Australian Federal Police? Thirdly, if not, was it received from Australian Labor Party sources? If the answers to the second and third questions are both in the negative, from whom was it received? Finally, does the information relate in any way to Mr Mick Young's role in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been informed that the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) requested the Australian Federal Police to undertake further investigations into the matter of the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd donation. All I have seen is the statement for the media issued by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions and released, I think, on 8 March 1988. All it says is:

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of certain additional information which we received yesterday, it has been necessary to request the Australian Federal Police to undertake further investigations into the electoral donation by Harris Daishowa (Aust) Pty Ltd. The DPP is not in a position to say what course will ultimately be taken until the further inquiries have been completed. Nor can we say how long that will take.

The Government has not sought advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions and has no knowledge of what prompted the request for further inquiries. I have already indicated that it would be highly improper for me or any other Minister to seek to know what the Australian Federal Police, in its operational role, is undertaking by way of inquiries into this matter. The Australian Federal Police will make its report available to the Director of Public Prosecutions, with the further refinement and clarifications apparently sought on the basis of additional information which came into the knowledge of the Director of Public Prosecutions. I do not know how long that process will take and I can go no further than the media release of the DPP.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTION: COST OF OPPOSITION PROMISES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister made any assessment of the cost if the promises made by Mr Greiner in the New South Wales State election campaign were implemented? If a similar increase in spending were applied to the other States, what would be the total addition to spending by the States? Are there any precedents for promises of increases in expenditure in either the Commonwealth or any of the States? What would be the effect on the Commonwealth Budget if Mr Greiner's promises were implemented?

—I take a point of order, Mr President. In light of the longstanding hypocrisy of the Government on these issues, when it professes an expert knowledge of what is being done by Liberal or non-Labor administrations and total and absolute ignorance of what has been done by Labor administrations-such as the Burke Administration, which pledged $150m worth of taxpayers' money, and has thrown a lot more money down the drain on behalf of Western Australian taxpayers-and that extraordinary double standard, which is constantly evidenced by this Minister, can I draw your attention to the fact that the early part of the question--
—On a point of order, Mr President: Is it in order--
—Biggles, I am on a point of order.
—Well, my point of order--
—Well, you cannot take a point of order on a point of order, you silly ass.
—is that it is not a point of order to behave in an offensive and vulgar fashion.
—Order! I believe it is in order to take a point of order on a point of order.
—I am indebted to you, Mr President. That was the advice that I had sought and received from the Clerk.
—In that case I will take a point of order on the Minister. We can keep that going all day, if you like, Mr President.
—Order! I will listen to Senator Evans's point of order.

—My point of order is: Is it in order, Mr President, in the guise of making a point of order, to make a series of vulgar allegations about hypocrisy, cant, opportunism and all the rest of the things that Senator Chaney has said without coming to the point of his point of order?
—There is no point of order. I listened to Senator Chaney and I do not think he broke any of the Standing Orders.

—Thank you, Mr President, I was very careful not to break any of the Standing Orders and I thank you for that ruling. My point is that I submit that the early part of the question was clearly out of order. In a formal sense part of it was brought into order at the end of the question, but I ask you to restrict the Minister to those parts of the question which are in order, and to avoid this abuse of Question Time.
—There is no point of order. The Minister is entitled to answer a question which the Minister accepts as in his area of responsibility, and I ask him to do that in answering this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, it is of considerable interest to the Commonwealth Government what the level of State government spending is and what the level of fiscal responsibility or irresponsibility is of State governments. I was asked three quite precise questions seeking answers of fact, and finally a more general question of what effect Mr Greiner's promised programs would have on the Commonwealth Budget if they were implemented. The first question was: has an assessment of the cost of Mr Greiner's promises been made? The answer is yes, an assessment has been made and it was spelt out in great detail-I table the relevant Press release and attached documents-by the Treasurer and me about 12 days ago at a Press conference in Sydney. Promises of $1.43 billion in additional expenditure proposals have been dribbled out by Mr Greiner to particular vested interests and pressure groups over the last six months or so. I understand that since then, in the last 10 days, an additional $270m worth of promises have dribbled out from the New South Wales machine. I am unable to give details of that $270m. However, leaving aside that additional $270m for which I cannot provide precise details, costing assumptions and parameters, if all the States were to go on a spending binge of the size proposed by Mr Greiner in New South Wales there would be an increase in total State government spendings of $4 billion-an extra $4 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that Mr Greiner has asserted that the costings in the document produced by Mr Keating and me are not correct. However, he has not attempted to disprove any of the specific items which are costed in that document, for the very good reason that he cannot do so. Even if there were people in the Liberal Party who were numerate-I must say that the evidence over the last 12 months or so is not supportive of that-they could not challenge significantly those costings. That is why Mr Greiner has not tried to do so; he has just tried to dismiss the entire document. I regret to say that some sections of the media have so far allowed him to get away with it. So there is the $1.43 billion and an extra $270m, not specified by the Treasurer or me anyway, making a total of $1.7 billion.

I was asked whether there are precedents for promises of increases in expenditure of this magnitude by the Commonwealth or other States. I am aware of two precedents. One is the $8 billion worth of tax cuts promised by the Federal Opposition in the last election campaign, which were not matched by expenditure cuts, and the other is the notorious 1982 Budget, the last Budget which the discredited former Treasurer brought down, which had no economic strategy; it was just a political strategy aimed at buying up every pressure group and vested interest that could be identified-just as Mr Greiner is doing now-leaving us with a prospective Budget deficit of $10 billion. Honourable senators need not take my word for that; they can take Senator Stone's word for it. I can quote him, if honourable senators would like me to do so. Senator Stone said that Mr Howard's last Budget was an explosion of spending without precedent in peacetime. Mr Greiner is going down the same way.

It is coincidental, I believe, that the forward estimates of expenditure which the Fraser Government left behind had built into them, with no policy changes, an 8 per cent real increase in the first out-year and a 14 per cent increase in the second year. Mr Greiner has gone a bit beyond that. If he actually proceeded with all the promises that he has made for increased spending, his real increase in spending would be somewhat above 8 per cent, on the 1987-88 base, which is marginally down, in real terms, on the year preceding that.

Finally, I was asked what effect the proposals, if implemented, would have on the Commonwealth Budget. They would have no direct effect on the outlay side of the Budget because I have already stated that if Mr Greiner is elected and proceeds with that wild spending spree, he will not be bailed out of the fiscal hole into which New South Wales will fall by the Commonwealth Government or by any enhanced payments from the Commonwealth Budget. So the proposals will have no direct effect on Commonwealth Budget outlays. If Mr Greiner proceeds with such a policy, the people of New South Wales will just have to put up with it-should they be misguided enough to elect him. A possibility, if the policy were to be implemented, is that New South Wales government taxes and charges would have to be increased to offset the $1.43 to $1.7 billion additional expenditure. The effect of that would be to push up substantially the inflation rate in New South Wales, which would have repercussions for both the revenue and the outlay sides of the Commonwealth Budget. It is a bit difficult to judge how they would finally balance out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce concerns work bans by clerks in the Australian Customs Service on the processing of diesel fuel rebate claims which have stopped the payment of claims. Is the Minister aware that the bans have been in place now for over three weeks? Is the Minister aware that the bans have held up the reimbursement of over $40m to about 10,000 claimants around Australia and that the amount is growing daily? Is the Minister aware that this delay in reimbursing legitimate claims is causing great financial hardship to small primary producers, many of whom are already suffering considerable financial hardship? Will the Minister intervene to ensure speedy resolution of the dispute which has led to the bans? Will the Government pay interest on the outstanding amounts to recompense producers for the financial hardship caused by the bans?

—I am aware of the existence of bans in the diesel fuel rebate section of the Customs Service. I am not aware of all the details which Senator Lewis alleges in his question. I will seek information about those matters. I think it unlikely that the Commonwealth would pay interest on any outstanding rebates.
—We have to pay interest if we don't pay our taxes on time, though.

—If Senator Panizza is in favour of that he could certainly advance that view in the Senate. I think it unlikely that the Government would do that. As soon as I obtain some further information, I will provide Senator Lewis with a more detailed answer.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to Press reports in recent months about the possible involvement of the Queensland Government in a deal to develop a coal-fired power plant in Turkey and the more recent statement by the Queensland Premier that his Government no longer wished to take a major role in the project. What action has the Commonwealth Government taken to assist the bid by the consortium led by SEAPAC, a Sydney-based consulting and infrastructure project promoting company, to build a power plant and a deep water port in Turkey?
—They have asked the Greiner government to help.

—The first thing that can be said in answer to the question and in reply to the interjection as to whether we will ask a Greiner government to help, is that we will not. That is a figment of Senator Chaney's imagin- ation which will probably remain so. The proposed consortium is in a position to take advantage of a very substantial opportunity in Turkey. It is a large project which offers substantial opportunity for both Australian equipment and coal suppliers. The consortium is certainly to be complimented for its success to date in securing this project against strong international competition. I should say that the Queensland Government under the leadership of the former Premier had undertaken to take a significant equity position in the venture to secure a long term coal market for Queensland coal producers. The Queensland Government, as led by Mr Ahern, has re-assessed its position and has announced that it is no longer able to take the major role previously envisaged.
—You know why?

—Yes. It is not, I believe, appropriate for the Australian Government to provide direct equity assistance for projects of this kind. That is probably the role of the private sector and those who might benefit directly from the projects. At the same time there are various other forms of assistance which might be available to support SEAPAC in its efforts to maintain maximum Australian involvement in the project. The Government will continue to examine these as appropriate. I must say that recently some interest has been expressed in the project by a number of corporations in other States. The Queensland Government, although clearly not interested in a significant equity position, has a continuing interest in the project. It is possible that it will proceed, but based only on its commercial merits.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Will the Minister inform me whether Australian National is negotiating with Westrail regarding the takeover of the Kalgoorlie-Perth standard gauge railway line? If so, what stage are the negotiations at or, in fact, is the takeover a fait accompli?

—Some discussions, which were initiated by Mr Duncan when he was Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, are going on about the rationalisation of the operations in Western Australia of Australian National and Westrail. Because that is a matter that has now been taken over by Mr Peter Morris and one with which I am not dealing personally, I am not sure what stage those discussions have reached. I shall seek information from my colleague and let the honourable senator know as soon as possible.

—I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister has obtained that information, will he inform the Senate why a rail administration, at a main centre along the line, has already been issued with Australian National stationery in the form of work sheets? Will the Minister obtain that information as well?
—Yes, I shall be delighted to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 24 February entitled `Mining production goes up 14 per cent in December quarter'. That article states that the increased production should earn a further $1.5 billion for Australia in 1987. The article states also that the industry has greatly benefited from an end to unnecessary work practices, a reduction in industrial disputation and a capacity to adapt to demand production. My question is: Can the Minister confirm the substance of this report? Is the Minister of the view that, despite record low prices for some ores, the mining industry is adopting a strategy which is helping Australian exports?

—I have not seen the article to which Senator Foreman refers, but since he has drawn my attention to it I will, of course, acquaint myself with it in detail. Given the background to his question, there are some aspects of his question to which I can reply. It is true that in the last period for which figures have been published Australia exported record volumes of commodities from mining. It is true also that most of those commodities have been exported into an oversupplied world market and that in order for Australia to be more competitive in that world market we need to improve our efficiencies in all the inputs into the mining process. Senator Foreman asked about work practices. I think there is a case for introducing improved work and managerial practices in the mining industry. I hope that that is one of the things that we will see evolve and develop out of the second tier wage discussions and whatever form of wage fixation arrangements are decided upon in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The Minister will be aware of the fact that Queensland has the highest student retention rate to year 12 of any State of Australia at 58 per cent, when the national average is lower than 50 per cent. However, at the same time it has the lowest participation rate in tertiary education in the country. For example, in 1987, 37.2 per cent of those in the age bracket below 20 missed out on participation in tertiary education in Queensland, with the State coming closest to that figure being New South Wales at 28.2 per cent and with Tasmania at only 8.3 per cent. In view of the fact that the Federal Government has total responsibility for the funding of universities and colleges of advanced education and that this Government has had this responsibility for the last five years, why has it continued to dump Queensland school leavers to such an extent that, through lack of Federal Government funding, considerably fewer of them than their equivalents in other States are able to attain a tertiary education? When and to what extent will the Government act to correct this blatant discrimination against young Queenslanders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the rhetorical flourish at the end of the question. I think Senator Parer said in his question that participation in tertiary education in Queensland is the lowest of all the States in Australia. I am not sure whether that is correct, but I am well aware of the fact that it is low and it has long been so. That is the result of many things. I think in particular, going back over an extremely long period, so long that it is even before a National Party or Country Party government, back to Labor administrations in the 1930s and 1940s and continued by National and Country Party administrations since 1957, it is the result of a neglect-I do not think that is too strong a word-of primary and secondary education, and an ethos has developed in Queensland out of that.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the final part of the question, I accept that this Government has been in office for five years and it is not defensible to go on blaming predecessors over a very long period for everything that is wrong. But the implication of Senator Parer's question is that this Government has taken no steps, or has not put in place any policies, to correct that imbalance. That is not true.
