I do not have the figures with me now but I think three weeks ago I answered a question in the Senate in which I gave details and specific numbers of the more rapid rate of increase, in percentage terms, in students taking part in tertiary education in Queensland than in any other State-certainly well above the national average. If Senator Parer wants those figures I can get them I think within a day or two and supply them to him. We are not saying that parity with the rest of Australia has been restored but, because of the deliberate policies of this Government, it is moving in that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen Press reports indicating that show bags containing so-called victim toys may be sold at the forthcoming Sydney show? What action is the Government taking to protect children from these toys?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen one Press report in the Sydney Sun-Herald indicating that it may be that victim toys will be appearing in show bags at the Sydney show this weekend. For the information of the Senate I should just read one paragraph of that report:

ANSWER.PARA: The Dr Disgusting bag, for $6, with its stickers of `garbage pail kids'-One Eyed Jack and Brutal Brad-and the rubber vomit, passed the test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sounds like a Queensland National Party team.
—I take Senator Ray's point that it might have some reference to honourable senators on the other side of the chamber. Being serious about this problem, victim toys are--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Since the interjection has been incorporated in Hansard I ask for a withdrawal. I would not have taken a point of order had it not been incorporated.
—I ask that it be withdrawn.
—It is certainly withdrawn.

—I did not think there was any reference to ferocious Fred in the bag. Victim toys are those that depict physical injury, mutilation or deformity. The Government has for some time been concerned that these toys may be available on the market. In early August 1987, the then Minister for Consumer Affairs approached importers and the major distributors requesting them seriously to consider stopping the distribution and sale of those toys.

ANSWER.PARA: Following that period from August 1987 an inquiry was set up by the Government headed by the Hon. R. G. Reynolds, QC, a retired judge of the New South Wales Supreme Court, and chairman of the legislative committee of the Child Accident Prevention Foundation of Australia. He has also been involved in child accident prevention and law reform. The members of the committee were drawn from consumer organisation, toy manufacturers, industry associations and other interested groups. The committee proceeded on the basis of calling for public submissions and reported to the then Minister on 23 December 1987.

The committee formed the view that victim toys would affect some children in one or more of a number of specifically undesirable or anti-social ways. However, the committee's major concern was to see whether the damage to children could be taken within the provisions of the Trade Practices Act, which is limited to action against consumer goods presenting physical injury hazards and did not cover psychological injury. Faced with this problem the committee then had two alternatives from which to proceed. It chose the one of self-regulation and, as a first step towards this self-regulatory process, drafted guidelines which were approved by the Australian Retailers Association and the Australian Toy Association Pty Ltd, which together cover some 98 per cent of all toy retailers in Australia. Those regulations were also accepted by the Government. The Government made it clear at the time that we would monitor this self-regulation process over the next 12 months to ascertain its effectiveness.

The concern the Government now has, particularly as a consequence of this article and evidence that is coming to the Department, as I am informed, is that the situation may be that victim toys are being promoted, and may be promoted, contrary to the self-regulatory process.

As a consequence of this the Government has written to the retailers involved in the show alerting them to the self-regulatory agreement in the first instance and also alerting them to the fact that the Government is concerned that if the self-regulation process is not successful, at the end of the trial period the Government may have to consider introducing legislation under the Trade Practices Act to ban such products.

I should say in closing that the Government is not here making an assessment of what is good or bad taste. However, the Government has a major concern about psychological damage to children in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Lewis asked me a question about disputes in the diesel fuel rebate processing section of the Australian Customs Service. Senator Lewis is probably aware that the dispute involves a decision to centralise the processing of diesel fuel claims in one location. That decision follows an Efficiency Scrutiny Unit report obtained last year. There has been considerable industrial unrest about the matter. The Australian Customs Service has again referred the matter to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and a hearing is listed for tomorrow. I hope that that hearing will lead to a resolution of the dispute. If so, of course, many of the more colourful aspects of Senator Lewis's question will be taken care of.
—Mr President, could I move that the Senate take note of the statement?
—I do not think the Minister has finished the statement at this stage.

—Perhaps we could take note of half of it. Senator Lewis raised a number of issues about the effects of the industrial action. I do not dissent from the view implicit in what the honourable senator said about some of the unfortunate consequences of that action. However, I hope there will be an early resolution of the matter.

—Senator Macklin asked me a question today about participation by South Africans at a bicentennial gold conference in Melbourne on 18 to 20 May. As I recall Senator Macklin's question it was suggested that a large number of South Africans will participate, and that most of the participants are executives of gold mining companies. I am advised-and at this stage I am giving limited information only-that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is aware of about 50 applications from South African mining experts, mostly academics and technical experts, to participate in the conference. All of these applications are being considered on a case by case basis in accordance with the Australian Government's policy of limiting official and other contact with South Africa. However, given South Africa's position as the world's major gold producer, the Government accepts that representation from that country is desirable and appropriate.

—On 18 February I replied to a question from Senator Maguire about a global display at the Jimmy Carter Presidential Library in Atlanta, Georgia, which indicated that nuclear weapons are stationed in Australia. I said at the time that the location of a couple of light bulbs on a map in the Jimmy Carter museum does not seem, on the face of it, to count for very much by way of evidence. Nonetheless, I asked that the matter be followed up by the Australian Embassy in Washington, and the embassy has been in contact with the Director of the library to see whether he knows anything that we do not know. I now advise the honourable senator that the Director has advised that the global display had been constructed for the library by a `museum company' but that the library now recognised that errors had been made. The Director undertook to remove from the display indications that nuclear weapons were stationed in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 February Senator Hamer asked me a question about the differences in the cost of container handling between union-approved depots and non-union depots. I undertook at that time to provide the honourable senator with further information, which I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Industrial agreements dating from the early days of containerisation in Australia in the late 1960s have led to the development of two types of container depots handling less-than-full container load (LCL) shipments of cargo

so called ``international'' depots which employ Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) clerks and either Federated Storemen and Packers Union or WWF operational employees. This type of depot packs and unpacks any international LCL shipments.
trans-Tasman depots which employ members of the Transport Workers Union and handle LCL shipments associated with the trans-Tasman trade
In addition a small number of containers are unpacked at conventional common user wharves (such as Darling Harbour in Sydney) by WWF labour.

While both types of depots also handle some full-container-load (FCL) shipments, these are generally packed or unpacked at the consignee or consignor's premises. Over 85% of containers passing through Australian wharves are FCL's.

A survey of depot charges undertaken by the then Bureau of Transport Economics in 1985 on behalf of the Industry Task Force on Shore Based Shipping Costs found charges for packing and unpacking LCL containers at international depots ranged from $500 to $600 per container whereas charges made at trans-Tasman depots ranged from $300 to $400 per container.
A further survey undertaken by the Waterfront Industry Committee's Melbourne Working Party in 1987 found a similar relativity in charges.
about $600 per container for packing and unpacking at international depots
about $250 and $300 per container respectively for packing and unpacking at trans-Tasman depots
The cost differentials reflect differences in the cargo handling operations and nature of cargo handled at each type of depot and the higher labour cost structure in international depots.

Some initiatives have already been undertaken by industry to address the inefficiencies in the international depot sector. With the agreement of the Waterside Workers' Federation innovative employment arrangements involving more flexible working arrangements and providing incentives for increased efficiency have been in operation in two Melbourne depots for some time. These arrangements are reported to have led to substantial improvements in labour productivity at those facilities. Similar arrangements have recently been introduced at a further Melbourne container depot and at a Sydney depot.

Like many areas of the waterfront however it is unrealistic to expect quick or easy fixes to arrangements which have so long received the tacit endorsement of Governments, employers and other interested parties, in the context of a particular short term problem. The Government's Waterfront Strategy is aimed at addressing the underlying causes of these problems through the development of a broad package of measures to achieve substantial improvements in waterfront performance.

The Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet met with major participants in the Waterfront Strategy on 17 February 1988 to review progress in the Strategy. The Committee noted that, while there were substantial problems continuing on the waterfront, very real progress had been achieved already in a number of areas including both productivity based container depot operations and joint venture initiatives undertaken by the Waterside Workers' Federation at smaller ports in Queensland, Victoria and Tasmania. In some cases, these had halved the cost of stevedoring grain and other cargoes. As a result of its discussions with industry participants the Committee felt there was now a firm basis to anticipate that the Strategy would result in agreement by the end of the year to a broad package of measures to achieve significant improvements in waterfront and port efficiency productivity and reliability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1988 the Senate passed a number of resolutions relating to privilege matters which I moved. Unfortunately, due to ministerial commitments, I had to leave the chamber before the end of the debate and I was therefore not able to respond to a number of questions, essentially on technical matters, asked by honourable senators during that debate. I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the responses to those questions that were put to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

(1) Senator Puplick asked (Hansard, p. 634) whether there would be any difference between publication of a response by a person named in the Senate and incorporation of the response in Hansard. The only difference between the two methods is that when a document is ordered to be published by resolution of the Senate copies are distributed by the Table Office to the normal list of recipients or other inquirers, but the text does not appear in Hansard. It is envisaged that in particular circumstances, e.g., if a response were of considerable length or, possibly, a considerable time had elapsed since the debate in the Senate, the Senate may think it appropriate that the response be published rather than incorporated in Hansard.

(2) Senator Puplick asked (Hansard p. 634) whether a response published or incorporated in Hansard would attract absolute privilege. A response published or incorporated would attract absolute privilege; that is why the rules provide that a response be succinct and strictly relevant and not contain anything offensive in character.

(3) Senator Cooney asked (Hansard p.636) about the appropriateness of considering whether a person had a reasonable excuse for committing an act which might be a contempt in relation to such offences as obstructing the Senate in the performance of its functions. Resolution 3 merely indicates that the Senate will consider whether any defence of reasonable excuse is available. Of course, there may be contempts which, by their nature, exclude any defence of reasonable excuse (e.g., threatening a witness), but that does not prevent the Senate from considering whether such a defence is available.

(4) Senator Cooney asked (Hansard p. 637) whether questions as to a witness's credit would be regarded as relevant to a matter under inquiry by a committee. As Senator Durack pointed out, the question of whether a question is relevant would be determined in the first instance by the committee. A committee may well regard questions as to the credit of a witness as relevant, depending on the circumstances, but it would be for the committee to decide, subject to any direction by the Senate. The same answer applies to a question asked by Senator Harradine (Hansard p. 368) concerning relevance of questions.

(5) Senator Harradine questioned (Hansard pp. 638 and 639) the inclusion of the expression ``improperly influence'' in the list of matters which may be treated as contempts. Resolution 6, as its terms indicate, is intended to give some guidance as to matters which may be treated as contempts. It is in the nature of the offence concerned that it is not possible to specify in advance all methods of influencing Senators which may be regarded as improper. It is analogous to such statutory offences as attempting to pervert the course of justice.

(6) Senator Harradine asked (Hansard p. 638) whether the existence of another remedy for an act which may be held to be a contempt, in the criteria to be taken into account when determining matters relating to contempts, refers to the ability to sue a person for an act which may be held to be a contempt. The criterion does refer to the availability of any civil or criminal remedy, but it does not follow that, as Senator Harradine suggested, no account will be taken of a matter because a civil or criminal remedy is available; it is merely a matter to be considered.

(7) Senator Haines referred (Hansard pp. 639 and 640) to the inclusion in the list of matters which may be treated as contempts of the references to influencing Senators and Senators seeking benefits in return for the discharge of their parliamentary duties. That these statements may be too broadly worded was suggested in the explanatory notes accompanying the draft resolutions. Again it must be stressed, however, that Resolution 6 is simply an indication, for the guidance of the public, of matters which may be treated as contempts. The resolution does not commit the Senate Committee to treat any particular matters as contempts, nor does it affect the ability of the Senate to judge particular cases on their merits and according to circumstances. The resolution therefore does not create any difficulties or give rise to any questions which did not exist before the resolution was passed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Lewis-Mr President, I wish to clarify a matter. In the course of a supplementary answer which Senator Button was giving to me, Senator Watson sought leave to move that the Senate take note of the Minister's statement. Senator Button, as I understood it, granted leave at that stage. Is it the ruling that leave was granted and that Senator Watson so moved at that stage, so that, in effect, Senator Button made two statements, or should I now seek leave to move the motion?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be tidier if you seek leave, because I do not think Senator Watson sought leave at all at that stage.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Button-Mr President, if I might give you my version of what happened, I think Senator Watson, in an unseemly fit of enthusiasm, leapt to his feet and interrupted what I was saying. Discovering at the time that he had projected himself into something which he had to withdraw from, he then withdrew. I am quite happy for Senator Watson's motion to be accepted now and for it to relate to the whole of the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that my recollection of the matter was correct. Senator Watson did not formally seek leave at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to a question without notice asked by Senator Lewis this day.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The 1986-87 annual report of the Parliament House Construction Authority has now been tabled in this place. Whilst welcoming that, I draw attention to the fact that it is overdue by many months. That is a very unfortunate situation, given the importance of this report as the Parliament House Construction Authority moves towards the completion of its number one objective, namely, the construction of the new Parliament House, which is to be officially opened on 9 May. Unfortunately, the report has not been available to the Senate during our recent debates on the progress of the Parliament House construction, the last such debate having been held as recently as a couple of weeks ago.

Whilst pointing out the lateness of the report, I link my remarks to those that were made by me and by other senators on this side of the House in the Senate on 18 February. I do not propose to go over all those points again, but I wish to make one or two points. Last week radio station 2GB presented a broadcast, with Mike Carlton as the host, from the new Parliament House, in which interviews were conducted with various persons associated with the building. I was one of those who spoke and I have since received criticism from the Chief Executive of the Construction Authority, Mr Peatey, about my remarks during that broadcast. I wish to take this opportunity of commenting in the Senate on my remarks, because they go to many of the matters that are dealt with in the annual report before us at the moment.

The first point that I was making last week in my comments on the House during the Mike Carlton interview was that I believe that we are going to finish up with a quite magnificent building which will be a matter of great pride for the Australian people for generations to come. I have no criticism at all of the building in that sense. But what I find surprising is that the Government and the Construction Authority appear to be so sensitive to any suggestion that we could have got the quality building that we are undoubtedly going to get at a lesser cost. That point of criticism has been made on this side of the Parliament and by others over a considerable period. I have been taken to task on that matter by the Chief Executive, Mr Peatey, as have other members of the Senate from the Liberal and National parties.

It is a fact that the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, which was chaired so very well and diligently by my colleague Senator Michael Baume and of which I had the pleasure and privilege to be a member, has been very highly critical of many aspects of the financing of the project in terms of waste and inefficiencies. They have been documented time and time again. So also have the very considerable costs in the area of industrial disputation and related matters been brought to the Parliament's attention by the Opposition committee on rorts, which is so well chaired by my colleague Senator Parer.

The criticisms are not just from this side of the Parliament. What is ignored all too often are the very trenchant criticisms that have been aimed by the Auditor-General at management practices, inefficiencies and wastes in the project period and by other committees such as the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I regret that the Authority and the Government have refused to accept--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This belated annual report for a year that ended last June, which we are now debating in March, is, regrettably, another document of which the Parliament House Construction Authority should be ashamed. Among the many matters of concern in this report is a paragraph on page 11 which alleges that criticisms by the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . were largely ill-informed and unfounded and were a matter of deep concern to the Authority in that they posed a serious threat to the bi-partisan nature of the project which had been a feature at its inception.

That is utter bunkum. It is dishonest. I challenge the members of the Parliament House Construction Authority and the person who signed this document to indicate any error of substance made by the Waste Watch Committee in its hordes of allegations, all of which were substantiated, all of which were documented and none of which have been effectively countered by the mountains of paper that have been put out by the Parliament House Construction Authority.

As Senator Short said, none of us on this side of the chamber cavil at the concept of or complain about the quality of the building, but we do complain about the quality of the management and, I might say, the Government intervention, which has resulted in enormous increases to the cost of that building which are unjustifiable and disgraceful. As I said, I challenge the Parliament House Construction Authority to establish one substantial item of error to substantiate this dishonest and nonsensical comment in its annual report.

The major thrust of the Waste Watch Committee's complaints was the total and disgraceful lack of cost control over the four years of the construction phase of that project. The Authority has belatedly introduced a system only as a result of an inquiry by an independent adviser from the United Kingdom who pointed out in a biting report the disgraceful lack of cost control and the enormous volume of unsatisfied claims that was emerging out of what clearly was an unsatisfactory management system.

I pointed out in the first major Opposition Waste Watch Committee report the enormous volumes of items such as cement that were going into much smaller holes. I outlined the enormous cost overruns on individual contracts such as plumbing contracts. I documented every allegation that I made. I still await a coherent and effective response which would support the nonsensical and dishonest statement in the report that in fact the criticisms were largely ill-informed and unfounded. The Auditor-General agreed with me and my committee. I must say that if this is the quality and nature of this annual report some doubt must be cast on some of the other claims made in the report. In particular, I am concerned about the industrial relations situation on the New Parliament House site. The report states:
The strikes between February and April and the slow return of the work force following resolution of the dispute caused major delays.

The Authority claims that the great bulk of the industrial problems suffered last year resulted from national strikes. Let me remind the Senate of the enormous list of strikes that we received during Senate Estimates committee hearings. That list included strikes which were specifically and solely related to this site. This is despite the fact that something like $350,000 a year of Government money is being spent to pay for industrial organisers-union organisers-on that site. In 1984 this extraordinary gesture was made to try to bring about industrial peace at a cost of $350,000 a year-a cost per union organiser of $44,000. Union organisers' pay is being met by the Commonwealth Government further to facilitate, apparently, the organising of strikes on the site. No doubt it has been claimed that the strike situation would have been even worse had it not been for that arrangement. All I want to say is this: it is astounding to me-and it was astounding to Senator Robert Ray when I raised this matter briefly last year-that this situation should apply. Senator Robert Ray said that it is not an ideal way of doing business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to refer to the annual report of the Parliament House Construction Authority, late as it is. From what I hear, I understand that the report was ready some time before Christmas but because of some fact known by other people-I do not know the reason-it has only now come forward. Like Senator Michael Baume, I would also like to refer to the Authority's comments on page 11 of its report. The Authority makes reference to the continued barrage of criticism of the project during the year by the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee which it claims was largely ill-informed and unfounded. One wonders about the credibility of this report when the Authority has its facts wrong on that point. Certainly my colleague Senator Michael Baume highlighted many items in the waste watch area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament House Construction Authority wants to attack only Senator Michael Baume. It does not even have the wit to recognise that there are two areas of criticism-one from Senator Michael Baume's Waste Watch Committee and the other from my restrictive work practices report on the construction industry. Honourable senators on both sides of the House with any sort of sensibility are very much aware of and concerned about the matters raised in this report. Some seven of the 32 pages of the report referred to the Parliament House Construction Authority. We drew attention to the new Parliament House because it is a major issue which involves a large amount of taxpayers' money. We have responsibilities in this place to draw attention to areas of concern and waste. If we did not do that, we would not be exercising our responsibilities as senators in the Parliament of Australia.

I concentrated on the restrictive work practices area. I took the view that this problem was endemic in Australia and that we had to be more conscious of it because over $1 billion of taxpayers' money was involved. The report of the Authority states:
The industrial climate on site this year was on the whole calm and productive, with the most disruptive and costly industrial action being taken as a result of industry rather than site issues.
Senator Baume has questioned that; I would also question it. When one flips across to page 22, one finds the following remarks:
The level of industrial disputation continued at approximately the same overall rate as in 1985/86.

From about August 1985 to about August 1987-which are the two years to which the Authority refers-that site was idle because of industrial disputation, on average, for one week in every month. If the Parliament House Construction Authority and the Construction Manager believe that the industrial climate on site was on the whole calm and productive, God knows what would have been the case if it had not been calm and productive. There was an industrial dispute for one week of every month for 24 months-for two years. Yet, the Authority has the audacity and the cheek to put out a report to try to hoodwink people into believing that the industrial position was calm and productive. Of all things, the word `productive' was used. Yet we drew attention to the sort of rorts that went on across the board. For instance, it was claimed that the climbing time on cranes was two hours a day when the time taken was 45 seconds. When I raised this matter with the Construction Manager, he said, `You are wrong. It is not two hours a day-it is only one hour a day overtime'. Not only that; when the men were not working on cranes they were paid, with taxpayers' money, for one hour's climbing time to climb into a forklift.

The other comment I want to make-and Senator Michael Baume alluded to this-is that taxpayers have been footing the bill for eight full time union delegates on site costing over $350,000 a year. When I raised that with the Construction Manager he said, `Yes, this is because there are eight unions on site'. That is not true. I have since discovered that a granite contractor who had 30 employees on site was compelled to pay a union delegate $44,000 a year. This delegate worked for the union and was not employed by the granite operator. I wonder what I can believe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Official Establishments Trust is charged with the duty of looking after the Governor-General's residences and the Lodge and Kirribilli House. I wish simply to concentrate my brief remarks on the Lodge and Kirribilli House. The Waste Watch Committee pointed out, in the first instance, the year before last, the extraordinary amounts of money which were being used on capital works and other works in both the Lodge and Kirribilli House, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had declared to be of such an urgent nature that they should proceed despite the belt tightening that the rest of Australia was obliged to undergo.

I refer particularly to Kirribilli House because there is no doubt that substantial restoration work has been required at Kirribilli House since the Fraser Government noted it in 1977-78. Why this restoration work, which was outlined at that time, should suddenly become urgent in 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987 and now 1988 apparently relates to the increased usage of that place by the Prime Minister himself. We note that the report says that stage 2 of the restoration program was completed during 1986-87 at a cost of just under half a million dollars. This work included repairs and reslating of the roof, the installation of damp-proof courses, repairs to walls, floors and ceilings and repairs to electrical and hydraulic services. The report goes on:

As a consequence of this work a number of rooms have been seriously affected and will need attention. The Trust will be recommending to the Government that plans be developed for their redecoration with work to commence towards the end of 1987 in order to have the residence in sufficient order in 1988, including for visiting guests of Government.

We have already seen in the Senate Estimates committees that something like a quarter of a million dollars was to be spent this year and no doubt when we look at the Supplementary Estimates next month we will find out just how much money has been allocated for this year. No doubt it will be more than a quarter of a million dollars.

What intrigues me is that it is suggested here that the reason this work became urgent was for visiting guests of government at Kirribilli House. In these circumstances, it would be appropriate if the Government advised the Senate how many visiting guests of government used Kirribilli House and on how many occasions it was used by the Prime Minister as his Sydney residence? There is no doubt that since Mr Hawke became Prime Minister, the primary function of Kirribilli House has not been use by visiting guests of government. In fact, Kirribilli House is regarded by this Prime Minister as his perk of office in Sydney. After all, it does have quite nice views which would be enhanced if the Prime Minister got his way and had the Royal Australian Navy removed to Jervis Bay.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he does not pay fringe benefits tax on it, either.

—As Senator Stone says, he does not pay fringe benefits tax on it. To my mind, it is a matter of some concern that this building which, under the previous Government had been used basically for the purpose of entertaining visiting heads of government, is now regarded as a perk of this Prime Minister. The Government has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars in making it acceptable and bringing it up to his level of accommodation. After all, he has a high standard of accommodation requirement. He spent $250,000 redecorating five rooms in The Lodge last year. He does set high standards, no matter what the cost and no matter what the impact on the taxpayer of that cost. I would be grateful if the Government would provide us with figures as to the usage of Kirribilli House by visiting guests of the Government during this bicentennial year compared with the usage by the Prime Minister of what he regards as his private Sydney residence. I shall certainly seek those answers in Estimates committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not seek to turn this into a debate but we have just heard a mewling, puking, contribution from Senator Michael Baume. The reality is that Kirribilli House is the private Sydney residence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).
—That is a good admission.
—Well, it is.
—That is not what it says here.

—What nonsense! The question of whether Kirribilli House is used by visiting guests of government or by the Prime Minister-as he is absolutely entitled to do-as his official residence, which indeed is what it is, is not relevant. I do not know how many visits Senator Baume has paid to Kirribilli House, but Kirribilli House suffers from the same problems as all houses of that vintage. Kirribilli House is not only an extensive house on extensive grounds-it is an old house and the trouble with old houses is that they are extremely expensive to maintain. Senator Baume should advise the Senate whether he wants Kirribilli House maintained for the nation of Australia, as I certainly do. It belongs to Australia and to whichever government is in power at the time. Whichever Prime Minister is in office at the time uses it as his official residence because it belongs, as do the official residences of State Governors and the Federal Governor-General, to the people of Australia. If Senator Baume wants to see Kirribilli House and its grounds and, indeed, Admiralty House which is next door, fall into disrepair and disuse it is irrelevant whether anyone actually lives in them. The fact is that Kirribilli House is a national possession. We have an obligation to keep it in good repair. Because I am interested in old houses I have, on a number of occasions, gone through it and had a look at it. Like all old houses it is extremely expensive to maintain.

SPEECH.PARA: In Darwin, the city in which I live, is a tiny little house on Myilly Terrace which was the ex-residence of the Government Auditor. It is not nearly as extensive or as expensive as Kirribilli House. It is a three-bedroom, normal residential house which, I must say to the credit of the people concerned, was rehabilitated and is maintained at public expense. It is now called Audit House and is the residence of Mr and Mrs Harry Giese, who have lived in it for many years now. Despite the fact that it is a normal, small, suburban, three-bedroom house that probably cost a couple of hundred pounds to construct originally, it cost more than $70,000 to rehabilitate. It costs the Gieses about $2,000 a year just for water to maintain the tiny piece of garden that is attached to it. It is an expensive exercise to keep these houses in the public domain. If Senator Baume is honest about it, he should simply declare whether he thinks Kirribilli House should be maintained in public ownership as part of the treasures that we have or whether it should be sold or otherwise disposed of.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to speak to the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia entitled Folklife-Our Living Heritage. This report was sponsored by the then Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, the National Museum of Australia, the Australia Council and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Folklore in Australia is yet another manifestation of multiculturalism. This is demonstrated at the beginning of the report where one of the first pages shows a delightful picture of a traditional Welsh love spoon. As someone who was brought up and had her early education in Wales, I was really intrigued to see this picture so early in the report. The spoon was carved from a single piece of huon pine-that is, native Tasmanian pine which, of course, is now endangered. This very hardy pine was used for shipbuilding in the last century; and more rarely this century because it is not now so available. Huon pine was used to carve this traditional Welsh love spoon in Australia. Bert Davey, who carved the spoon, was born in Cardiff, South Wales. The spoon is in the full tradition which means that the bowl of it is carved in the shape of a love heart and the other carvings are, as usual, the originals of the person who carved the spoon. In this case, the spoon depicts the Prince of Wales feathers and a kangaroo to depict the birthplaces of Bert Davey and his wife, for whom he carved the spoon.

This particular Committee was set up on 26 March 1986 by the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Hon. Barry Cohen, MP. The report was delayed and there was some concern about that delay but now that it is here, the report and its recommendations are to be commended. There are a great number of recommendations. The most significant are that there should be established an Australian folklife centre which would provide a national focus for action to record, safeguard and promote awareness of Australia's heritage of folklife; that there should be established an Australian folklife grants scheme; that there should be a national collection of Australian folklife which would give identity and stimulus to the development and conservation of folklife materials within the national collections; that there should be a folk arts committee within the Australia Council which would provide the needed expertise and advice in relation to folk arts support; and that there should be a folk arts grant program which would provide more adequately for the particular needs and circumstances of the folk arts.

In brief, the report deals with the nature, diversity and significance of folklife in Australia, which is quite diverse and wide. It describes how we should safeguard our heritage of folklife. It also deals with folklife and education and how within our schools system there should be the education of children about our folklife heritage, which education should be expanded to the tertiary level so that teachers in schools also have a greater understanding of what folklife heritage is in Australia. Finally, the report deals with the living folk arts and describes how folk arts in Australia are living, are to be fostered and are part and parcel of the Australian identity. Honourable senators here may recall a poster recently issued by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs entitled, `I'm half Italian, half Dutch and 100 per cent Australian'. So folklife is tied up with the Australian identity.

The report reminds us that it is only in comparatively recent times that England has ceased to be referred to as the mother country for Australians and that on Australian passports we are now described as Australian citizens, instead of British subjects as we were described until quite recently. I want to finish with a quote from the Curtin University of Technology in Western Australia:

To many younger people it must seem incredible that until the late 60s, an interest in Australian history, songs, yarns, idiom, etc., was far from generally accepted by the community as a whole. Indeed, those who showed an active interest were considered aliens, ratbags or even traitors in some quarters. To some, to foster an interest in one's own national identity--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired, as has the time for debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to make provision for and in relation to regular reviews by the Parliament of the delegated legislation of the Commonwealth.
Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of good government is to make laws for the good of its people in an organised and coherent manner. It is not to overburden its citizens with more and more laws, many of which are outdated, unnecessary and in conflict with one another, although one could be forgiven for thinking otherwise.

In 1988, some 87 years after Federation, we have in Australia a national government, six State governments, fourteen Houses of Parliament and 836 local government authorities; all of which make laws for the benefit of their citizens. And yet, with so many different law makers in this country, it is not difficult to envisage why there are not only too many laws, but also too many conflicting laws.

Mr President, support for the review of government regulations comes from all sides of the political spectrum. On 21 September 1984, in an address to the Business Council of Australia, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said:
I am convinced that, after 84 years of federation, we have accumulated an excessive and often irrelevant and obstructive body of laws and regulations.
On 13 May, 1985, in a Ministerial statement to the House of Representatives on Australia's trade situation and policies, the then Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, said:
The Government's successful deregulation of important sectors has also provided a powerful boost to the efficiency and dynamism of the economy and has provided a major fillip to our export sector.

Mr President, the Opposition has been no less vocal on the need to reduce government regulation. On 19 November 1986, when speaking to the Public Service Legislation Streamlining Bill 1986, the then shadow minister for public administration, Mr Connolly, said in the House of Representatives:

The effects of regulation distort the allocation of resources, reduce efficiency, distort consumer investor behaviour and thereby shift expenditure patterns, increase costs, and cause lower productivity, which therefore makes overall management, both in the public and private sectors, that much more difficult.

No one suggests that all regulation is bad per se. What I am saying is that it is the responsibility of the Government not just to take the evidence given to it by its own Business Regulation Review Unit, but also to put in place effective management tools within Departments and within this Parliament to ensure that regulation can be effectively reviewed from time to time. The Government should see that what we have on the statute books is relevant to the problems facing Australia today.
On 11 June 1986, in his reply to the Prime Minister's address to the nation, Senator Chaney said:
There is absolutely no prospect of the sort of relief that is needed from the over-regulation, cost burdens and ridiculous work practices which afflict so many Australian manufacturers.
Later, in his reply to the Budget of the same year, Senator Chaney said:
We said that the level and cost of regulation must be reduced dramatically and across the board.

Mr President, one has to ask why there has been such growth in the proliferation of government regulation. Some of the major reasons advanced for this growth were identified in a report released in January 1987 by the New South Wales Legislative Assembly's Select Committee Upon Small Business. They included:
(i) To save pressure on parliamentary time so that Parliament considers only essential legislation.
(ii) A lack of time during parliamentary sittings for politicians to consider legislation of a highly technical nature.
(iii) As legislation cannot be easily changed, there needs to be a regulatory mechanism which can be readily amended to deal with changing circumstances.
(iv) There needs to be a mechanism to deal with emergency situations when Parliament is not sitting.
(v) To regulate, upon request from business, a particular sector of industry.
(vi) To protect the interests of consumers and the health and safety of workers.
Furthermore, Mr President, delegates to the first Commonwealth Conference of Delegated Legislation Committees, which was held in Canberra in 1981, endorsed the following view:

Subordinate legislation is an historically accepted means of governance. There is no longer any point in arguing that it is fundamentally improper or that it should be used only occasionally or for mere matters of detail. What is essential is to surround the making of subordinate legislation with procedural safeguards and measures of control so that the rights and liberties of the subject, which is the object of our Constitutional order, to protect while maintaining a viable system of government may be secured as well under subordinate legislation as well as statute. Subordinate legislation must not become a means, even unwittingly, of suppressing rights and liberties or of subverting parliamentary supremacy over the law. The Crown's power has never stood higher, the potential for its abuse has never been greater.
Mr President, to identify how bad the problem of over-regulation is in the Australian economy, one only has to consider the following examples:
(i) Between 1960 and 1979 there were some 16,631 laws made by parliaments in Australia and a further 32,551 regulations were made at an annual average of 1,628.
(ii) There are some 30 different State Acts of Parliament governing the manufacture of margarine in Australia.

(iii) In my own State of New South Wales, in order to operate a small business as a motor trader, one may need to obtain up to 14 different licences. To operate in the retail trade, that figure may rise to 40 different licences.

Mr President, with all these different and non-uniform regulations, it is not too difficult to imagine the huge costs incurred by industry while trying to comply with all these regulations. To quote a few examples:

(i) The Confederation of Australian Industry (C.A.I.) has estimated that in the decade of 1975-85, Australian consumers paid an extra $500 million in food prices due to over-regulation of the industry.

(ii) In December 1986, the Business Regulation Review Unit found in a survey of four large food companies that the following costs were incurred because the regulations changed or because of variations in labelling imposed by the individual States:
Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd (Aug.)...$80,000
Cottee's Foods...$76,880
Coles Myer Ltd...$305,000
Woolworths Ltd...$1,602,500

(iii) In an article in the `Business Review Weekly' of 25 July, 1986, Mr Neil Shoebridge wrote that a Melbourne company, Jarrah Foods, was instructed by the New South Wales and Queensland Departments of Health to change the labels they put on their coffee products, even though nine months earlier the labels were found to be satisfactory. Mr Phil Jaroslow, the Managing Director of Jarrah Foods, estimated that the change in labelling laws cost his company an entire year's advertising and promotional budget along with all the good will they had built up.

(iv) Mr Tony Thomas, in another article in the `Business Review Weekly' of 22 August, 1986, found that new export regulations from the Department of Primary Industry threatened to wreck a $20 million export order by a well known food exporter which had been built up over the previous fifteen years.

With the excessive growth of government regulations and the ever-increasing costs incurred by industry as a result, governments of all political persuasions in Australia have made attempts during this decade to come to terms with the problem.

On a State government level, several different approaches have been tried with varying degrees of success. The Victorian government, with its Regulation Review Unit and the enactment of the Subordinate Legislation (Review and Revocation) Act 1984, is the State government which has done the most in the area of regulation review. Queensland and Tasmania both have non-statutory authorities on deregulation, while in South Australia a government adviser on deregulation was appointed in August 1986.

In New South Wales, the Premier's Department provides assistance to specific task forces and in January 1987 the Legislative Assembly Select Committee on Small Business released its first report which dealt with the matters of regulation and licensing. In last year's Budget Session, the Regulation Review Bill 1987 was passed.

Finally, the New South Wales government is currently awaiting a review of business licensing requirements which is being conducted by Mr David Block of the New South Wales Government's administrative structure. His report is due to be presented in March, 1988.

At a federal level, there is no doubt that the present government has done more in the area of regulation review than any of its predecessors. In May, 1985, the Business Regulation Review Unit (B.R.R.U.) was established under the auspices of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It has as its main function the review of new regulations affecting business, initially in terms of eleven priority areas. In its nine reports to date, the unit has had some success in identifying over-regulation as it applies to such areas as:
Industrial chemicals,
Packaging and labelling of food products, and
Indigenous crude oil marketing arrangements.

Mr President, whilst trying not to decry the work of the B.R.R.U., the Australian Democrats believe there should be a systematic review of all government regulations-both current and future-at the federal, State and local levels. This Bill, if passed, will establish such a mechanism at the federal level.

Mr President, the first question one should ask is whether or not such a review could be undertaken by an already established Senate Committee such as the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.
This Committee was established in 1932, and was:

``charged with the responsibility of seeing that the clause of each Bill conferring a regulation-making power does not confer a legislative power which ought to be exercised by Parliament itself. It would be required to scrutinise regulations to ascertain:
(a) that they are in accord with the statute;
(b) that they do not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(c) that they do not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative and not upon judicial decisions; and
(d) that they are concerned with administrative detail and do not amount to substantive legislation which should be a matter of parliamentary enactment.''.

In 1979, in its 64th report, this Committee changed item (d) to read that the Committee was charged with the responsibility to ensure legislation does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

As such, Mr President, the Committee was charged with the responsibility of reviewing only new regulations and then only in terms of the criteria set out above. The Committee can make no judgment on the merits or otherwise of the regulations, nor may it review current regulations, which would be the prime task of the proposed Joint Committee. In fact, as the Senate Select Committee on Standing Committees reported in 1932:

``It is conceivable that occasions might arise in which it would be desirable for a standing committee to direct the attention of Parliament to the merits of a certain regulation but, as a general rule, it should be recognized that the Standing Committee would lose prestige if it set itself up as a critic of governmental policy or departmental practice apart from the tests outlined above.''

Thus, if we accept the above advice and therefore make a judgment that an analysis of government regulations, in terms of their merits or otherwise, by a Senate Standing Committee, is not appropriate, then we must examine what alternatives there are for this most onerous, most critical and most essential task.

A second alternative would be for a House of Representatives Committee to be charged with the responsibility to review current and future government regulations on the basis of merit. However, the arguments against such a proposal were succinctly put by a former federal labor Member, Mr Maurice Blackburn, who said:

The Commonwealth Parliament makes provision for the disallowance of statutory regulations by the vote of either House through the Acts Interpretation Act . . . The House of Representatives is not likely to do that work well or, in fact, to do it at all. Upon its fate turns the fate of the Ministry. The regulation is made by the Ministry, and a proposal for its disallowance would certainly be treated as a vote of want of confidence, and would be tested on party lines.

Mr President, the only alternative that is left that would overcome the objections discussed above against the establishment of a standing committee of either House of Parliament to review government regulations on the basis of merit, would be for the Parliament to establish a joint standing committee of Regulation Review as outlined in this Bill. Such a committee would be given the onerous task of reviewing, in terms of the guidelines as set out in this Bill, all current regulations and all future regulations before their enactment.
Mr President, the work of previous joint committees has been well documented. To quote but a few examples.
(i) The Joint Select Committee on the Australia Card.
(ii) The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.
(iii) The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

Mr President, as Senator Cooney has said in the past, a bipartisan approach would be needed on such a committee if it is to work effectively in considering government regulations on their merits. Otherwise, the committee may fail in its task.

Of course, there are many examples which show just how costly it is to debate the merits of regulations on the floor of the Senate as a committee of the whole rather than with the assistance of a specialist committee.
For example, one only has to recall the Freedom of Information (charges) regulations which were disallowed by the Senate after more than two hours of debate on 13 November, 1985.

It may have been possible that a Committee examining the merits of these regulations could have extracted from the Attorney-General an undertaking to amend the legislation and thereby lower the fees to a more reasonable level and, at the same time, he would not have been prevented for six months from introducing similar regulations to those disallowed.
Mr President, there are several consequences if this Bill is passed.

(i) To begin with, there would be a joint standing committee of both Houses of Parliament who would be charged with the responsibility of reviewing all current regulations and all future regulations before they are enacted on the basis of merit.
(ii) It would allow input into the proposed regulations by all interested parties before the regulations are enacted.

(iii) It would help identify areas of conflicting regulations between the three levels of government and may well be successful in reducing the number of these regulations. In fact, Mr President, the then Opposition Shadow Minister on Public Administration-Mr David Connolly-said in the House on 11 September, 1985, that this was in fact a major area of concern. To quote him directly:

``--we must reduce government involvement. For example, over one third of the staff of the Department of Primary Industry are involved in meat inspection. In addition we have state meat inspection services and in some states local government is involved in the same activity as well.

Clearly, there is a massive need for restructuring and a devolution of the responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States. We cannot control a cost factor in governmental terms while we have more than one level of government actively involved in the same area of policy. In addition, we have to reduce government involvement overall''.

(iv) Not only would the committee help to identify areas of conflicting regulations between the three levels of government, but it would also help to identify areas of conflict at the same level of government. To quote but one example:
Under the Queensland Margarine Act, the following inconsistency occurs:
``Section 16 (i) provides that it is an offence to use in the manufacture of margarine, skim milk which contains more than 0.05 per centum of butter fat''.
Note also Section 16 (iii) which in spite of section 16 (i) prohibits the sale or manufacture of margarine which contains any butter fat.

(v) The Committee would identify outdated regulations propose methods to up date them. For example, the Machinery Ordinance for the A.C.T. of 1949 has not been comprehensively reviewed. This ordinance is the primary regulatory device for industrial safety in the A.C.T. and yet, it does not say anything about modern management techniques of safety committees, the rights to information for employees and the right to stop dangerous work.

(vi) The Committee would help identify regulations with unclear intents such as the Machinery (Amendment) Ordinance of 1983. This ordinance provides for fees which are payable ``to the Commonwealth'' for matters for which notice has been given in the `Gazette'. This provision does not define `a relevant matter' except to say it is `a matter in respect of which the Minister may make negotiations'. A person managing a small business is unlikely to read the government `Gazette' or to check on amendments and thus be in a position to cut and paste together what is currently legal. Furthermore, nowhere in the ordinance does it specify answers to questions such as the following:
To whom is the fee paid?
Where is the fee paid?
What is the fee paid for?
Why is the fee paid?

Mr President, despite Senator Button's statement on 9 January 1987 in which he committed the Government to a ``Plain English Policy''-a policy with which the Democrats wholeheartedly agree-there is still much work to be done in this area, not only to cut out the legal mumbo-jumbo, but also to check regulations for clear intention and how difficult they are to abide with.

(vii) The Bill provides a mechanism for the proposed Joint Standing Committee to examine all proposed and existing delegated legislation in terms of a Regulatory Impact Statement as defined in clauses 9 and 123 respectively.
(viii) Under clause 14, the Committee is given the power to report to the Parliament and either House of Parliament is empowered to act on a report of the same Committee.

(ix) Clause 15 specifies that the power of either House to act upon a report of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is the same as the power of either House to act upon a report of the proposed Joint Committee. It could be argued that the work of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee would be deemed to be less important than the work of the proposed Joint Committee.

Of course, Mr President, it would be a self-defeating exercise if, once the Committee were established, it was not provided with adequate resources such as clerical staff and the ability to second `experts' from the private sector as required because the Committee was starved of funds. These experts would be members of the Committee for as long as required and they would then be discharged. They would not necessarily be voting members of the Committee.

The Committee, to be truly effective, must have a budget commensurate with the job at hand, a job which must, at least initially, will be mammoth. But given the potential cost savings to the community from the Committee identifying unnecessary or conflicting regulations, I am confident such a budget would be economically justifiable.

Mr President, calls within the community for a systematic review of government regulations have intensified in recent years. This has occurred principally as a result of the public becoming more aware of the fact that urgent action is required in this area if the economy of this country is to get moving again. We have enough problems in Australia without complicating matters further by continuing to promulgate regulations without some mechanism of review.
In fact, as Mr Justice Michael Kirby said when he was Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission:

It is ironic that on the continent of Europe, divided by language, separated by culture and history and ancient enmities, not blessed with a common legal system inherited from a common source, served by utterly different legal institutions and personnel, they can agree on uniform laws on so many varied topics. Yet we in Australia, with a common language and traditions, with like institutions and a great degree of cultural homogeneity, find it difficult even to agree on the time of day.

Mr President, the Committee which the Bill seeks to establish would be a vehicle to overcome some of the regulatory problems I have spoken of today, and which others have decried, both inside and outside this Chamber on other occasions. The solution we propose to these problems was endorsed by the Confederation of Australian Industry in 1985 and again in their most recently published annual report, which was released in January 1988.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Bolkus) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the revised explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the precincts of the Parliament have never formally been defined. In November 1985, the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House saw the relocation of the Parliament in 1988 as an appropriate occasion for the definition of the precincts of the Parliament to be enshrined in legislation. The Parliamentary Precincts Bill 1988 reflects the Government support for this recommendation. It also provides a legislative vehicle for the recognition of the management and control responsibilities of the Presiding Officers within those precincts. Following receipt of the Joint Standing Committee's report, a working party, comprising representatives of the parliamentary departments and interested government departments, was established to co-ordinate a response to it. This Bill represents the level of agreement reached within that working party. It implements the substance of the Joint Standing Committee's major recommendations.

Mr President, I now turn to the provisions of the Bill in more detail. The Bill defines the precincts as the land, buildings, structures and works, within a boundary formed by a circular line drawn from the outer edge of the retaining wall right around the site. This circle will, I understand, be defined by a concrete strip or other discernible markings where there is no wall.

While this definition does not accord strictly with the recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee, I understand that it is acceptable to you, Mr President and to Madam Speaker. I believe it will be acceptable to all honourable senators.

The Bill confers on the Presiding Officers overall management and control within the precincts while providing for separate agreements to be reached between the Presiding Officers and the Government with respect to the ministerial wing, the operations of Australian protective service officers and the detention of persons in custody and with the Director of Public Prosecutions in relation to the launching of prosecutions. The Bill provides for statutory rules to be made deeming buildings outside the precincts to have the same status as those within when being used for parliamentary purposes.
In keeping with the provisions I have already referred to, Mr President, the Bill also:
provides for the application of the relevant sections of the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971 within the precincts;
adapts section 15 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 to reflect the declaration of the precincts under the Bill;
amends the Parliament Act 1974 to enlarge the parliamentary zone by including that area between State and Capital Circles not presently included in the zone; and
amends the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979 to remove from the Authority responsibility for consenting to the grant of leases and licences within the precincts.
The other important effect of this Bill is to empower the Presiding Officers or their delegates to grant leases and licences to commercial operators of business premises within the precincts.

Mr President, this Bill is an important piece of legislation to the Parliament itself. It had its genesis in the 1985 report of the Joint Standing Committee and is the product of extensive consultation between all interested parties. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the debate on this Bill is adjourned, I wish to inform the Senate that the provisions of the Bill have been the subject of extensive consultations between the responsible Minister and the Presiding Officers and between various executive departments and officers of both Houses. The Bill arises from a report presented in November 1985 by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House which recommended that certain statutory provisions be made in relation to the parliamentary precincts. Early in 1986 my predecessor, President Douglas McClelland, prepared and circulated a draft Bill to carry out the recommendations of the Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Bill now introduced contains a number of modifications of the provisions proposed by the Committee and by President McClelland. These modifications have come about as a result of the consultations to which I referred. Because of the importance of the Bill to the two Houses I draw it to the special attention of honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to remove an inequity in the imposition of levy on dairy products and to streamline the Australian Dairy Corporation's (ADC) administration of the dairy product levy system.

The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986 (the Act) provides for the imposition of levy on dairy products that have been produced at a factory on or after 1 July 1986. The levy is payable by dairy manufacturers upon the sale of specified dairy products, currently butter and cheese, to fund supplementary market support of the dairy product export sector over and above the primary market support funded by the all milk levy. As the levy is intended to support domestic prices, a person who exports butter or cheese may seek an exemption from payment of the levy. Subject to certain limitations these arrangements also apply to butter and cheese contained in mixtures which are exported. Exemptions are issued by the ADC.

The arrangements reflect those which operated under the old dairy arrangements (the stabilisation levy on major dairy products operating prior to 1 July 1986) where consignments of mixtures for export under 15 tonnes weight (one container load) and mixtures with less than 25% dairy product content were not eligible for exemption. The intention of these limits was to avoid the need to process small consignments, or consignments involving only minimal dairy product content, which would involve disproportionately high administrative costs with little benefit to the exporter.

When the new arrangements commenced, in order to be consistent with the market support element the limit on refund of levy relating to minimum percentage of leviable product in mixtures, as set down in subsection 9 (3) and prescribed in subsection 9 (4) of the Act, was reduced to 1%. However, the minimum weight of 15 tonnes per consignment was retained through subsections 9 (3) and 9 (4) of the Act as it was thought that the administrative costs relating to applications for consignments of less than one container load would be prohibitive.
The ADC has since indicated that, in fact, the cost of administering the minimum weight limit outweighs the benefit derived from the exclusion.
In addition the limit discriminates against a manufacturer who exports a large amount of butter or cheese in a small consignment compared to one who exports small amounts in large consignments.

The Government has decided to accept the ADC recommendation that the situation be remedied by deleting subsections 9 (3) and 9 (4) of the Act to eliminate the weight and dairy produce content constraints. The result will be that any amount of butter and cheese exported in a mixture will qualify for levy exemption.

The amendment will apply from 1 July 1986 to put all applicants on an equal basis from the commencement of the new dairy marketing arrangements. Retrospectivity will also validate some exemptions which the ADC has already given but which would on a strict interpretation be inconsistent with the existing provisions of subsections 9 (3) and 9 (4) although not inconsistent with the intention of this amendment.

The amendment will result in savings in administration costs to the Australian Dairy Corporation and hence to the dairy industry at large and it will place the payment of levy on dairy products on a more equitable basis. It will have no financial implications for the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
