DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 25 February.
Clauses 23 to 34.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to progress being reported on the last occasion on which the Committee considered the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill, Senator Durack raised a matter concerning clause 34. I think he expressed some concern that Family Court of Australia judges may hear what we term an associated matter arising under part IV of the Trade Practices Act when dealing with a division 1 or 2 of part V matter-in other words, restrictive trade practices, the initial substantial matter being one dealing with consumer protection.

SPEECH.PARA: The point raised by Senator Durack is a very legitimate one, but it is not novel in the sense that, quite rightly, the trade practices committee of the Law Council of Australia raised the matter last December in a letter to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and received a response with which it is apparently satisfied in the sense that it has not come back. The response was to the effect that no matter may be transferred except by order of the Federal Court. The Chief Judge of the Federal Court has indicated the Court's intention that an order for transfer would not be made until after a directions hearing, at which stage it would be clear whether a part IV issue was to be raised. Where such an issue was raised, it is unlikely that a matter would be transferred. That seems to be the time at which it would become apparent that some such associated matter dealing with part IV might be involved. As I am advised, it is at the directions hearing that that will become clear. That is the way in which the Federal Court intends to deal with the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for his reply. However, I understand from the reply that some detailed guidelines have now been established. The Minister has just outlined a way in which a decision will be taken to transfer such a matter. He said it would be unlikely that a proceeding involving a part IV matter under the Trade Practices Act would be transferred. The Minister will recall that at the beginning of the committee stage of the Bill, which is now some time ago, I spent some time on seeking guidance from the Minister as to what would be the basis on which the Chief Judges would make decisions to transfer matters. I asked the Minister to table the guidelines if there were any. I was rather surprised to find that the Minister seemed to know very little about guidelines and what they would contain. As I understand it, he said there were no guidelines that he could table. I ask him whether something has developed since we were first in committee, perhaps three weeks ago. Have there been developments along those lines and are there now some guidelines?

SPEECH.PARA: It is very nice for the Minister to tell us how a particular decision involving part IV of the Trade Practices Act will be determined by the Chief Judges, but how will the countless other decisions that are called upon to be made by the Chief Judges be made? I have raised a matter which is somewhat embarrassing to the Government in view of some of the statements it has made, as well as the specific provision in the legislation to which my attention was drawn by the Minister in the debate, which excludes matters other than those under part V of the Trade Practices Act. When that was raised, I received an answer which was very specific and clear about the guidelines. But what about all the other guidelines? Earlier I was told that there were no guidelines. Now, when the Government wants to answer a question I have raised, there is a guideline. What is the position about guidelines?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I tried to state the matter as fairly as possible. I did not say that guidelines had been developed in the sense about which we spoke the other day. I reject any inference that it has taken me two weeks to find an answer. Senator Durack will recall that the matters were raised as we were about to report progress on the last occasion on which the Committee met. The guidelines will emerge from the consultations between the Chief Judge of the Federal Court and the Chief Judge of the Family Court in accordance with clause 4 of the Bill, which has been agreed to, which provides that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court and the Chief Judge of the Family Court may consult with each other in relation to the transfer to the Family Court of proceedings pending in the Federal Court, whether generally or in relation to the transfer of particular proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated that Mr Bowen was able to answer the query which has been raised by Senator Durack-that query being put to him by the trade practices committee of the Law Council of Australia-on the basis of the expressed intention of the Chief Judge of the Federal Court that no transfer would be made until after a directions hearing. It was simply on that particular matter that advice had been received to that effect; that that was the intention of the Federal Court regarding those matters. That is all I purported to inform the Committee of a moment ago. No guidelines have been established in accordance with the joint consultation process, but I am confident that those guidelines, when they emerge, will embody that intention of the Chief Judge of the Federal Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we debated this matter three or four weeks ago, questions were raised specifically about guidelines. Apparently, a specific answer was given some time ago to inquiries by the Law Council of Australia about this matter. I find it very strange that an answer can be given to one query when guidelines have not yet been established. The question that has been raised indicated the desirability of guidelines, if there are to be guidelines, being in place when we debate a matter in this chamber. It does not seem as though any further advance has been made in establishing guidelines, other than that in one particular case we can tell the Law Council of Australia, `Oh, you need not worry your head about that because the Chief Judge says we will not be transferring such a case'. The Government is asking the Committee to pass this legislation in a very sloppy way. The Minister has not given us any specific indications as to the way in which litigation will be transferred to the Family Court as a result of negotiations between the two Chief Judges. Yet, when the Law Council raised a particular matter, it was given an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Institute of Australia is very concerned about the transfer of tax cases. For the Minister's information, the Taxation Institute is a body which is made up of tax professionals, mostly lawyers and accountants. It has been very concerned about the matter. I am sure that it has written to the Attorney-General about it. It has certainly written to me and many other senators about it. It has been looking for guidance as to what sorts of tax cases will be referred to Family Court judges. The Opposition and I have taken the view that many Family Court judges will be qualified to deal with tax cases. However, a number will not be qualified to do so. It seems to me that there is very good reason for a body of highly qualified professional people to be given an answer in the same way as the Minister has now given an answer to the query about jurisdiction under part IV of the Trade Practices Act which, of course, worries a number of other professional people. These people belong to a different group from the Law Council. They belong to a much smaller group. However, the Law Council of Australia put their case and got an answer which, the Minister says, has satisfied them. From the correspondence I have had with them, I do not know whether the answer has satisfied them. However, we will assume that as the Minister has not heard from the Council again he is right in saying that they are satisfied. The point is that the Minister was able to give them an answer; whether it satisfied them or not, perhaps does not matter. It was an answer. It was a rational answer. It might have satisfied even me in my present frame of mind in this debate. But, the fact is that the Taxation Institute is not satisfied. The Minister has not given any indication, in this debate anyway, as to what guidelines will be applied to the transfer of tax cases. It is totally sloppy and unsatisfactory for us to be asked to pass this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, but I can help the Committee only in regard to the matter which was raised by the Law Council of Australia trade practices committee, which has allowed me to indicate that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court of Australia thinks that, in relation to the transfer of matters to the Family Court of Australia, a directions hearing will take place. It is at that stage that the appropriateness of a particular matter being transferred will be determined. I have assumed that the same sort of procedure would apply in relation to the transfer of other matters. However, the only specific instance that we have available to us to judge whether that might be the case is that dealing with trade practices. However, it would seem to be such a sensible proposal that I am sure that in the discussions between the Chief Judge of the Federal Court and the Chief Judge of the Family Court that sort of procedure will commend itself in relation to the other matters also.

—I would like the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to give me some sort of assurance that organisations such as the Taxation Institute of Australia, which has expressed great concern to me and a number of other people I know of, will get a satisfactory answer as soon as possible from the Minister as to the rule relating to the transfer of tax cases.

—I give an undertaking, as I think I have already, that the guidelines, once they are determined, will be made available as publicly and as soon as possible. In fact, I believe that I have given an undertaking to table them in the Senate. I do not have in front of me, nor do my advisers, the particular objections that have been raised, but I will make sure that those misgivings are brought to the attention of the consulting parties in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will recall that when we dealt with part IV of the Trade Practices Act in relation to the Family Court of Australia Bill on 25 February I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Bill say anywhere that part IV of the Trade Practices Act cannot be dealt with by the Family Court?
The Minister replied:
The Bill is drawn in a way which confines the trade practices jurisdiction which might be conferred to divisions 1 and 1a of part V.

(i) that are associated with matters arising in the proceeding:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most other senators, I have just been handed this amendment. SPEECH.PARA: I now see that the Minister is proposing to amend the originally proposed amendment to section 65. This suggests to me that there must have been something wrong with the original amendment and that perhaps that is the reason I was somewhat confused by it. In these circumstances perhaps the Minister could explain why we have now got another amendment in place of the one he was proposing the last time we debated this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in the proposed clause 36 we have picked up the change to the jurisdiction that is consequential on the amendment moved by Senator Haines and agreed to by the Government in relation to motor vehicles and so on. That is straightforward; that is clear. Proposed clause 37 has not been changed from the original. It has been put on the one page in a convenient form for honourable senators. It is exactly the same as was circulated prior to the adjournment of the debate previously. I agree with Senator Durack that it is an extremely complex provision. When I saw it this morning I asked for a few dot points on what it could possibly mean. I am quite willing to read those into the Hansard record by way of explanation.
—Have they satisfied you?

—The English is sounder. Whether they convey tremendous meaning is another matter. It may be useful if I read them into the Hansard record. It is a complex drafting requirement. I am advised that this amendment makes consequential changes to the provisions of the Family Law Amendment Act 1987 which has not yet been proclaimed. It is to be proclaimed on 16 March, to commence on 1 April 1988. Section 20 of the amendment Act and clause 18 of the Bill have the same objective-to vary the limit on the property jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction. Clause 18 has been amended by this Committee. An amendment to new clause 36, which amends section 20 of the amendment Act, ensures that section 20 accords with the amended clause 18. That amendment has been distributed today. Clause 18 of the Bill and section 20 of the Family Law Amendment Act 1987 amended the jurisdictional limits in section 46 of the Act. Section 65 of the Family Law Amendment Act was a transitional provision in respect of section 46, in case clause 18 of the Bill came into operation after section 20 of the Family Law Amendment Act 1987. The latter provision will now commence on 1 April 1988. So there we are.
—Senator Durack, you had circulated an amendment to the earlier Government amendment. I take it that you no longer wish to proceed with that?
—No, that amendment has been superseded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee was debating clause 9 earlier. At that time I pointed out that I believed that the most important thing that the courts should take into consideration in a divorce action is the problems associated with the custody of children. It is imperative, and this is underlined in the Bill, that the judge be satisfied that the best arrangements are made for the child under the circumstances, that both parents are given access to the child, if at all possible, and that the best arrangements are made in relation to the custody of the child. The judicial registrars are really being given the power of judges of the Family Court of Australia. This power is being given to the judicial registrars purely and simply for the purpose of cutting the workload of Family Court judges to enable them to take on cases outside the Family Court.

SPEECH.PARA: I still maintain that, if we are serious about making the first priority in custody cases the arrangements made for the children and if the Government believes that its first priority must be the welfare of the children, the very least we can do is ensure that that task remains in the hands of the judges. The Judicial Registrars are not Family Court judges. The amendments we have moved have sought to ensure that judicial registrars are as highly qualified as possible. However, they will still not be Family Court judges. I now move the amendment I foreshadowed earlier:

Page 3, clause 9, proposed subsection 26b (1), at end of proposed subsection, add `except the power to make, in proceedings under this Act, an order, the terms of which have not been agreed upon by all the parties to the proceedings, with respect to the custody of a child.'.
In other words, I believe that because the judges will have their workload lightened, they should as a matter of priority take on custody cases where there is conflict between the parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since it is some weeks since we dealt with this matter, as Senator Durack pointed out, I would just like to put down again the attitude of the Australian Democrats to the duties of both judicial registrars and registrars. I know that one group is dealt with in clause 9 and the other is dealt with in clause 12, but I think it is appropriate that I make some comments about both of those classifications. The Bill proposes that judges delegate to both judicial registrars and to registrars certain of the duties that it is within their province-that is, within the province of the judges-to perform. As far as registrars are concerned-that is the group that will be affected by the Government's amendment to clause 12 of the Bill-I have no difficulty at all with accepting that judges can refer to registrars cases dealing with non-contested substantive matters, whether that be the dissolution of the marriage, the division of property, or questions of custody of and access to children. Under no circumstances, however-I think I made this clear when we were dealing with this matter previously-should registrars deal with or be given the right to deal with any contested matter at all.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Walters has just said, we are making every attempt to ensure that judicial registrars are of the highest possible calibre and have the highest possible qualifications. I presume that the judges of the Family Court of Australia are intelligent, compassionate and sensitive individuals and that they will show some sense and take some considerable care about which cases they refer to judicial registrars. It is important that they do this with care and it is equally imperative that they retain for themselves the most difficult, the most complex, the most problematic and the most potentially explosive of issues. I assume that there would not be a judge in the Family Court who would presume to refer or delegate to a judicial registrar any matter which the judge believes is more appropriate for him or her to deal with. I accept the fact that judges may wish to refer to judicial registrars matters in dispute and that judges may believe that a judicial registrar is competent to deal with a contested matter, whether the contest involves the simple dissolution of the marriage, if any dissolution is simple, a property settlement or a custody or access question. I accept then the premise that the Government is putting, that judges should be entitled to delegate powers to judicial registrars in respect of those matters. I do not accept, however, that they have an absolute right to do that.

I would like some clarification of the legislation from the Government, if necessary, to make it perfectly clear that if, at any stage, either party wishes to have referred back to a judge a matter that has been referred to a judicial registrar, that wish will be accommodated. I can see no point in excessively inflaming a situation. We have enough difficulties now with people taking umbrage at a decision made by a judge. It would be quite appalling if that unhappy circumstance were extended to judicial registrars because one of the parties involved changed his or her mind part way through a hearing and was denied the right to have the case taken back before a judge.

Senator Walters mentioned the question of the workload of Family Court judges and the fact that some of these delegations are being made to lighten the workload of Family Court judges in order for them to take on other matters from the Federal Court. I think the two things need to be kept separate. I guess that we are dealing with the question of judicial status, a rather unfortunate occurrence, given the differential in income of Federal Court judges and Family Court judges. I think I made it quite clear, when I was speaking during the second reading debate and quite possibly also during the committee debate, that I believe the stresses that fall on the shoulders of Family Court judges are excessive, that they need recompense as well as some relief from that and that they ought--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who would ever do it?

—As Senator Baume has interjected, `Who would ever do it?'. Of course, this is getting to be exactly the position. What silk who is on a squillion dollars a year, as most New South Wales silks seem to be, in his or her right mind would take up a position on the Family Court for tuppence ha'penny a week-it is in comparison with Federal Court judges' salaries-and submit themselves to the potential of--
—It's nothing compared with our salaries.

—I will accept that interjection simply to get it into Hansard. They not only submit themselves to the potential of being harassed and bombed but also take on the stresses of dealing with people. I think it is appalling that Family Court judges who deal with people are regarded as lesser individuals than Federal Court judges who deal with those high status matters of property and money. I think it is about time that we, in this society, got our priorities in order. I know that Senator Baume did not intend to get me wound up like that, but he seems to have succeeded. I will bring myself back to the matter at hand.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this Government is taking an appropriate step in allowing Family Court judges to deal with certain matters other than those that have been in their traditional jurisdiction. In any event, we have needed to do something for a long time to relieve Family Court judges of their intense workload. At the end of 1986 I asked a question, which was put back on the Notice Paper following last year's election and which I finally got an answer to late last year, with regard to the workloads of Federal and Family Court judges. I asked the Attorney-General's Department to come with some information on:
(1) How many days did each individual . . . Federal . . . and Family Court judge from each State or Territory sit in the most recent full year for which figures are available.
(2) How many cases were listed awaiting . . . hearing . . . and determination in each of the . . . Federal and Family Courts in each State and territory for each of the last five years.
(3) What has been the average duration of waiting before the case is heard and determined in each of those jurisdictions and States.

The Government finally came up with a masterly piece of prose and some accompanying statistics which my staff and I are still trying to work out, so I would be very grateful for any assistance that the Minister can provide. However, what is said in a nutshell is that Family Court judges are overworked and underpaid in comparison to their Federal Court colleagues. It is, therefore, appropriate that, to improve their status to relieve some of the stress of coping with some of the horrendous cases they deal with, they accept some matters relating to tax, bankruptcy and so on, from the Federal Court and that they are able to delegate the less contentious, less difficult Family Court matters to both registrars and judicial registrars with, as I have said, the two provisos, that registrars not deal with any matters that are contested and that judicial registrars deal with whatever matters judges see fit to refer to them, as long as one or other of the parties may at any stage request that the matter go back before a judge.

To take up Senator Haines's point, under proposed new section 26d (2) we find:

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in the Bill or the principal Act?
—It is on page 4 of the amending Bill.
—That doesn't satisfy the conditions.
—If the honourable senator would just let me finish my sentence, I have pointed to the page which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where:
(a) a power . . . is proposed to be exercised in a particular case by a Judicial Registrar; but
(b) the Judicial Registrar has not commenced to exercise the power in that case;

a Judge may, on application by a person who would be a party to the proceedings before the Judicial Registrar in relation to the proposed exercise of the power, order that the power be exercised in that case by a Judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is prior to the hearing?

—Prior to the hearing. In other words, people know that they are going to go before a judicial registrar. They obviously have the advice of counsel and so on and, for some reason or another, they are of the view that the case should go to a judge. No doubt, under this provision, they can go to a judge and seek for the matter to be put before a judge rather than be dealt with by a judicial registrar.
—What happens if part of it has been heard?
—You cannot really make provision--
—Why not?

—Halfway through a case a person might feel that it is going the wrong way, or something like that, and then decide to go off to a judge. I do not think that is appropriate. However, I think it is appropriate that if the problem is that the matter is being dealt with by a judicial registrar rather than a judge, the person should have the opportunity to seek that the matter be heard before a judge. I do not believe that we can provide for persons who are unhappy about a particular judicial registrar's dealing with a matter once it is under way. I concede that an argument can be raised before a matter gets before the judicial registrar. That is provided for in the Bill.

—The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) seems to have overlooked the point I was trying to make, perhaps not very well, in my comments a moment ago; that is, if somebody suddenly becomes aggrieved, we are doubling the jeopardy if we do not allow the proceeding to go back to a judge. Why place judicial registrars in jeopardy when a matter could quite easily be referred back to a judge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to point out that I do not think it is appropriate that, halfway through a proceeding being conducted by a judicial registrar, people should be able to say that they are not happy with the way things are going and want to go off to a judge. I have pointed out that if, before the matter gets to the judicial registrar, the person concerned considers that inappropriate, he or she can apply to a judge under proposed section 26d (2). Of course, once a decision is made by the judicial registrar, if it is unsatisfactory to a party, he or she can seek a review of that decision by a judge. That is provided for in proposed section 26c. I think that is the more appropriate way to deal with it. Proposed section 26c (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court may, on application made under subsection (1) or of its own motion, review the exercise by a Judicial Registrar of a power delegated under subsection 26b (1) and may make such orders as it considers appropriate in relation to the matter in relation to which the power was exercised.

I am saying that it is satisfactory to make a decision at the beginning or to seek a review at the end. However, it is not appropriate halfway through a proceeding to march off from one forum into another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can a review be reviewed?
—Yes. The normal appeal processes would apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bitterness of Family Court proceedings that involve property disputes is bad enough. However, when proceedings involve the custody of children there have been situations where violence has been not only threatened against Family Court judges but also actually taken against them. We must understand the bitterness that accompanies those proceedings. Halfway through a contested case a party may believe, as Senator Haines said, that the proceeding is being conducted by a second-class judge. Considering the bitterness involved with custody proceedings, there is no way that that will not occur. However, if a matter is being heard by a judge, the highest person in the Family Court, parties will be less likely to believe that they have been treated shabbily than they would if their partner or their lawyers persuaded them that it would be quicker to have the matter dealt with by someone who is not even a judge, someone who is second class.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that the qualifications for judicial registrars are very strict and are very good. However, I am looking at this matter as a senator. I am not looking at it as a mother desperately wanting custody of children. If I were a mother fighting for the custody of my children I would see a judicial registrar as someone of a lower class than a judge. In order to speed up matters, parties may have to agree to go before a judicial registrar. As the case proceeds, as Senator Haines said, a party may believe the proceeding to be hopeless, that the registrar is not listening to him or her. Honourable senators know how emotional parties can become. However, if the matter is being determined by a judge, the highest person available, I think the bitterness and disappointment would be less. For that reason I say that at least matters of the highest priority, those involving the interests of children, should be determined by a Family Court judge.

I understand exactly what Senator Haines was saying. In the middle of a case one ought to be able to change one's mind if one believes one is being given a raw deal. However, I agree with the Minister also that that could be difficult. If the Bill stipulated that only Family Court judges should deal with matters involving the highest priority in divorce proceedings, that is the care of children, that would be doing the best possible for children involved in this unhappy situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my support for the amendment that Senator Walters has proposed. I do not understand how the clauses of the amending Bill to which the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has referred can satisfy Senator Haines. In view of the very strong conditions that Senator Haines has laid down, I hope that she will support Senator Walters's amendment.
—This is to clause 9, you are talking about?

—Clause 9, yes-limiting judicial registrars, by excluding contested custody cases from their general jurisdiction. The Minister has pointed out that if at the end of a proceeding a party is dissatisfied with it or the way in which it was conducted there may be an appeal to a judge. However, that is cool comfort to someone, as Senator Haines said, who finds that the judicial registrar is not handling the matter properly, and he or she must go to all the further trouble and expense of an appeal; and perhaps then an appeal from the judge to the Full Court. That is unnecessarily expanding the agony and expense of the parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I should like to stress in support of Senator Walters's amendment is that it is in accordance with what the Minister has said is the intention of the judges. When this matter was raised, I think firstly by Senator Haines in the committee stage when dealing with clause 9, the Minister specifically said that judicial registrars would deal with only minor custody cases. When further queried, the Minister tightened his comment by saying judicial registrars will not deal with any contested custody cases, though they might deal with access matters, I think the Minister said. From further inquiries, I have ascertained that judicial registrars will not even deal with access. It is intended that they will deal only with machinery matters, such as pre-trial proceedings that might arise in custody cases. That is my understanding of the intention I have ascertained from elsewhere-not having received any clear guidance from the Minister on these matters.

Be that as it may, the Minister has indicated that the Government's policy is that judicial registrars should not be dealing with full-blown contested custody cases or, indeed, access cases, which can be just as disturbing and traumatic as a full custody case. If that is the position, I cannot see why the Minister or the Government-if the Minister does not like the wording of Senator Walters's amendment he might want to tidy it up-would be opposed in principle to Senator Walters's amendment. The Minister has now agreed that registrars should be specifically excluded from dealing with contested custody cases. Senator Walters will move an amendment in that regard later. I put it to the Minister that his own view of the matter, as expressed in answers to questions in this debate, is very much in accord with the principle of Senator Walters's amendment. Therefore, I think he ought seriously to think about it. He may feel that it needs some tidying up, that some qualification is desirable to enable registrars to deal with some machinery orders in a pre-trial proceeding before the full case is heard. Maybe Senator Walters's amendment would stop them doing that in a contested case. That is something that the Government might want to consider, but simply to take a stance of complete opposition to Senator Walters's amendment, in the light of the policy announced by the Minister when he answered questions earlier in this debate, seems to me to indicate a quite pig-headed attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make just a couple of comments on this matter. First of all, I repeat my earlier comments about registrars and judicial registrars; that is, that as far as we are concerned, registrars can deal with any non-contested substantive matter and that judicial registrars should be entitled, if a judge so rules, to deal with any matter, contested or not, provided only that there is a right of appeal to a judge from one of the parties concerned. Senator Walters has given a hypothetical case in which a person may feel that the judicial registrar is not dealing appropriately with that individual's matters and is not listening properly to his or her point of view, and so on. I can only point out that plenty of people believe that individual judges do not do precisely that and complain that they have not had a fair hearing. That is why, as Senator Durack pointed out, we have an appeals mechanism from judicial hearings. Without wanting to sound terribly cynical, however, from the cases that have come to my office it appears that people fight far more over who gets the property than over who gets the children.
—I think you have a pretty selective group, then.
—I am only talking about the people who complain to me about not being fairly dealt with--
—There are plenty of complaints about custody cases.

—Just wait a minute, Senator. I am talking of the people who complain to me about not getting a fair deal from the Family Court. But, in so far as children are a matter of dispute, as Senator Durack pointed out, access is as important as custody. Again, very many of the arguments are not about who is to have custody but about equitable, fair and reasonable access. Indeed, if more men were prepared to take on custody, we would have child-care centres popping up all over the country as they discover that it is not possible to be a sole supporting parent and work as well. I look forward to the day when 50 per cent of custody orders are made to the father.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we need to be a bit realistic about who fights over what but, by the same token, we do not need to make life more difficult than need be for either judges or judicial registrars in instances where people believe they are getting a raw deal. If they believe they are getting a raw deal from a judge-and plenty do-they have the capacity, as Senator Durack pointed out, to appeal. All I am asking for is that they have the right to go back to a judge from a judicial registrar in the event of their being unhappy. I accept the Minister's point that we may not be able to do it halfway through crossing the stream. I used to teach English and maths and am not into legalese, and I would just like to check how the lawyers use the word `may'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Selectively.

—Senator Puplick says, `selectively', and I have an awful sinking feeling that he is right. I understand that, if somebody seeks to appeal against a judicial decision, that appeal will not automatically be granted. There must be some grounds for the appeal and, if there are not, people do not have the right to appeal against a judicial decision. If that is correct, we may be only compounding the problem by not giving people a right to appeal, and have that appeal heard, from the decision of a judicial registrar to a judge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new section 26 (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court may, on application . . . review the exercise by a Judicial Registrar of a power delegated . . . and make such orders as it considers appropriate . . .

The word `may' has several meanings. Clearly, one meaning is that the Court is permitted to do that; it is able to do it; it is quite within its powers to do it; it can do it. But the additional meaning must be to make it not mandatory, to make it a discretionary matter. In other words, the word `shall' is not used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—That is a very good question.
—I think we got into this because I asked a very good question about three weeks ago. Quite seriously, Minister, it is a problem.
—I understand that it is serious and I am taking it seriously.

—I accept that people ought not to be able to make frivolous appeals from a judge's ruling to a full bench, but it seems unfortunate that this is being compounded by the fact that somebody whose case is heard by a judicial registrar can have a request that it go back before a judge turned down. I think we all accept that there is not going to be automatic approval for a review, for appeal, on a judicial decision, but I do not think it is right that we remove all absolute rights of appeal when the power is being delegated.

—I should perhaps draw Senator Haines's attention to another discretion in that area; that is, the one to which she has already referred. Proposed new section 26d (2) on page 4 of the Bill states that where there is a power delegated to a judicial registrar but the judicial registrar has not commenced to exercise his discretion, a judge may, on application by a person, order that the power be exercised in that case by a judge. Again, of course, it is a discretion. So even at the beginning all a person can do is go to a judge and ask that it be heard by a judge. A person has no absolute right to have it heard by a judge, and this is a further problem of the kind that Senator Haines has identified under section 26c. So, clearly, if a judicial registrar has had delegated to him or her a contested custody matter, including access, there is no way in the world under this section that a person has any absolute right to have the matter heard by a judge. It is only a discretion. A person has the right to apply for it to be heard by a judge; that is all he or she has.

—I agree with that. A discretion is vested in a judge to decide whether or not to review the exercise of power by the judicial registrar. I am advised that the decision by the judge not to exercise the discretion to review the decision of the registrar could then be appealed.
—To whom?

—To the appeal court of the Family Court. In other words, it is a decision by the judge not to review the decision by the registrar. I am advised that that decision is then able to be appealed because it amounts to a decree as defined in the interpretation section.

—I appeal to the Minister to agree to the amendment moved by Senator Walters. Senator Haines's conditions are clearly not satisfied by him in terms of his attitude. Senator Walters's amendment expresses in pretty well general terms the policy of the Government, as announced by the Minister in his answers to questions. We have already gone over this ground. Instead of the Minister opposing, or seemingly continuing to oppose the matter, why should we not now agree to Senator Walters's amendment? If the Minister wants this clause tidied up, if there are difficulties with it, this can be done when other amendments are being considered in the House of Representatives. That seems to me to be a fair sort of compromise and I appeal to the Minister to agree to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am thinking of doing is meeting Senator Haines most of the way she wants to go. Indeed, I am thinking of meeting Senator Walters all of the way she wants to go. I propose to do this by using the amendment that I have circulated to revised clause 12. I think we will probably need to amalgamate Senator Walters's amendment and my amendment in regard to paragraph (d) of my amendment.
—Is this a merger?
—In the most theoretical and abstract sense.
—I think Senator Puplick is right-a marriage of convenience.
—Yes. The paragraph would read:

SPEECH.PARA: except the power to make an order in relation to the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child, other than an order made in undefended proceedings or with the consent of all the parties to the proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for the judicial registrars?
—Yes. Obviously I am foreshadowing that we will do that in relation to registrars.
—Are you happy with that?
—I am not happy but I am prepared to--
—Senator Walters says that she would be happy with that.
—If Senator Walters is happy, I am delirious.
—Minister, would you clarify the position? Are you proposing to amend the amendment by adding certain words which you have just indicated to the Committee?
—The words that I would need to offer to the Committee as an amendment are:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 9, proposed subsection 26b (1), at end of proposed subsection, add `except the power to make an order in relation to the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child, other than an order made in undefended proceedings or with the consent of all the parties to the proceedings'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Done.
—Done.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, could you put clause 9?
—Do I understand, Senator Walters, that you would seek leave to withdraw your amendment?
—I seek leave to withdraw my amendment and I am delirious.
—Senator Tate, I understand that you now wish to move an amendment in the terms which you have just outlined to the Committee.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 9, proposed subsection 26b (1), at end of proposed subsection, add `except the power to make an order in relation to the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child, other than an order made in undefended proceedings or with the consent of all the parties to the proceedings.'.''.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 12 (Delegation of powers to Registrars).

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, to save a lot of time I should point out that I have circulated a revised clause 12. I think its terms are very clear. We have had a debate on all the issues that are comprised in the amendment that I have circulated. I wish it a speedy passage.

—I think before we debate the Government's amendment to clause 12 it would be appropriate for the Committee to attend to my amendment to clause 12, which is a wider and more significant amendment. The Government's amendment proposes a much more limited change. I think the Committee should first decide whether it wants to make a more substantial change. My amendment, which was circulated during the last committee debate, proposes to delete from clause 12 paragraphs (a) and (b). In other words, my amendment virtually guts the clause.
—The Chair is in the hands of the Committee. It is now up to Senator Tate to respond to Senator Durack.

—I am happy that Senator Durack's amendment be dealt with first. However, his amendment completely contradicts the purpose of the Government proposal. I think the differences between us were discussed at length both at the second reading stage and earlier during the committee stage. So obviously we will be opposing the amendment.
—Senator Durack, would you move your amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I think that is the appropriate way to go. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, paragraphs 12 (a) and (b), lines 20 and 21, leave out the paragraphs.

Let me just recapitulate a little. Previously we had quite a lengthy discussion in committee which resulted in the amendment which I have circulated, although we did not deal with it because we went on to other clauses. Clause 12 deals with section 37A of the Family Law Act which was passed by the Parliament in 1985 and which provides for a very wide delegation of powers to registrars. We have moved away from judicial registrars and we are now dealing with a better understood concept, namely, that of registrars who are officers of the Court. From the inception of the Court, they have performed most important functions of a minor character in conducting conferences, settling property disputes and exercising an increasing range of minor judicial functions. In 1985 the Parliament, in its wisdom, decided to give registrars these wider powers-perhaps more than was envisaged in the original Act-to enable judges to delegate to registrars a whole range of matters, some of which are spelt out but not exhaustively, and which restrict the registrars in this way. Section 37A (1) (g) of the Family Law Act 1975 states that the powers of the Court that may be delegated do not include:
(i) a decree of dissolution of marriage or nullity of marriage;
(ii) a declaration as to the validity of a marriage or the dissolution of annulment of a marriage; or
(iii) an order approving a maintenance agreement under section 87.

The Government's original amendments totally omitted that restriction so the Government came into the Senate with a proposal that there should be no restrictions whatsoever on the power to delegate to registrars. Of course, the Government retreated from that policy as a result of the committee debate, and as a result of the debate we have just had it has retreated from its stand in relation to delegation to judicial registrars in a very sensible way, if I may say so, even though the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) took a long time to see the sense of it. Perhaps it was the numbers that carried the day, but let us hope it was the sense of it.

It seems to me that the amendments we passed to section 37, as recently as 1985, make very considerable sense. The registrars of the Court, although well qualified people who, by and large, have successfully exercised important functions, do not have the proposed status of the judicial registrars who will be created and who will be like mini-judges. The Parliament showed good sense in 1985 in restricting the registrars' jurisdiction so that they could not make orders for the dissolution of a marriage whether defended or undefended; could not make declarations as to the validity of a marriage; and could not approve maintenance agreements under section 87. The approval of maintenance agreements under section 87 is a very important power because such a maintenance agreement could take away the future rights of a party. This power, like others, is very important. The Government is conceding, by its new proposed amendments, that registrars will not have power to grant a decree of dissolution when proceedings are defended. They will not have power to deal with decrees of nullity whether defended or undefended-that is the same limitation that exists under the present restriction. They will not have a power of declaration as to the validity of marriage or its dissolution whether defended or undefended-that is already in the restrictions. Now the Government is saying that they will now not have the power to make an order in relation to contested custody proceedings. The language of the Minister is more detailed but this is essentially what it means. This means that there is a considerable change of policy by the Government from the one that was embodied in clause 12 of the Bill.

I simply want to go a little further than the Government to ensure that we go back to the situation as it operates in the existing section 37A which would mean that the registrars could perform a whole range of minor judicial work. They could of course carry on their work of conducting conferences and settlements in relation to property and other matters such as maintenance and so on, but they would not be able to pronounce decrees of divorce, whether defended or undefended.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not right.

—That is the position if the Government adopts my amendment. The Government has now gone halfway and has said, `Oh well, we agree they cannot do defended divorces'. It is not very much different from the situation which we now have, because with the Government's amendment the registrars will not be able to deal with nullity of marriage, whether defended or undefended, or with a declaration as to validity of marriage, whether defended or undefended, or defended custody cases. Again, I fail to see why the Government, having retreated to the extent that it has in relation to clause 12, is bothering at all to proceed with this halfway house, so to speak, between the present position and the one it originally proposed. In view of this debate, I think that the Committee would be happier to adopt my amendment which would leave the situation as it stands and as was agreed to by the Parliament as recently as 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can usefully add a great deal. It is the Government's primary desire in regard to an extra role for registrars that they be enabled to deal with undefended dissolutions of marriages. That remains our core intention in pushing this particular clause 12. During the two weeks I have been overseas I have had a chance to read the Hansard record and reflect upon the debate. I think honourable senators will agree that we have gone a long way--
—That makes you an accredited masochist.

—In Manila it was very interesting to go through the Hansard debates. Honourable senators will agree that we have gone a tremendously long way to meet the concerns expressed in this chamber and, in particular, with the addition of paragraph (d) to my circulated amendment, the Committee should accept that the Government has gone as far as it can without abandoning the core of clause 12 which we still regard as important.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move my amendment as circulated under the heading `Revised clause 12':

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, clause 12, lines 20 to 21, leave out proposed paragraphs (a) and (b), insert the following paragraph:
(a) by omitting subsection (2) and substituting the following subsection:
``(2) (a) a decree of dissolution of marriage in proceedings that are defended;
(b) a decree of nullity of marriage;
(c) a declaration as to the validity of a marriage or the dissolution or annulment of a marriage; or

(d) an order in relation to the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child, other than an order made in undefended proceedings or with the consent of all parties to the proceedings.'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister please add to his amendment that the theme that is currently (c) in the Bill will become (b); otherwise we are left with a sort of gap in the middle.
—I was told that that will be dealt with in the Table Office.
—That happens as if by magic? That's wonderful!
—Order! It is not done by magic; it is done by the Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that Senator Tate is proposing, as it stands, does not seem to make sense. The amendment that we have now passed leaves out proposed paragraphs (a) and (b).
—No, that is the amendment before the Chair at the moment. It has not yet been passed.

—I thought you were suggesting that some words were to be added to Senator Tate's amendment, which seems quite necessary. The amendment says that we omit subsection (2) of the Family Law Act, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers of the court that may be delegated under subsection (1) do not include the power to make:
That has been omitted completely and the following subsection substituted:
(2) (a) A decree of dissolution of marriage . . .
That does not make any sense. We need to have the words in the existing section:
The powers of the court that may be delegated . . . do not include the powers to make:
I thought that was what Senator Haines was talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the point that Senator Haines made about what would happen to amendment (c) that would become correctly lettered by the Chairman's amendment when the Bill went through. But, if it is a matter of the principal Act at issue, the Minister should answer.

—We need some further elaboration from the Minister. He seems to be struggling with this. If he looks at his original amendment, it included those words. It omitted the clause and substituted the following:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The powers of the court that may be delegated under subsection (1) do not include the power to make:
(a) a decree of dissolution of marriage in proceedings that are defended;
(b) a decree of nullity of marriage; or
(c) a declaration as to the validity of a marriage or the dissolution or annulment of a marriage.
But those opening words have been omitted from the amendment that has been circulated at the last minute today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the amendment that has been circulated under the heading `Revised Clause 12' amends clause 12 of the Bill as originally circulated. It does not in itself purport to amend section 37a. It is an amendment to clause 12 of the Bill so that, if one looks at page 6 of the Bill, it would read:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 37a of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by omitting subsection (2) and substituting the following subsection:
Then (2) (a), (b), (c) and (d) would follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that does not make any sense.
—You still have to turn back to the principal Act.

—The Minister has not amended his original amendment. If he looks at his original amendment, which was put down the other day-I do not know when it was circulated-it did not have a proposed paragraph (d). It is the right drafting because it has the necessary words in it. Is the Minister saying that he is amending that amendment? He is putting down another substitute for the amendment in the printed Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 37a (2) in the principal Act starts off:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers of the Court that may be delegated under subsection (1) do not include the power to make:

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have omitted that.
—No, that is the preamble to section 37a (2) in the principal Act. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers of the Court that may be delegated under subsection (1) do not include the power to make:
Those words are retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are omitting the whole of subsection (2) in this revised clause. If you omit the whole of subsection (2) you have to have some words leading in.
—What the Minister is saying is that the words leading in are not affected; it is only what is in subsection (2) that are omitted.
—Mr Chairman, in that case, I think some enlightenment is dawning.
—It is taking a long time.
—Yes, I know. The amendment should read:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, clause 12, lines 20 to 21, leave out proposed paragraphs (a) and (b), insert the following paragraph:
``(a) by omitting subsection (2) and substituting the following subsection:
`(2) the powers of the Court that may be delegated under subsection (1) do not include the power to make:
(a) a decree of dissolution of marriage in proceedings that are defended;
(b) a decree of nullity of marriage;
(c) a declaration as to the validity of a marriage or the dissolution or annulment of a marriage; or

(d) an order in relation to the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child other than an order made in undefended proceedings or with the consent of all the parties to the proceedings.'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I was trying to tell you.
—I appreciate Senator Durack's assistance.
—Is leave granted by the Committee to amend the amendment accordingly?
—I am indebted to the Committee and to Senator Durack in particular.
—Senator Haines saw it and tried to help you.
—The question is that Senator Tate's amendment, as amended by leave, be agreed to. Paragraph (c) will be relettered by the Chairman to (b).
—The question is that the title be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a matter which was drawn to my attention a short time ago. It concerns an effect of the new clause 8b that we agreed to the last time we dealt with this Bill in committee. The Government circulated a whole raft of new amendments. We have started debate today at the very end of that list of amendments. At page 3 of the Government's revised amendments, under the heading `Seniority', it seeks to insert a new clause 8b into the Family Law Act. It deals with the rearrangement of seniority of judges as a result of the creation of the positions of Deputy Chief Judge and judge administrators.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed that at a meeting-I think only this morning-of a number of judges of the Family Court of Australia some concerns were expressed about the effect of clause 8b, which certainly affects the seniority of some existing judges as a result of the amendments and the creation of the office of judge administrator. This has been brought to the attention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-I do not know whether the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) is aware of it-and the judges have been told that this proposed new section will be amended to deal with the anomaly that it creates in relation to this question of seniority of some of the existing judges who have been in the appeals panel as against the new office of judge administrator which is created. I cannot give any further details to the Minister, but I wonder whether he has heard of this. The information I have received seems to be from an impeccable source. If some further amendments are to be made to the proposed new section, can the Minister tell us when that will be done?

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before the Chair is the title of the Bill. I will allow that as a question, but, if there is to be a prolonged debate, a motion for the recommittal of the relevant clause would be necessary. The Minister may wish to answer.

—Very briefly, Mr Chairman, and with your indulgence: as you were speaking it was drawn to my attention that apparently the matter arose in discussions between the Attorney-General and the judges of the Court at a meeting in Sydney this morning. The Attorney has not indicated to me any amendment that he will push, in order to deal, as I understand it, with one judge who apparently is to lose some seniority in some hierarchy. I have no amendment to offer. I have no doubt that it will be for the Attorney to determine whether it is appropriate that, in light of the discussions, some amendment be moved in the House of Representatives. Certainly, I have no amendment to offer here.

—Can the Minister take it one step further and indicate whether the Attorney proposes to make any amendment in light of the anomaly that has arisen as a result of a clause we have already passed and about which we were never informed by the Minister?
