That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will vigorously oppose the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill and will do so, I hope, effectively in terms of drawing public attention to what it believes to be a series of totally undesirable amendments which the Government will seek to make to two pieces of legislation by the passage of this Bill. The Bill represents, on the part of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Government, an admission of their failure to make the federal system work and their inability to deal with the constituent States of the Australian federation in a proper and civilised fashion. The Bill represents, in effect, an attempt by the Government to treat all environmental matters as if it were dealing with the Enmore branch of the Australian Labor Party. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that the Bill does to which I wish to draw attention is seek a significant extension of the Commonwealth's power in relation to areas which are or are potentially being considered for listing on the World Heritage List. It proceeds, by way of amendment to section 3 of the principal Act, to redefine the term `identified property' so as to bring into the term, and therefore to bring into the Minister's jurisdiction, property which is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth whose purpose, or one of whose purposes, is to consider whether the property forms part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage. The term `one of whose purposes' may be fairly limited. The purpose may be quite subsidiary to the main purpose for which an inquiry has been established. It is the sort of inquiry which may cast its net widely and which may, in fact, have quite extraordinary powers over the future land use decisions to be made within Australia. The first point I make is that I believe such an amendment is rendered unnecessary by the clear decision of the High Court of Australia on 10 March in relation to the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Act. If one looks at page 12 of the printed judgment of the High Court and at the words of the Chief Justice, Mr Justice Mason, and Mr Justice Brennan, one will see that they say:
It is for each State-
on this occasion they mean a State party to the convention-that is, Australia-
to determine what it will do by way of protecting a particular property pending resolution of its status as part of the heritage.
They went on to say:
. . . the State's duty to ensure protection of the heritage and to the attainment of the object of the Convention.
They say, in relation to that legislation:
. . . the absence of such action on the part of the Minister-
that is to say, a restraining action-
by way of interim protection in the meantime would expose the property to the possibility of irreparable damage.

The important thing to understand about this is that the High Court of Australia, in fact, has said that the power which the Government claims it needs to put into legislation is a power which is already there. Therefore, it is unnecessary for the rest of the Bill to be hinged upon some alleged necessity to undertake a course of action which clearly has been stated by the High Court to be within Commonwealth power.

The second point of real objection in this legislation relates to the appalling new system of inspectors. I refer to this new, intrusive system of inspectors whom, I suppose, one might refer to now as Richardson's greenshirts, who will be able to go crashing through private property to take all sorts of extraordinary actions on their own initiative. Despite the fact that Senator Richardson put out a Press statement on 3 March in which he said that these inspectors would really not be anything to worry about, everybody who has looked at this legislation knows that they are to be worried about. There have been representations to me from the Queensland Coal Association, the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia, the Tasmanian Chamber of Mines and the Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, to name just a few, who have all drawn attention to concerns that this new system of inspectors is to be put in place.

These inspectors really may do just about anything. They may enter and search premises, although I concede they are not entitled to enter a place defined as a `dwelling house' because an `eligible place' does not include a `dwelling house'. Whether one dwells in a caravan perhaps is a moot point or, indeed, like most of Senator Richardson's friends, whether one dwells in a tent may indeed be an equally interesting point. These inspectors may enter and search; they may take photographs; they may examine, inspect and measure. They may stop, detain and enter any vehicle. Allegedly, they are to do so either with the consent of the property owner concerned or on the basis of a warrant or-here is the great Richardson cop-out clause-if the entry is made in `circumstances that are of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry' without the consent of the person in charge, or the authority of a warrant issued under the relevant subsection.

Look at those tests: `such seriousness', `urgency', `require and justify', `immediate entry', `without the consent', `or the authority of a warrant'. In other words, it is an absolute, open-ended arrangement for all of Senator Richardson's greenshirts to now come traipsing through the private property of individual Australian citizens. Even if they were to get a warrant, from where would they get their warrant? They would get a warrant from a `judge of a court created by the Parliament'. Presumably, that could mean the Family Court of Australia because that is a court created by the Parliament. Senator Aulich, who is a great expert on and supporter of the intrusion into the civil liberties of Australian citizens, nods his consent. I can hear it from here. It is indicated that such a judge has to consent in writing to be nominated by Senator Richardson as one of the friendly judges who, presumably, are prepared to give a warrant whenever a warrant is asked for.

Finally, these wonderful inspectors are to be provided with identity cards which contain up to date photographs. Once again we have a system in which the insistence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to have identity cards is back on the agenda. If we look at the West Australian of 10 March this year we see the headline `Hawke revives ID card debate'. Once again we see that the whole paraphernalia of identity cards, inspectors and entry on to private property without consent or warrant is part of this Government's Enmore approach to dealing with the environment. We will find next that to qualify as an inspector one will have to have a certificate of character worthiness from the Minister's mate Tommy Domican.

We have vast paraphernalia put into the legislation that will remove from the jurisdiction of Australian courts the right to make certain determinations about the validity of nominations or, indeed, about the quality and worth of the nominations. In fact, under this Bill the Commonwealth will remove the test under the World Heritage Convention ensuring that an area is genuinely part of the cultural heritage or of the natural heritage of the nation. In doing so the Commonwealth has sought to make the World Heritage Committee the final arbiter of these matters. It is not dependent on an Australian court, Australian evaluation or Australian expertise, and there is plenty of that around. If one goes back to the decision of the High Court in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests case which I previously mentioned, one will see that the judges in fact are at pains to make that sort of evaluation. The majority of judges, speaking through Justices Mason and Brennan, in fact make it quite clear at page 14 of the transcript that they have made certain objective judgments about the validity of the law prohibiting tree felling and the removal in the course of forestry operations, road and track construction and excavation, which are `generally speaking acts involving a potential risk or injury to a particular place'. Similarly, in coming to a decision that parts of the Act were invalid, Her Honour Justice Gaudron did so on the basis of looking at the scientific evidence which was presented to the court and coming to the conclusion that the scientific evidence did not justify the provisions of the Bill. Therefore, to say that in Australia, even at the level of the High Court of Australia, we do not have the capacity to make these judgments, is not only insulting but is, in fact, also revealing of the fact that Senator Richardson does not want these matters dealt with properly within Australian jurisdiction, subject to the normal public scrutiny and debate which would accompany those things in Australia.

We have a specious part added to the Bill to the effect that we will have some fast track mechanism of dealing with compensation claims in cases in which there has been an acquisition of property. Yet the most vulnerable area in Australia remains the Northern Territory. Senator Collins, who is in the chamber, and my colleague Senator Tambling will know that as a result of the High Court's decision in the Teori Tau case in 1969 the Commonwealth is not obliged to provide just terms for the acquisition of property which takes place within the Territory which they represent. But there is no attempt in this Bill to address that particular matter. The Bill simply states that if there is an acquisition of property it shall have the same meaning and be done on the same terms as paragraph 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia. This is of no comfort whatsoever to any of Senator Tambling's or Senator Collins's constituents. However, that matter is not addressed.

Next in the legislation we have the removal of the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 from the Commonwealth's own actions. This is the situation that arises: If I am the potential builder of a motel adjacent to Ayers Rock, Uluru, I have to go through the process of an environmental impact statement to see whether in fact such construction is environmentally sound. I have to make my presentation; I have to have it evaluated and judged. I have to go through a whole set of evaluation procedures. However, if I am Mr John Brown and reinstated as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and I want to build a wretched monorail around Uluru, then I am entitled to do so and to desecrate it without having to go through the analysis and rigour of the impact of proposals legislation. In other words, the Commonwealth frees itself under this Bill from any necessity to submit its own development proposals in World Heritage listed areas or areas subject to potential World Heritage listing to its own legislation, something which it requires other people or indeed the States to adhere to if they want to build or develop in exactly the same way. That is absolutely unjustifiable. The Government gives itself carte blanche. In fact, it retrospectively seeks to validate actions already undertaken which may have been in breach of that legislation, and it does so by asserting that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act does not apply to anything done under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act or regulations made under that Act. That is absolutely scandalous.

The next thing we have in the legislation is the thimble and pea trick with the regulations made under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act relating to the tropical rainforests of north Queensland. Today time does not permit me to go into great details about this particular matter, other than to draw attention to the level of debate in which Senator Richardson has engaged. He has consistently refused the offer made to him by the Ahern Government in Queensland to discuss this matter and come to a sensible, rational decision and determination in which both the Commonwealth and the States can be participants and partners. The Minister has consistently refused that offer. Instead he has indulged in gratuitous abuse of the Queensland Government and the Queensland Department of Forestry. Senator Richardson put out a statement on 3 March in which he claimed that forestry maps reveal some `gross deceit' about how much or how little virgin rainforests remains and how much of that has been logged or not logged.

A detailed examination of the reply which the Queensland Department of Forestry has prepared on this matter reveals that it is Senator Richardson's Department which has been guilty of gross deceit about these figures. If one reads carefully the material provided and if one examines the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation studies done by Hopkins, Tracey and others, one sees that the area to which Senator Richardson refers is in fact not the area which is exclusively concerned with the question of the World Heritage listing boundaries. In fact, it is a much larger area. It is the whole of the rainforest estate remaining between Townsville and Cooktown. The Minister has provided a quite dishonest presentation of the facts in this matter.

We are already at a crisis point in terms of the economic development of Australian resources. Something of the order of 20 per cent of the land mass of the Australian continent has already been removed from potential economic evaluation, let alone exploitation. If this process continues unabated, we will soon get up towards one-third of the Australian land mass quarantined out, not simply from development which may or may not be justified once environmental and economic considerations have been properly taken into account and evaluated but even from being properly and scientifically examined as to its economic and ecological worth. Throughout this whole process I have stressed repeatedly, and the Opposition has stressed repeatedly, that this matter could have been handled in a proper, coherent and federalist manner by dealing fairly, openly, and honestly with the Queensland Government in respect of the north Queensland situation. Discussions which took place a couple of days ago in my Sydney office involving myself, the Hon. Mike Ahern, Premier of Queensland, and my senior shadow cabinet colleagues, Mr Andrew Peacock and Senator John Stone, brought us to a position in which we have made it abundantly clear that the Federal coalition in government could have negotiated openly with the Queensland Government to bring about a resolution of this particular matter.

I am in a position to say that the approach we would have made to the Queensland Government as the basis upon which those discussions would have proceeded-I believe they would have proceeded in a satisfactory fashion towards a satisfactory conclusion-would have been on the following premises: First, we would have proposed that the State of Queensland take steps to create a greater Daintree national park which would have been created within the laws and jurisdiction of that State. It would have been created in the area between Mount Molloy and Cooktown, based upon the existing national parks of the Daintree River, the Dagmar Range, Wonga, Cape Tribulation, Cedar Bay and Black Mountain. We believe that it would have been possible to identify clearly the absolutely unique characteristic of the Daintree-Cape Tribulation area and to give that area very special protection, because it is quite unique and undoubtedly worthy of very special protection, without in fact drawing the sort of extensive, ambit claim boundaries which have been drawn by Senator Richardson and his Government.

We would have sought to have, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, a complete socioeconomic and environmental evaluation of the Queensland wet tropic rainforests. That inquiry would have been open and public and conducted along the lines of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry so that everybody who was interested, everybody who wanted to present scientific evidence, to challenge scientific claims, to have evidence or claims independently, properly and publicly evaluated, would have had the chance to do so. We would not have proceeded with World Heritage listing until that process had been completed and until we had secured the agreement of the Queensland State authorities to proceed with that World Heritage listing. We would have sought to develop a sensible multiple land use plan, using the sorts of zonal arrangements which have been applied successfully by the Commonwealth in Queensland to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

We would have ensured that the north Queensland timber industry would have been allowed to continue its operations and that there would have been an independent evaluation of the need to commence any logging activities in areas which are currently virgin. We would have expected that, as evidence of good faith on the part of the local industry, it would have agreed to a voluntary moratorium on that particular activity; and, indeed, there should be no variation in the current logging quotas set by the State Government. That, together with the proclamation by Queensland of the Greater Daintree National Park in which those activities destructive of the environment, including specifically logging and mining, would not have been allowed to proceed, would have been the basis for an intelligent discussion of these particular matters. We would have sought to bring an end sensibly and in an orderly fashion those activities which could be demonstrated to be sufficiently and significantly environmentally destructive in a way which clearly would have been incompatible with the maintenance of a good national park and significant heritage values.

I take this opportunity to make two remarks about Queensland's national parks and about its timber industry in particular: The standard of establishment and maintenance of Queensland national parks is of the highest order, and the competence and capability of the Queensland Department of Forestry is of the highest order. There is no reason to believe that this would not have been something which a clear public examination of these issues would have demonstrated to be the case. We certainly would have sought to provide Queensland with additional assistance under the national rainforest conservation program. Indeed, we would have hoped that any inquiry would have been concluded within a reasonable timeframe and that its decision would have been final so that other important and highly desirable activities in the region, such as the development of the Cape York space centre, were in no way placed in jeopardy or in no way prejudiced in their future development. We would have ensured that any authority managing the Greater Daintree National Park area would have had the closest co-operation and the closest liaison with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority because, after all, we are talking about two physically immediately adjacent areas.

That would have been the basis upon which we would have entered into sensible negotiations with the Queensland Government. I believe, given the willingness of the new Queensland Government, which has been repeated by Premier Ahern on a number of occasions, it would have been possible to achieve balanced development, both in terms of environmental protection and in terms of economic development, in that particular region of Australia. Exactly the same process could have been under way in Tasmania. Just a week or so ago my Liberal Party Leader, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, went to Tasmania for discussions with the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, and they issued a joint statement which said in part:

The States traditionally have responsibilities for land use matters. Clearly, some environmental issues involve national considerations as well and views we have we will seek to put in a co-operative and constructive manner.

In other words, the basis for constructive discussion with Tasmania has also been made abundantly clear. That, however, is not the way in which Senator Richardson and his mates in the Australian Labor Party proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —And his mates in the Australian Democrats.

—Indeed, as Senator Stone has said, his mates in the Australian Democrats. They proceed on the basis quite simply of seeking deliberately to manufacture confrontations where confrontations need not exist. The very perceptive article by Mike Seccombe in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald has as its headline `Has Richardson barked up the wrong tree?'. Of course, the answer to that is yes because, quite simply, the Minister is looking for every available opportunity to provoke a confrontation in which he does not care who are the victims. He does not care whether the victims are either the townspeople of Ravenshoe, or the people of south-west Tasmania, or indeed even the trees in north Queensland, or the trees in Tasmania, as long as he sees political advantage in the seats in Sydney and Melbourne, which, as far as he is concerned, are his power base and the power base of the Labor Party within this Parliament. So he now produces this piece of legislation which is absolutely unnecessary in terms of the powers of the Commonwealth, given what the High Court of Australia has most recently said in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry case. Under this Bill we have established a system of absolutely unnecessary inspectors-Richardson's greenshirts-with all their powers, with all their enforcement provisions to enter and search places, take photographs and record occurrences, inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements, and stop, detain, enter and search any vehicle-the whole gamut of this sort of environmental police state that the Minister wishes to establish. The Government wants to remove from Australian courts and tribunals the right to make final determinations and, above all, to remove from the Government the necessity to comply with its own Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act so that it may read it in such a way as to give retrospective justification to the things which it has done but which it was not entitled to do in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a bogus, dishonest piece of legislation. It has been produced for bogus and dishonest reasons. It deserves to be rejected and, above all, it should be exposed as a clear admission on the part of this Federal Labor Government that it cannot make co-operative federalism work for one reason and one reason only: the Minister, Senator Richardson, and his Government do not want co-operative federalism to work. They seek deliberate confrontation regardless of cost and, above all, regardless of the gravest cost to our unique Australian environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I find it quite difficult to agree with some of the remarks made by Senator Puplick. One reason why we have not been able to have cooperative federalism is the intransigence of the Queensland Government. I will mention that later because I think it is quite important to have a look at that Government's record and at how it tries to do anything it possibly can to frustrate the efforts of the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill is an important Bill for World Heritage areas throughout Australia. In the short term it has special significance for certain areas in Queensland, the State that I represent in this chamber. The main purpose of the Bill is to clarify and strengthen the protection afforded by the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. The Bill sets out in more detail than is now present in Commonwealth legislation when property is to be regarded as identified property for the purposes of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. The Bill also provides for the appointment of inspectors. It repeals certain provisions of the Act that I have just mentioned. These provisions were held to be invalid in the dams case. It also simplifies the procedure for determining compensation when the operation of the World Heritage Properties Act results in the acquisition of property.

An important practical effect of the Bill is to afford interim protection to the wet tropical rainforests in Queensland, pending a decision by the World Heritage Committee on the nomination of this area for World Heritage listing in December last year. I shall return to this specific matter later. But before I do, I wish to outline the importance of retaining certain parts of our environment in their present state and the consequent importance of World Heritage legislation.

The World Heritage Convention is an important international expression of the need to protect and conserve the world's natural and cultural heritage. In the days of redevelopment and massive uses of non-renewable resources it is important for the whole world to consider what parts of our cultural and natural environments should become inviolate. The Convention helps to do this. It was adopted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation General Conference in 1972 and came into force in 1975. Australia ratified the Convention in 1974, and was the seventh nation to do so. There are now 100 countries which are party to the Convention. These include the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table listing all those nations which are now party to the Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Signatories to the Convention commit themselves to help in the identification, protection, conservation and preservation of World Heritage properties. They accept that it is their responsibility to identify and safeguard those parts of the heritage which are located in their own countries. They agree that they will do all they can, with their own resources and with what international assistance they can obtain, to ensure adequate protection. Signatories also undertake to refrain from deliberately damaging their cultural and natural heritage and to take the appropriate legal, scientific, technical, administrative and financial measures necessary for the heritage's protection.

SPEECH.PARA: The Convention is administered by a World Heritage Committee consisting of 21 nations elected from those nations which are party to the Convention. Elections are held every two years. It is noteworthy that Australia has served as a member of the Committee continuously since 1976. It is the only nation to have done so. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The executive body of the World Heritage Committee is the World Heritage Bureau. This consists of a chairman, five vice-chairmen and a rapporteur. The Bureau is elected by and from the Committee at its annual meeting and holds office until the following meeting of the Committee. Australia served on the Bureau for three consecutive years-1980-81, 1981-82 and 1982-83-and also in 1984-85. The conditions which have to be satisfied before any property, cultural or natural, is inscribed on the World Heritage List are extensive. It is worth while to outline how these conditions are assessed. Only the national governments of member countries can nominate areas for the World Heritage List. It is not the role of national governments to decide, however, whether the area so nominated is accorded a World Heritage listing. This is the responsibility of the World Heritage Committee. Once a nomination is lodged, it is first thoroughly assessed by the World Heritage Bureau. The Bureau is assisted in this task by non-governmental organisations. On occasion, internationally acknowledged scientists are invited to act as referees for a nomination related to the natural environment. The rigorous procedures adopted by the Bureau and by the Committee which makes the final decision are evident in the number of nominations which have not been successful. Of the 63 nominations scheduled for consideration by the Committee in 1987, only 41 were accepted for inscription on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: What are some of the places on the World Heritage List? There are 288, and they include the Pyramids of Egypt, the Grand Canyon of the United States of America, Westminster Abbey, and the Great Wall of China. Australian properties on the World Heritage List are the Great Barrier Reef, which extends for a greater part of the length of my State of Queensland, stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park, the Lord Howe Island group, the Australian east coast temperate and sub-tropical rainforest parks, the western Tasmanian wilderness national parks, and Uluru National Park.

The Australian Government has a first-class record in its commitment to the environment and to heritage conservation. Australians look to the Commonwealth to maintain this commitment, and it is doing so in collaboration with the States and Territories. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth does not always receive co-operation from the States. This has been particularly so with regard to the area known as the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia. This area in Queensland was nominated for inclusion in the World Heritage List in December last. For many years it has been identified both nationally and internationally as being of World Heritage value. Despite this, the Queensland Government has opposed and continues to oppose the nomination.

Given its past record in matters pertaining to the environment, the Queensland Government's attitude is hardly surprising. Only by the actions of firstly the Whitlam Government and then the Fraser Government was Fraser Island spared from destruction by mineral sand extraction. The only lasting record of the Bjelke-Petersen Queensland Government in relation to Fraser Island was Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's unscrupulous act of blackguarding and financially ruining John Sinclair, who was the saviour of Fraser Island. In 1975, the Commonwealth passed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. The Bjelke-Petersen Government was unco-operative with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Indeed, there were often suggestions made by the Queensland Government opponents that the Barrier Reef should be available for oil exploration.

Returning to the North Queensland rainforests, or, to use the full title, the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia, it is highly likely that this area will be included in the World Heritage List. These rainforests contain the highest concentration of primitive plant families on earth, they are home to a high diversity of animal life, including one endangered species, and hold important clues to the origin, evolution and migration of flowering plants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw attention to the Bill that we are debating, the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill. In 20 minutes Senator Colston has not addressed one part of that Bill. I ask you to direct him to be relevant to the Bill.
—There is no point of order. Senator Colston is being relevant to the Bill.

—I was speaking about the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia. In addition to what I said earlier, the region is one of natural beauty, with waterfalls, deep gorges, fast-flowing rivers, and spectacular mountain peaks. The Commonwealth Government believes that this area qualifies for World Heritage listing on cultural grounds as well. The only remaining recognised Australian Aboriginal rainforest culture is found in the wet tropics.

SPEECH.PARA: For those who are unconvinced of the significance of this region, I refer them to a 1986 publication of the Australian Heritage Commission. The publication is entitled Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland. Their Conservation Significance. This is a report to the Australian Heritage Commission by the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland. Undoubtedly, that Society would have been desirous of putting forward its point of view. But a careful reading indicates a well written scientific appraisal of the area. Allow me to quote from a part of the summary:

Geologically, the Area has both very old and relatively recent elements, and includes granites, basalts, acid volcanics, metamorphics and alluvia. It is a region of rugged topography with fast-flowing rivers, deep gorges and numerous waterfalls. The highest mountain in Northern Australia, Mt. Bartle Frere (1622 metres), is a biologically important site within the area. The association of fringing coral reefs and rainforested coastline in the Cape Tribulation region has no recorded parallel.
The summary goes on to describe the flora of the area, outlining the diversity of plant life. In describing the fauna, the summary notes:

With respect to the fauna, the wet tropical region of North-East Queensland has the highest diversity of any area in Australia. It contains 30 per cent of Australia's marsupial species, 60 per cent of the bat species, 30 per cent of the frog species, 23 per cent of the reptile species and 62 per cent of the butterfly species. Eighteen per cent of Australia's bird species occur in the rainforests of the Area. There are no less than 54 species of vertebrate animals that are unique to the Area.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many workers? What about the workers?

—If Senator Boswell wants to hear about the workers of the area I invite him to be here at 8 o'clock, because at about that time I shall be speaking about them. The summary makes mention of the record of Aboriginal culture which I mentioned earlier. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The section of the Study Area between Cooktown and Cardwell contains the only recognized Australian Aboriginal rainforest culture and is therefore a significant component of the cultural record of Aboriginal society which has the longest continuous history in the world. The oral pre-history of this surviving Aboriginal rainforest culture is the oldest known for any non-literate indigenous people: Archaeological studies in Jiyer cave in the remote Russell River valley have yielded valuable information to date, and are believed to hold records, as yet unexcavated, dating back more than 10 000 years. The Study Area contains the only remaining, functioning Aboriginal culture using the coastal environment anywhere on the east coast of the mainland.
Finally, the summary concludes:

It is concluded that the wet tropics of North-east Queensland are of outstanding conservation significance and more than adequately fulfil the criteria defined by the World Heritage Committee for inclusion in the World Heritage List.
I recommend a reading of not only the summary but the whole publication. It clearly outlines what a unique area this part of Australia is.

In spite of the heritage value of the area, the Queensland Government has steadfastly refused to consider World Heritage nomination and has maintained that rainforest logging should continue. What was the Commonwealth to do under these circumstances? Would it have been acceptable to ignore its obligations under the World Heritage Convention and allow a potential World Heritage listing to be destroyed? Of course it would not be acceptable. The Commonwealth's only real option was to nominate the area for the World Heritage List and ban rainforest logging.

Even though the Commonwealth has finally nominated the area, the Queensland Government has indicated that it believes that normal forestry management practices in north Queensland should continue. This would put in danger the integrity of the nominated area. The passage of this Bill will permit the area to be protected while World Heritage listing is being considered. Under the Bill, identified property-that is, property to be protected-will cover the three stages of the World Heritage Convention: identification, nomination, and listing. Protection will be afforded at each stage.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was discussing the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and had mentioned various aspects in relation to the north Queensland rainforests. I indicated that the passage of the Bill will permit the north Queensland rainforest area to be protected while the World Heritage listing is being considered. Identified property, that is, the property to be protected, will cover the three stages of the World Heritage Convention-identification, nomination and listing. Protection will therefore be afforded at each stage. The amended World Heritage Act, therefore, will afford interim protection to the north Queensland rainforests pending a decision by the World Heritage Committee on the application for their inclusion on the World Heritage List. The World Heritage Committee will determine whether the north Queensland rainforests constitute a natural heritage of outstanding universal value for all the world. This determination will be made at its next meeting in November this year. In making its determination it will be assisted by the advice of independent experts. These people will have inspected and assessed the area and will have conducted discussions with both the Commonwealth and Queensland governments.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely essential that, until the World Heritage Committee makes its determination, the area should be afforded protection. It would be absurd if the World Heritage Committee later this year decided to include the north Queensland rainforests on the World Heritage List, only to find that they had been irreparably damaged in the meantime. Protection of this area from human interference will be permanent if the rainforests are placed on the World Heritage List. If the World Heritage Committee decided against the nomination, the protection under the amended Act would cease.

I would like to make some mention of the social dislocation which will occur as a result of the nomination of the northern rainforests for World Heritage listing. This is a real problem and concerns not only senators representing the State of Queensland but all senators in this chamber. I remind the Senate that the Hawke Government has a first-class record in the provision of employment prospects for people throughout Australia. Since the Government came to office in 1983 a million new jobs have been created. Well over one million families have benefited from this massive increase in employment opportunities. The rate of unemployment is decreasing and, although the Queensland State Administration has caused higher than average unemployment in that State, the Federal Government is pleased, but not complacent, about its record. I mention this to show that this Government gives a high priority to providing work opportunities. It is well aware that, behind the statistics of the unemployed and the employed, there are real people with financial obligations and, in some cases, families to support. The Government has no intention of lightly making policy decisions which have the effect of taking away the livelihood of any group of Australian workers. Where policy decisions do have this effect, the Government will do all it can to alleviate the dislocation which occurs.

Some people may suggest that if specific employment opportunities are to be lost due to certain policy decisions, those decisions should not be made. In relation to the north Queensland rainforests, that is just not an acceptable option. Continued logging would destroy a highly sensitive area, an area that the World Heritage Committee is likely to decide later this year should be afforded protection from destruction. Logging, therefore, must stop. I am not unmindful of the initial trauma caused by such a decision. I was brought up in a family dependent upon the building industry and know only too well the dislocation that occurs when a job finishes and no further work is available. I can remember when my father was shamefully put off by Hornibrooks, then a major Brisbane firm, because he had been working for the company for 9 1/2 years and, if he had attained his ten years, would have been eligible for prorata long service leave. The family disruption was immense. So, yes, I do understand the problems.

But, unlike Hornibrooks, there is nothing shameful about the Government's policy in relation to the north Queensland rainforests. Unlike Hornibrooks, the Federal Government is assisting those whose method of earning a living has been disrupted. Workers who were directly employed in the timber industry and who lost their jobs as the result of the Government's decision to seek World Heritage listing for the north Queensland rainforests are eligible for a lump sum payment of $2,500 from the Commonwealth. These unemployed workers, plus those workers employed in other industries who can show that they lost their jobs as the result of the Government's decision, are eligible for short term council employment and wage subsidies in other jobs. At present about 220 people have received local authority employment, paid for by the Commonwealth at award wages. It is expected that there will shortly be work for 500 to 600 people. These jobs will run for between 13 and 52 weeks and will comprise a variety of blue and white collar council jobs. A wage subsidy of between $50 and $125 per week is available to employers who hire retrenched workers. This program is essentially the Jobstart program without the need of the six-month waiting period.

All that I have mentioned are essentially short term jobs. The Government, however, intends to go further than this. A Cabinet submission on compensation for the north Queensland rainforest areas is being prepared and is likely to be considered in the next few weeks. This will include the establishment of long term employment opportunities and compensation for companies connected with the timber industry. The package is based on six socioeconomic consultant studies which have been received by the Government. I must stress that the success of the package will not depend on Commonwealth action alone. There will have to be co-operation at all three levels of government. I have no doubt that local authorities will give the co-operation that is required. They understand that the well-being of their area depends upon an active work force, not an unemployed one. The Queensland Government's record of co-operation with the Federal Government has really been one of a lack of co-operation. For the sake of workers in north Queensland, it is essential that the Queensland Government take a mature approach to the Commonwealth's package when it is released.

I earlier outlined the essential nature of this amending legislation. I have dwelt upon its significance for the north Queensland rainforests because this is an important contemporary matter. It is important for the State of Queensland, for Australia and for the world, but the legislation will assist the Australian Government to fulfil its obligations in relation to the north Queensland rainforests. It will also assist the Government to fulfil its obligations in other areas under the World Heritage Convention. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 is just a further stage in the naked opportunism that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who introduced the legislation, demonstrates in relation to his professional career. It is a blatant attempt to buy some votes from a few people that he thinks exist in Sydney and Melbourne. But, like most of the schemes or rorts that the Australian Labor Party gets involved in, it is very badly thought through and it will misfire upon those opposite. I think it has misfired already, from the way they were caught with their hands in the cookie jar over the Harris-Daishowa business. That showed the sincerity of the commitment of Senator Richardson to the conservation cause.
—He was taking money from a woodchipper.

—As Senator Sanders says, on the one hand he is taking money from a woodchipper, reducing the landscape to the sort of devastation that only a nuclear disaster can bring; and, on the other hand, he is turning around to all the white wine whingers of Sydney and Melbourne and saying, `Trust me. I will keep your grass green, the trees growing, the birds singing and the rest of it'. What a hypocrite. Unfortunately for Senator Richardson, times move on. I have been involved in the conservation movement for far longer than Senator Richardson has known the meaning of the word `environment'. That involvement goes back over 30 years to my university days. As a bushwalker and a rockclimber I learnt the principles of conservation of the Australian bushland which Senator Richardson still has not learnt today. Ever since I have kept an interest in what is going on in the community. None of us wants to live amongst our own garbage. None of us wants to change the things that we have in the natural environment to the extent that our children and grandchildren will not enjoy them.
—But. Come on, give us the but.

—There are no buts, Mr Minister. There are just some facts, if you have the intelligence to follow the argument. The community realises that we want to preserve the assets that we have. But people want a balanced view. They do not want the fruitcakes and the obsessionists running around denying the assets that we have for the use of mankind. What the community wants is a balanced view which allows us to preserve what we have and to use it for our benefit and enjoyment if that can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no simple formula for this. The situations are not the same. Dealing with the rainforests is not the same as dealing with the Great Barrier Reef. Again, the environment around Ayers Rock is quite different. The community recognises that. What people want from governments is an intelligent management plan so that an asset is preserved and not destroyed through use. But it must be recognised that the community may want an important asset used.

I would like to say something about World Heritage listing. I think the way in which the Australian Labor Party, with its great cultural cringe, always leaps to be part of international treaties says a lot about the confidence it has in its ability to manage and its judgment on cultural matters. There is also a dark and sinister side to this because one of the attractions for the Labor Party of international treaties is that they allow it to use the external affairs power of the Constitution and outflank in a dishonest way, in a way that was never intended, the Constitution of Australia.

Whatever the nature of State and Federal governments of Australia, I would defend very strongly the standards of public administration in this country. With respect to the administration of public affairs, I do not believe that either a State or Federal government in Australia has to sign an international treaty in order to give it a leg up to attain a higher level of management. This country has a great deal to be proud of in regard to all levels of public administration. We can run things properly, sensibly, responsibly and honestly.

I have a personal view that while there are cases for World Heritage listing of some assets, I do not see this automatically as the desired path to follow. For example, I think in the case of rainforests, the National Parks and Wildlife Service of Queensland has proved its ability to administer the area in question. Indeed, under the legislation, if it ever goes through, it will be the administering authority in the fullness of time. The Service is well able to do the job and preserve the park in every way that the Minister wants. But the area does not have to be a World Heritage listing just because it is a national park. But that is a side issue.

This Bill is designed, first of all, to cut the ground completely from under the Queensland legal challenge which would have succeeded under the existing legislation. The Government has altered the goal posts. It seeks to achieve through legislation a cover-up for the faults in its earlier legislation. This is the most naked grab for an expansion of central powers by the Canberra Government that we have seen for many a long year. I hesitate in giving the Government the ultimate accolade because, if one goes back through history, one finds that the Labor Party has always had this great hang-up. Somehow it seeks to compensate for that inferiority complex which I was talking about before-the doubts that it has about its own administration ability. It feels that if it takes over everything it will eliminate any challenges to its powers by State governments. I suppose that is the psychology behind this legislation.

This Bill allows property which has been designated by the Minister to be isolated and treated as if it already was listed and approved by the World Heritage Commission. In so doing, the Commonwealth takes unto itself powers that no responsible government would ever take. Under the legislation inspectors can be appointed and can operate as secret police with rights of entry on the basis of a simple judicial warrant, a warrant issued by any judge of any court set up by the Parliament. As Senator Puplick said, this can be done by a Family Court judge, and in saying that I do not mean any disrespect to those judges, who have a very difficult job to perform. But they are hardly the people in the community to pass judgment on whether a claim by a Minister for a permit to be issued for a search and destroy or a search and enter exercise into bushlands is in the public interest. They simply cannot make that sort of judgment.

Very interestingly, too, the Bill absolves the Commonwealth from observing its own environmental impact study legislation. In other words, it is the old Labor business of one law for you and one law for me-just do not ask me what the law is that applies to me. The big problem with this legislation is that it is a gross abuse of the federal system. Under the Australian Constitution we hold that how land is administered is a matter for the sovereign States. That does not mean that the Commonwealth, in its wisdom, cannot consult with, counsel or advise if it thinks that what a State is doing is not in the public or national interest. But it is not part of our practice, and it is not our legal right as members of the Federal Parliament in a federal system, to be dictating in this jack booted fashion as to what the States will do on land use matters.

I find it particularly galling that in this House, which was set up to be a States House, we have a Minister, who is a senator, introducing some legislation that flies in the very face of what a federal system is about. The Liberal Party of Australia has no objection to moves towards World Heritage listing. But we have made it abundantly clear-and we will continue to do so-that there must be co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth. It is okay with us if a State approaches the Commonwealth Government and says, `We would like such and such an area listed or considered for World Heritage listing'. What we will not have is a Federal government dictating to a State government that such and such a thing will be done. As Senator Puplick said, in this instance Liberal and National party policy would have been to set up a Greater Daintree National Park which would have included most of the area that is in dispute.

As a Queenslander and as someone who has spent a great deal of time in the north-since Senator Richardson went adrift and took leave of his responsibilities, I have been forced to spend a great deal more time up there-I have found no opposition at all in Queensland to preserving the rainforest areas. The great majority of the Queensland community is quite happy to see those areas as a national park and have them preserved in perpetuity. There is no argument about that at all. The Liberal Party and the National Party recognise that. We would have liked to have seen a Greater Daintree National Park set up. We would have liked to have seen an independent authority come in and define the boundaries of that national park. Unlike Senator Richardson, we would not have decided, with the great clarity of vision that comes from being about 2,000 miles away from the site, where those boundaries should be drawn. We would have left that to independent experts. We would have protected the timber industry, though we would have put a prohibition on the logging of virgin forests.

We would have set up an inquiry into sustainable yields for long term logging. Unlike Senator Colston and other speakers on the Labor side, we do not believe that when we are spending $1 billion a year in importing forest products we should be negligent of the assets we have in this country. More important than the $1 billion a year we are spending on importing forest products is the loss of 2,000 to 3,000 jobs as a result of the callous actions that the Labor Party is imposing on the community in north Queensland. These people have given most of their lives to supporting the timber industry and working in it. They are honest, hard working citizens and they do not deserve to have their livelihood taken away by a stroke of the pen by an ignorant Minister who is pursuing a few votes for blatant, political and opportunistic purposes.

We would also have done something to secure private landholdings on the borders of whatever national park we set up because there is no security at all for private landholders under the Richardson scheme. One of the very great worries about the World Heritage listing is the way that, once a property is listed, the Federal Government can, by regulation and without any reference to the Parliament at all, expand the borders of that listing willy-nilly. To anyone who lives in the area that is quite frightening.

I turn to how World Heritage listing takes place. This is a function of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), one of the agencies of the United Nations, but when a proposal for World Heritage listing is made to UNESCO by a government, the actual examination is carried out by a body called the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN). One of the regrettable facts is that extremists in the conservation movement in Australia-the Bob Browns, the Mosleys and the Ketos-have politicised the IUCN, which has a proud record as a responsible scientific body. On occasions it has been irritated by the actions of people such as those I have mentioned who have gone to its conventions and have tried, for narrow personal aims, to politicise what has been an impartial international body. It has come to my notice that delegates of member nations of IUCN are more than a little disaffected by the behaviour of these more radical Australian delegates who have gone to conventions on various occasions.

I was interested to read the nomination, which Senator Richardson characteristically did not table in the Senate, that the Government made of wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia for inclusion in the World Heritage listing. With his usual scrupulous attention to detail and the truth, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has given a lead in to the nomination. One is required to put in juridical data on the owner, legal status and responsible administration. We then come to a blatant lie. We find that the public property is administered by the Queensland Government through many agencies, including principally the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Department of Forestry and the Land Administration Commission. Private property is the responsibility of the owners, who must comply with relevant laws on ownership and occupation of their land. The Government has enacted the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 to implement its responsibilities and obligations arising from the World Heritage conventions. We now come to the significant part of the nomination, which says that a joint authority of the Australian and Queensland governments `is envisaged to assume responsibility for administration of the property'. That is a blatant lie. In the second reading speech the Minister says that, unfortunately, the Queensland Government has no intention-or words to that effect-of co-operating with the Federal Government on this matter. On page 3 of his speech he says:
It is an unfortunate fact, however, that this is not always the case-
he is talking about co-operation between the State and Federal governments-

the area known as the `Wet Tropical Rainforest of North-east Australia', nominated by Australia in December 1987 for inclusion in the World Heritage List, has been identified for a number of years both nationally and internationally as being of World Heritage value. Despite this, the Queensland Government continues to oppose the nomination.

His very words in this chamber were `continues to oppose'. But here is this blatant lie in this presentation for the World Heritage listing claiming that a joint authority of Australian and Queensland governments is envisaged. How could the Minister envisage it with the history of opposition from the Queensland Government? It is a blatant misrepresentation of fact to a world authority.

Conservation is important. We are all on this earth and as there is nowhere else we can live we have an obligation to protect what we have. The Minister has introduced this legislation purely as a misguided vote buying exercise. The big issues facing Australia are not the preservation of rainforests or Ayers Rock; they are the issues of soil erosion, soil preservation and salinity. Not a word has been said by the Minister about the really big issues-the life and death issues of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do something about it? I haven't heard you say anything.
—I have done so on many occasions over a 10-year period.
—I haven't seen you in the streets marching.

—The honourable senator should sit back and listen then. Nearly half of Australia's export earnings come from agriculture. Whatever one may think about the need for developing industrial capacity-and I believe in that-the fact of life is that for the next two to three decades at least the export of agricultural products will be vital to us economically. Primary production is enormously important and that is the area in which the Minister, if he has any real interest in the environment, should be directing his efforts. But we have not heard a word of that. We have never heard him say that $100m a year is being lost as a result of land degradation from primary production in Western Australia. He does not tell us that Australia is a very different continent from most of the other continents of the world. One of the characteristics of this place is that we have a very thin layer of topsoil. We do not have many areas such as the great prairies of the United States of America where there is 40 feet of topsoil or the central plains of Europe where, again, there are huge areas of topsoil. We have very little soil. We have suffered great loss through the removal of vegetation, tree removal, overgrazing and burning. Unless the problems of land degradation are arrested they will have a dramatic effect on Australia's ability to produce food, not only for export but also for our own consumption.
—So we need more trees.

—Yes, we do need more trees; that is quite right. I would be glad if the Minister started a reafforestation program. But I would be interested if he took note of farming practices which are well known and which do work and sought ways in co-operation with State governments, to have those applied so that further loss of soil does not take place from Australian farms and properties. Very few people realise how much soil can be lost in the high rainfall areas. Figures between 100 and 300 tonnes of topsoil per hectare are not uncommon in high rainfall areas on the Queensland tropical coast.
—Innisfail is a good example.

—That is correct, but we hear nothing at all from the Minister; no incentives at all from the Government. We then move to the matter of salinity. We have had an enormous land clearance program, particularly through the Murray-Darling Basin. Naturally, we have areas where saline scalding takes place. But probably our biggest problem comes from the removal of trees. Wide-scale tree removal has taken place in the Murray-Darling valley, which has allowed the water table to rise, with the consequent destruction of the pastures and the farmland above from increasing salination. We have problems also in irrigated areas. These are the big issues that face Australia from a conservation point of view. But we hear nothing-not a word-from the Government about them. Rome is burning while the Government is fiddling, trying to get a few votes from a few misinformed people.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before us is just a cynical, opportunistic move by the Government. It is a dangerous move because it is nowhere near the end of the trail. The Minister does not realise that, in dealing with people on the extreme fringes of the conservation movement, he really is riding a tiger and he cannot get off it; and that tiger will eat him. I would like to tell him what will happen in Queensland because the appetite of these people is insatiable. When this legislation goes through, the next thing that the conservation movement in Queensland-and Aila Keto, who is doing this because she realises the great ravaging of the rainforests that her parents did in their farming years and for which she is somehow trying to compensate by making us all suffer with irrational schemes-will want will be a total prohibition on logging in any natural forest in Queensland. The great majority of logs in Queensland happen to come from natural forests.

The next thing that will happen will be the conversion of Fraser Island to World Heritage listing. That has already started by changing the name from Fraser Island to Great Sandy Island; somehow or other it is felt that it has a better ecological ring if it is called Great Sandy Island. Great Sandy Island, or Fraser Island, is a place I know very well. Logging has taken place there under the auspices of the Queensland Forestry Department for well over 100 years. Just as Senator Richardson could walk into forests of north Queensland that were logged 30 years ago and say, `This is beautiful virgin forest; look at this, we cannot have foresters in here', he can also walk onto Fraser Island and say, `This is marvellous. There are beautiful stems. Mankind has never been through here'. But he would be wrong. It has been logged for over 100 years and it is a beautiful example of controlled logging and the finest professional skills of foresters. But that will be next on the list.

After the wet tropics, we will see a move for World Heritage listing of Fraser Island. then there will be a move to ban clearance of the brigalow country in central Queensland. When the brigalow movement starts, it will cut the heart out of the cattle export industry in Australia because it is based on the brigalow lands in central Queensland. After that there will be a move into the Channel country, which also will have profound implications for the cattle industry. Then it will be a move into the Gulf country, to keep the beautiful flats up there for crocodiles. At the end of the day the Government will find that agricultural production in Queensland, which is its staple production, its major economic resource, will have been cut to shreds by a number of irresponsible people. I do not even give those people the courtesy of saying that they are well meaning; they are just ignorant and emotional.

The interesting thing to me is that, although members of the Australian Labor Party are slow learners, they are at last learning. I happen to believe that the accounts that have appeared in the Press about the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) using four-letter words about Senator Richardson and his intelligence are true. I am told there are now enormous fights in Caucus as members have started to realise that the sort of nonsense that Senator Richardson goes along with has enormous implications economically for the welfare of this country. But the great revelation will come on Sunday morning, and the knives will be out in Caucus on Sunday morning when all the people in the Labor Party who have been denied their democratic rights within the Labor Party by Senator Richardson and his bully boys from headquarters suddenly find that the Richardson doctrine of buying votes has not worked. When Barrie Unsworth goes through the back door at a great rate of knots, people will be saying, `What happened to `Richo' and his environmental policies? They did not deliver the votes'. At the next Caucus meeting here in Canberra, Senator Richardson will be tarred and feathered by his colleagues.

I just want to say one thing in conclusion about this legislation. I give the people of Australia an undertaking that, when the Liberal and National parties are in government, I will move to repeal this legislation. There is no question that the argument has moved way beyond what Senator Richardson imagines the Australian public want. The Australian public want balanced environmental policies. They want intelligent management plans. They want to be able to use resources and to preserve them for their children. This is not the way to attain those goals.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly is nice to see so many smiling faces in the chamber tonight. We have heard some rather strange presentations by the Opposition. One of the strangest comments was made by Senator MacGibbon just previously, who claimed that the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) was annoyed by the actions of the dreadful Aila Keto, Bob Brown and Geoff Mosley, who had the temerity to propose these areas for World Heritage listing. In fact, the IUCN is perplexed that Australia alone amongst all the nations on earth harbours local governments which actually want to knock back World Heritage listings. Everywhere else on the face of the earth, when a local agency finally succeeds in getting the IUCN to recognise an area for World Heritage listing, there is joy and dancing in the streets; there is great pride. But here in Australia, especially in the benighted States of Queensland and Tasmania-that horrible north-south axis-the local politicians throw up all sorts of impediments--
—Threw up!

—They threw up-regurgitated perhaps-all sorts of impediments to the implementation of World Heritage listing. That is what annoys the IUCN. Actually, its members ar too gentlemanly to be annoyed; they are flabbergasted. This never happens anywhere else and they do not understand how it could happen in Australia. Frankly, I think that it does the country a great disservice for Queensland and Tasmania to act in the manner they do. It gives Australia a bad name.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the listing was a good idea. The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill is a good idea and we will support it. We were worried about some aspects of it, which I will go through in some detail later, but we will support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without amendment.

—Without amendment. Senator Puplick, the Opposition's spokesperson for the environment, sounded like a spokesperson for mining-for ripping off the resource. He sounded like the man who claims to be the Minister responsible for the environment in Queensland-the Hon. Geoff Muntz, a member of the Legislative Assembly. Senator Puplick cannot really expect anybody in Australia to take him seriously when he parrots the same line as the Queensland Minister responsible for the environment. Can anybody outside of Queensland take him seriously? Of course not. Senator Puplick said that something like 30 per cent of Australia is already locked up and cannot be--
—He said 20. Get your notes right.

—He said 20 to 30 per cent. He was a bit imprecise and I tended to take his upper number. I will take his lower number. At any rate, he said that a percentage of Australia is locked up and cannot be developed or used by developers. In fact, that was an extraordinary exaggeration. The mining companies have access to 95 per cent of this country. Under the present laws, mining companies, if they wanted to do so, could drill for oil in the middle of this chamber and there is nothing that we could do about it. Mining companies and timber companies have huge powers. We know exactly what powers they have. The Queensland Minister responsible for the environment, the Hon. Geoff Muntz, was reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . more than 75 per cent of North Queensland's rainforests had been set aside already, never to be logged. They were not disappearing or endangered, but in fact were expanding annually.

The Minister responsible for the environment in Queensland says that the rainforests are expanding annually. In a media release dated 18 December 1987 he said that the rainforests are actually expanding. That is the same line as Senator Puplick--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they do that?

—I do not know how they do it. Perhaps an honourable senator will tell us how the rainforests are actually expanding when they are being logged so heavily. The Queensland Minister, Geoff Muntz, also made some other interesting statements. He claimed that Queensland is an enlightened State when it comes to such issues. He said that if there is one State that has given the Aboriginal people their heritage and rights it is the Queensland Government. Furthermore, he said that the average Queens- landers have a right to determine their own destiny and not have their destiny determined by some other radical race or radical country across the world; that is, the international conspiracy-the IUCN. There is a degree of paranoia in Queensland, which is reflected in Tasmania, that somehow it will be controlled by a radical group of internationalists-the IUCN. I think that those States should be controlled not only by the IUCN but also by the Federal Parliament because it is obvious that neither the Queensland Government nor the Tasmanian Government is capable of administering its own territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to another of Geoff Muntz's little gems which appeared in a media release issued in Brisbane and dated 17 September 1987. It reads:
Melbourne's `Toorak blue rinse set' has been accused of placing the future of North Queensland tourism in jeopardy.

Another theme which we hear on this side of the House is that somehow the wealthy people in the cities-the Range Rover drivers-are the only people interested in the environment. What utter rubbish! The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, knows full well the political power of the environmental movement. It extends up and down the spectrum. Everyone in Australia is interested in the environment. The Opposition parties pay lip service to it and do very little about it, but everyone is interested in it. More people are becoming interested in actually doing something about it. That is the vein which Senator Richardson hopes to tap and I say, `More power to him'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell him that, for heaven's sake!

—I think that he should be told that. He is a responsible politician and he listens to the will of the people. As such, I think that he is doing a good job. Senator Puplick said that somehow the Federal Government should have sensible negotiations with the Queensland Government. I fully agree, but how can one have sensible negotiations with a government that will not negotiate? A similar situation existed with the Tasmanian Government over the dam issue. How does one have sensible negotiations with a government that will not negotiate? One cannot do so. So the Federal Government is taking the only steps it can. Senator Puplick lauded the Queensland Department of Forestry. He said that it is a wonderful thing and should be in charge of the forests. The Queensland Department of Forestry is very much like the Tasmanian Forestry Commission; that is, it is wholly a subsidiary of the timber industry. It works for the timber industry and is firmly in the pockets of the timber industry.
—That is a fact.
—Senator Richardson verifies that and says that it is a fact. That timber industry has so overcut--
—It is a slur on the character of public servants who can't even defend themselves.

—They certainly need it. The forests are so overcut that the industry is on its knees. In many areas, there is only three years of viable timber left, even if the people concerned go after all the logs. This Forestry Department which Senator Puplick said should be in charge--
—Where did you get that information from?
—From the people in Innisfail who work at the mill.
—Order! Senator Sanders should address his remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. You are an impeccably good arbiter in these affairs and we have been transgressing. The trees have been cut far beyond the sustainable yield and that is why these people have had to go into virgin areas. If they had not cut beyond the sustainable yield there would not be this cry to go into virgin stands of timber. I thought that Senator MacGibbon contradicted himself. He said that we should worry about soil erosion and look at the massive problem these tropical rainforest areas have with soil erosion. The reason there is a massive problem with soil erosion is that the trees have been cut. If we leave the trees and the natural vegetation on the land we will not have erosion. As soon as the topsoil is disturbed by removing the trees, erosion occurs. I should think that Senator MacGibbon understands that, but I do not think that he did at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats had some basic difficulties with the Bill. On our reading of it, we were afraid that it would deny access to the freedom of information (FOI) legislation. That worried us because we believe that we should have more freedom of information, not less. Certainly, the Government has not been innocent in this area. It has denied and limited freedom of information. It has made it much more expensive to apply for information and we have been worried about that. According to the interpretation which was given to us, clause 17c, which relates to information and documents collected by the inspectors, will operate in conjunction with the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and will be subject to FOI requests. Section 38 of the Freedom of Information Act deals with secrecy provisions in other Acts and allows exemptions to freedom of information. Thus, clause 17c (4) works to preserve rather than weaken freedom of information access by making it clear that section 38 of the FOI Act does not apply to information or documents collected by the inspectors. After looking at section 38, which I will not read into the record, we are satisfied that the Bill does that. We feel however that the language is awkward and that it should be cleaned up so that ordinary people, without being lawyers, can understand it. I think that all framers of legislation should be directed to make legislation understandable to people other than lawyers. This does, in fact, clear that area up. I refer now to the powers of entry and search. Much was made of the so-called limitation of civil liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My greenshirts.

—Yes, Senator Richardson's greenshirts who wish to take over the world. More power to them. There were some mutterings about entry into private homes. It is simply not permitted in the Bill under any circumstances. There is no threat of a knock on the door at midnight by an inspector who wants to come into a private home to see whether there is any cedar under the bed. This is simply not going to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to private property in general. Most World Heritage properties in Australia are almost entirely composed of crown land. There is very little private property involved. For example, in the nominated rainforests of north Queensland about 20 to 28 freehold properties make up considerably less than one per cent of the nominated area. Access to crown forest areas is controlled by the State governments. In order to check reports of, for example, logging, the Federal Government currently must gain a permit from the various State forestry departments. This is an unsatisfactory arrangement as it can give pre-warning of Federal inspection and checking of reports of damage or destruction. We had the same problem in Tasmania where, during the Franklin Dam dispute, the Australian Federal Police were not allowed to inspect what was happening on State lands. In fact, that led to the famous F111 flight because, as the Commonwealth police were not allowed to inspect the infractions of the injunction so that the F111--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't mention that; I was enjoying it up until now.

—Senator Richardson did not like the F111 flight. But it was a fact. In fact, it got so bad and so ludicrous that if the Commonwealth police who were allowed to chuff up and down the Gordon River wanted to use a phone at Warners Landing they could not do so because the Tasmanian police had been told to deny them the use of the telephone. The Federal police had to get in their boat and go clear down to Strahan, a distance of some 30 or 40 miles across water, to use a telephone. I am sure that the same thing would happen in Queensland. There has to be some mechanism to make sure that the Federal authorities can inspect what is happening in World Heritage properties because we simply cannot trust the Queensland Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What about vehicles? The searching of vehicles is necessary in determining logging operations. The Queensland wet tropical rainforest is a vast area. Logs are carried on trucks. A schedule of logging operations and their exact locations is not made public. An operation may involve only a single cutter or a group of cutters. Thus the first indication that logging is taking place in an area is often the movement of cutters and support resources into the area and the movement of timber jinkers carrying logs. As there may be no information available as to where the timber has come from or where it is going, it is important that the vehicle can be stopped and the load inspected. If the logging is being carried out under a State licence the logs will have been crown stamped and numbered. This enables the timber to be traced to both a mill operator and a sale area in the forest. Quick processing of these logs once at the mill could destroy the numbers and the Crown stamp. Therefore it is important that the search of a vehicle or place can be undertaken without a warrant, if necessary, to allow inspectors to identify and examine the log markings. There is no emergency seizure power. In effect, inspection is limited to delaying the removal of, for example, a felled tree until it is examined.
