Under the heading of `inspectors', the amendments do not seek to create a separate conservation police force. The inspectors would have powers similar to those people who operate under, for example, agricultural Acts. In fact, inspectors would probably be members of a Queensland governmental agency such as the National Parks and Wildlife Service. In the final analysis this is an enabling mechanism to allow the Federal Government to make sure that the Queensland Government or any people operating under permits from the Queensland Government are not adversely affecting a World Heritage area. These are not draconian powers. They are made necessary-it is unfortunate that they are necessary-by the previous actions of the loggers and the Queensland State Government. Such powers have a place in the Bill. What about retrospectivity? As Australian Democrats we do not like retrospectivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You heard what Senator Chipp said about retrospectivity.

—Yes. We believe that it should not be. I know that the mining companies are sending out letters saying that the Government is moving the goalpost now that the game has started. An honourable senator on this side of the chamber used the same term, so I guess such people are working closely with the mining companies in this matter. In fact, the proclamations and regulations were signed and gazetted on 19 and 20 January 1988. These were intended to prohibit commercial forestry operations. However, logging operations were then, and are now, suspended for the normal wet season close-down. They are due officially to resume on 1 April. Therefore, nothing has been affected by the legislation because, up until this point, nothing has taken place. Therefore, the Commonwealth's prohibition on logging operations has so far been prospective as there has been no logging while the regulations have been in force.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act? Part III of the proposed amendments in the Bill provides that no action taken under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act since it came into force on 22 May 1983 will apply to the Environment Protection Act. The Commonwealth has informed me and convinced me that the Environment Protection Act is irrelevant to conservation initiatives taken under a special case environmental law such as the World Heritage Act. It was never the Commonwealth's intention that actions taken under the World Heritage Act be subject to environmental protection. It would be ridiculous in the extreme to have it under environmental impact assessment legislation. If the intent of the action is to preserve an area and to put it under protection, it would be absolutely ludicrous to have an environmental impact statement prepared. It is put under protection to save it from any development which, in fact, might require an environmental impact statement. After it is listed and has received it listing, any development which might take place in the area should be under very close scrutiny in terms of environmental impact.

The Government has stated that any action which would take place in such areas which would adversely affect the environment would be under impact statement requirements if, in fact, it involved export licences, foreign investment and that sort of thing. There are circumstances in which development could take place without an environmental impact statement. This is not peculiar to this legislation or to this area but is endemic in Australia. As a former American it is something that has always bothered me. In the United States any project which has any involvement in any way either legislative or monetary with many of the States and all the Federal governments is subject to an environmental impact statement, a hearings procedure and an appeals procedure. What we really need in this country is a good national environmental policy Act. We do not have one. We have piecemeal legislation. We do not have a good national environmental policy Act and until we do we cannot truly and adequately protect our environment.

We think that the Bill to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act will help to ensure that the intent of the people of Australia is acted on. The people of Australia make the plea that the wet tropics be included in a World Heritage listing. The Government is making sure that the people of Australia get what they wish and that the rather petty, shortsighted and very greedy Queensland State Government cannot contravene the wish of the Australian people. Therefore, we commend the Government for its action in pursuing the wet tropics listing. We commend the Government's action in introducing this amendment. We will support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, which is now before the Senate, seeks to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. According to our learned Senator Richardson, the Bill is designed to clarify-I emphasise the word `clarify'-and strengthen existing legislation for the protection of World Heritage areas and is a measure of his Government's commitment to the World Heritage Convention and the conservation of the environment. I take issue with the word `clarify' because certain parts of this Bill are ambiguous and are open to different interpretations. Far from clarifying the situation, they tend to lead to certain problems. However, more seriously, upon examining the Bill a little more closely, I believe it has the potential to be a wolf in sheep's clothing. In fact, the Bill has very far-reaching implications for Australia. Regrettably, this Bill is confrontationist in its approach.
—Never.
—Furthermore, it infringes the rights of private property owners. Never?
—Never.

—I disagree. However, more importantly, it passes the final and sole responsibility for deciding World Heritage status in Australia to an external body. But this external body is not an elected group. The Bill passes this responsibility to the World Heritage Committee. In so doing, it abrogates Australia's sovereignty in these matters. Can I have the Minister's response? Never?
—Never.

—That is basically what it does. We are passing our responsibility over to an unelected group outside Australia. This Bill contains amendments to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. They clearly state that, in relation to World Heritage, that Act will no longer apply and will be taken never to have applied to any action by the Federal Government under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act or regulations under that Act. In other words, the Bill has a retroactive aspect to it. In the past some of the nominations for World Heritage status have been questioned on the grounds that the inquiries that have been conducted prior to the particular nomination being made have been quite inadequate in terms of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Often that has been a legitimate claim. I firmly believe that if this Bill comes into effect this option, which has been available to the States as a means by which they can challenge the Federal Government's decision in respect of nomination for World Heritage status, will be lost to them.

SPEECH.PARA: This amending Bill is the subject of some dispute. While Senator Richardson said that its intention is to try to clarify the issues, we have a distinguished body of legal opinion, including the opinion of the Queensland Attorney-General, that is at odds with Senator Richardson. While he is saying, on the one hand, that the Bill is intended to clarify this issue, this other body of opinion suggests a different result, because that body of opinion is that no appeal in an Australian court against any nomination by the Federal Government would be possible if this Bill comes into force. Senator Richardson says by way of interjection, `Australians will have the right of appeal before an Australian court if this Bill comes into effect'. I submit that that is contrary to what he said in one of his recent Press statements. In essence, the Bill will give the World Heritage Committee total responsibility for the determination of World Heritage nominations here in Australia. Senator Richardson is apparently, without compunction, abrogating Australia's responsibility with regard to World Heritage matters; he is bowing out. He said:
Arguments about heritage values are not something Australian courts should be asked to determine . . . the World Heritage Committee . . . is the appropriate body to be making a judgment.

That is what Senator Richardson said in his Press release of 3 March. Yet, he interrupted me by way of interjection in the Senate tonight to say that Australia's rights are not being abrogated. He cannot have it both ways. He said in his Press release that the appropriate body to determine these matters is the World Heritage Committee and not the courts. In the chamber tonight he said that Australia's rights to lodge a judicial appeal will not be affected. What are we to believe? He says that this Bill is intended to clarify this issue. It is adding to the confusion. His remarks in the Senate tonight are confusing because they are contrary to what he said in his Press statement. Where will the people of Australia stand on this issue? Where are we as senators to stand in relation to the legislation before us? Senator Richardson said in his Press statement:
Arguments about heritage values are not something Australian courts should be asked to determine . . . the World Heritage Committee . . . is the appropriate body to be making a judgment.

Again there is tremendous confusion. I suggest that in this important matter Senator Richardson appears to be a prime exponent of what my colleague Senator MacGibbon referred to as the cultural cringe. Unfortunately, this cultural cringe has really dogged Australia for too long. The question really is: Are we, as Australians, considered not to be capable of making informed decisions on matters relating to our own heritage in our own lands? Are we so incapable that we have to abrogate this responsibility and pass it over to an unelected unrepresentative group overseas? In other words, is the prime exponent of this cultural cringe saying that we do not have the capability or understanding and that we are not prepared to stand up for our own destiny, our own lands in our own home? I strongly object to such a notion.

That is really what this Bill is all about. It is about abrogating sovereignty to an outside body. It is about giving away power over our own lands to some other body because the Government believes that we are incapable of making these decisions ourselves. I contend that we are a proud nation and one capable of making these decisions. I think it is a reflection on the Australian people the Government is supposed to represent that Senator Richardson believes that they are incapable of making these decisions and that the power to do so should be handed over to an outside body.

How certain can we be, for example, that the World Heritage Committee will make the best decisions for Australia? What qualifications do its members have? They lack the proper qualifications, and I shall go into that matter later. This particular Committee consists of representatives of 21 nations. Its members are elected from the signatory countries. Its current membership includes Australia and, to name a few of the others, Algeria, Malawi and Cuba. I certainly would not say that those nations are high on the list of countries known for conservation and preservation. One need only look at some of the problems of creeping deserts and the way in which Algeria and Malawi, for example, are managing their environments. But, typically, these representatives are actually career diplomats rather than authorities on environment and heritage matters. I should imagine we would take a slightly different view if they were experts or scientists. But, no, they are so-called career diplomats from the sorts of countries that do not themselves always have the best record in environmental matters.

However, this Committee does receive advice. It receives advice from such groups as the International Centre for Conservation and the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. But I submit that, while it receives advice from these sorts of groups, the submissions from the latter organisations are characteristically brief. In fact, they are so brief as to be 1 1/2 pages long. I submit that the area we are looking at tonight-the north Queensland rainforest-would require a briefing of more than 1 1/2 pages. Unfortunately, this Committee meets in Paris for one week per year, during which time as many as 60 proposals may be considered. How can an informed opinion by non-scientists accepting briefs of up to 1 1/2 pages really look into all the ramifications of world heritage? So even with the best intentions it is possible for errors to be made in such circumstances.

I submit that, if there is any uncertainty whatsoever as to the efficacy of the decision-making process or any doubts whatsoever as to the ability of State governments to challenge nominations by Federal governments, this Bill should be rejected. I think it is a sad reflection on our system of law and appeal in this country if we are to pass this Bill with these sorts of powers. I just do not think that, in cricket parlance, it is cricket to pass this Bill if it has these sorts of powers.

Let me deal now with what I term identified property. Clause 5 of the Bill amends the definition of identified property in the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. We are told that this definition is to be expanded to include property subject to an inquiry to consider whether or not it forms part of the cultural or natural heritage and property declared by regulations to be part of the cultural and natural heritage. It brings Australia's legislation more into line with the provisions of the World Heritage Convention, but it also gives the Commonwealth considerably expanded powers under the Act to control land use practices.

It is interesting to note that Australia is the only country in the world to enact specific legislation to fulfil its responsibilities under the World Heritage Convention. If we are to be a pacesetter we are setting a pace that is far and above that which will be accepted by any other nation. I ask Senator Richardson whether he considers that the 281 properties listed for preservation outside Australia are inadequately protected.

On the question of entry and search, following this expansion of the ambit of the Federal Government's powers, clause 7 of the Bill deals principally with the appointment and powers of inspectors, despite the fact that article 6 of the World Heritage Convention states that it should be applied, `without prejudice to property rights provided by national legislation'. This Bill is a direct infringement of the rights of private property owners. Under the conditions imposed by this Bill, Senator Richardson's inspectors will have the right-I mention that they need have no special qualifications and he could send in an army of inspectors if he wanted to who could be people's neighbours-to enter, search, photograph and examine private property and vehicles at any time of the day or night, provided it is for a so-called eligible purpose. Thankfully, personal dwelling places are excluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is for a limited term.
—And that is for a limited term. In other words, there is no limitation as to the number of inspectors the Minister can appoint. He could appoint hostile neighbours, if he so wished, as inspectors.
—He could appoint the local branch of the ALP.

—That is more likely. Just imagine the local branch of the Australian Labor Party descending on a farmer's property at midnight. It would be rather frightening. So these inspectors can enter, search, photograph and examine at any time of the day or night, providing there is an eligible purpose. They have to do it for a justifiable cause, and that is not difficult to substantiate. They can determine whether any part of that property might form part of our cultural or natural heritage-that is very easy to determine as the north, south, east and west of Tasmania all contain parts of our cultural or natural heritage-or whether unlawful acts, as defined in the principal Act are being perpetrated. As my colleague Senator Puplick has said, this would be under warrant. He has referred to it as a phoney warrant because an inspector could have a warrant authorising him to enter an eligible place with such assistance and by such force as is necessary and reasonable up to one month after the issue of the warrant. He may do all these sorts of things that I have just outlined without the consent of the property owner if he believes that it is necessary to enter to prevent the concealment, the loss or the destruction of an eligible thing-it could be a hunch-or if he believes that circumstances are urgent and serious enough to justify immediate entry. There is not much hope for the poor landowner under these circumstances. We have really reached a police-type state.

SPEECH.PARA: These extensive powers are, therefore, loaded with opportunity for abuse. The protection of the rights of individuals is completely infringed. I think we are entering a rather sad stage of development in the evolution of Australia and Australian culture when we start taking these sorts of attitudes towards ordinary Australians. Australia is not yet a police state; it is not part of the Eastern bloc. I believe that it is up to every Australian and certainly every parliamentarian in this place to make sure that we do not pass legislation that will impose these inspectors-they will be called tax inspectors next-who will be given these powers which are loaded with opportunity for abuse. Surely we should be protecting the rights of individuals to overcome situations in legislation which give draconian powers loaded with opportunity for abuse. They are invasions of privacy; they are infringements of the basic right to own land and to have quiet and peaceful possession and occupation of that land.

Should the property owner seek in any way to restrict the inspectors in the exercise of a virtual carte blanche to enter his property he may be fined $1,000, imprisoned for 12 months, or both. What happens if a shooter comes on his land with a shotgun at night? He is not given 12 months imprisonment or a fine of $1,000. But if a landowner seeks to check and to question an inspector he can be thrown into prison for 12 months or fined $1,000. He is treated worse than the ordinary deer poacher in my State. He is treated worse than an illegal trespasser on land. The owner of this land is put in an inferior and onerous position. This legislation is loaded with opportunity for abuse.

As if this were not enough, inspectors are to have right of entry powers that extend beyond areas already listed on the World Heritage List and beyond those areas being nominated for listing to just about anywhere they choose outside dwelling places. Again the ramifications of this legislation are far and wide and are outside the nominated areas.

How frightening it will be if somebody has a bit of a grudge or is hostile to a particular practice of an ordinary farmer. By this legislation these inspectors could be used to invade a farmer's property at any time of the day or night. I think that this whole Bill is quite foreign to our notion of justice and fair play in this country. As such, the legislation should be thrown out.

These inspectors will have access, with minimal constraints, to all eligible places, defined in proposed section 17a (10) as, `any land, building or structure, whether or not identified property, or on identified property'. So, we must rely on the judgment and discretion of inspectors in the pursuit of this duty. I just do not think that is good enough, because these inspectors may be appointed, in any number, without qualifications, and without training. I just do not think that it is good enough for the Minister to say to us that we have to rely on the judgment and the discretion of people who might be unskilled but, who because of a political judgment, are given the opportunity to enter property at any time of the day or night. We are told that we must rely on the judgment and discretion of these inspectors, who probably would have a bias or chip on their shoulders.

However, this legislation does not specify who the inspectors will be. If the Government were sincere, I believe that the legislation would specify the qualifications required by the inspectors. The Bill does not specify what, if any, experience or training these inspectors will require. Yet the inspectors will have draconian powers to enter property at any time of the day or night and frighten people. The legislation does not specify how many inspectors there will be, how secure the system of identification will be, and to whom, other than the Minister, inspectors will be responsible.

I trust that none of the Ministers has a little shack in the bush, because at some time of the day or night he will find his property being invaded by inspectors. Any honourable senator who has ever lived in the country and had a carload of hoons arrive on the property after midnight will realise that it is a rather frightening experience to have to go out and confront them. I think that this is a pretty poor approach by this Government in giving inspectors these sorts of powers. Surely the decent thing would be for the legislation to require at least some sort of prior notice or advice of inspection.

The Bill does not specify the guidelines under which the inspectors will work. Again we are told that we must rely on the skill, judgment and discretion of these people, who have no special training and who might not necessarily have any special skills. I believe that the powers are excessive and that the safeguards are quite inadequate.

I turn to the confrontationist nature of the Bill. Environmental issues have been the subject of heated and emotional debate in recent years. The intense media cover that has surrounded the debate has meant that the issues have escaped the attention of few Australians. As a consequence there has been a polarisation of opinion within the community regarding conservation issues, and the respective points of view are held very strongly. However, this Bill does nothing to ease that situation or that polarisation. As I said, the Bill is confrontationist, and assumes barriers where none may exist.

The arrogant disregard that the Bill provides for the rights of property holders is guaranteed to create ill will in some quarters. Property owners have been cast as the villains of the piece. It is apparently now necessary to keep them under surveillance to ensure that they do not damage or destroy our cultural or natural heritage and to threaten them with heavy fines or imprisonment should they seek to protect their property. All of this, allegedly, is to ensure that we meet our obligations under the World Heritage Convention. Yet, no other country has found it necessary to legislate in such a manner in order to fulfil commitments to the conservation of world heritage.

This Bill goes well beyond the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) Convention. For example, a recent publication produced by UNESCO on the World Heritage Convention states:
A site which is protected by a World Heritage listing does not necessarily mean a cessation of economic activity; private property rights are not invaded.

However, if this Bill were to be passed in its present form, that would patently not be the case in Australia, because property rights would be invaded here. So, the Bill goes well beyond UNESCO's requirements. For many people in Australia the UNESCO requirements are considered to be far ahead of their time. What we are doing is leading the field by a mile.

The aim of the World Heritage Convention-to encourage co-operation among nations and to conserve the heritage that is recognised as being of outstanding value-is a very valuable one. However, adherence to this aim will mean that Australia must delegate the power to make the final decision regarding the significance of its own territory to other nations, to other people, to an unelected, uneducated and uninformed group essentially composed of diplomats. Further, adherence to the aim will mean that the rights of property holders over their land will be disregarded, and their rights to privacy will be so invaded that these unqualified inspectors will be able to enter at any time of the day or night. Therefore, there is good reason to question this legislation which purports to fulfil our international obligations.

I believe that Senator Richardson has no other option than to take this Bill back to the drawing board. I ask Australians to stand up and be counted. We must not surrender our sovereignty over our destiny. We must not accept this cultural cringe attitude that we are not good enough and that we do not have the capability of determining these issues for ourselves. I submit that this Bill seeks to abrogate this responsibility to an outside body that is unrepresentative of the people of this country. We are a proud nation. Let us remain so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988.
—That is the only thing you will get right.

—If this Bill is passed, and it is likely that it will be unless the Australian Democrats have some deathbed repentance, it will take the right to decide the fate of our Constitution away from the High Court of Australia and will give the final say on constitutional matters such as this to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. If I have that wrong, I invite Senator Collins to get up and say so-because he will not.
—You have got it wrong.

—I have not got it wrong; I have it dead right, and the honourable senator cannot deny that. This is a piece of blunt legislation and is nothing more than a ploy to stop any challenge by the Queensland Government to take its constitutional battle to the High Court of Australia. It is a coward's way out. The legislation allows the fate of Australia to be determined by unelected members of international organisations that do not have the same democratic requirements as this country has. The Labor Party not only has tried to bypass the State governments but also is now trying to bypass the High Court of Australia and allow some unelected bodies to decide our fate.

SPEECH.PARA: I completely concur with the previous speaker, Senator Watson. I think his contribution was one that everyone should take note of. He made a wonderful contribution, particularly when he summed up his remarks. The Commonwealth Government has removed the test under the United Nations convention as to whether an area is part of the cultural heritage or the national heritage. By taking this approach, the Commonwealth has sought to make the World Heritage Committee the final arbitrator in these matters. But it is still trying to have two bob each way. It is stated in proposed new section 3a (1) (a) (iv) that it can still claim a listing by regulation.

I do not believe there has been any time in Australia's history when the Constitution, in its 90-odd years, has been under a more severe attack. The Government is in its death throes, inflicted with Ministers resigning and waiting around for other jobs, with jobs for the boys being carried out to an art form. It is so desperate to stay in office that it is prepared to sacrifice the Australian Constitution-a book of regulations which we live by and which everyone in this country holds so dear-for a few lousy votes in the metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne.

If the Government wants more power it has the opportunity under the Constitution to ask for it. All it has to do is go to a referendum and ask the people of Australia whether they want to give more power to Canberra or whether they want a balance of power between the States and the Commonwealth, as was written into the Constitution. It is a very simple thing to do. I suspect that the answer would be very definitely no, but if the Government wants more power it should ask the people at a referendum. It should say, `We want to control more of your lives from Canberra. We believe that we can do it more effectively 3,000 or 4,000 miles from Perth and 2,000 or 3,000 miles from Cairns'. I tell the Government now that the resounding answer it will get is a definite no. The people will not give the Government more power in Canberra and it should accept that. But, no, the Government has gone to some shonky backroom deal, selling out our Constitution under an international treaty.

If this legislation is passed-and, according to Senator Sanders, it is likely to be-it will establish a special police force. I suspect that there will be Commonwealth police all over the Queensland wet tropical rainforests. They will be able to go onto private land, take pictures, make inspections and pull cars over on the road to inspect them, all without a warrant. If a landholder objects, he can be gaoled for 12 months or fined up to $1,000. Are these the type of civil liberties that the Australian Democrats support? We hear them bleating in the Senate day in and day out, saying that they demand civil liberties, yet when it comes to the acid test they fail miserably.

I ask Senator Gareth Evans whether he supports this invasion of privacy. The hypocrisy of Senator Evans never fails to amaze me. He is a great civil libertarian when it suits his own cause. No wonder the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave him nought out of 10 when he was Attorney-General. He is about as useless as an ashtray on a motor bike in his present portfolio, too. The people of western Queensland cannot even get a telephone, not to mention what he is doing to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. But I am not here to attack Senator Evans; I will do that on another occasion.

Let us go through what the Bill does. It sets up another police force with the power to fine and imprison. That measure is backed by the Democrats. The Bill declares retrospectively that no action under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act is subject to an environmental impact proposal. This is clearly an attempt retrospectively to legalise the Government's own unlawful act of not obtaining an environmental impact study before the listing. The Government is using retrospective legislation to cover up the fact that the reports it obtained and commissioned do not support World Heritage listing.

Six or seven months ago Senator Richardson said to an Estimates committee that he had spent $300,000 on consultants' reports, yet the Government is not prepared to present those reports to this Parliament. The Government required the reports to be finalised by 18 December 1987, yet in the Courier-Mail of 23 January 1988 we were told by a spokesman-not Senator Richardson; he did not want to mislead anyone-that the reports were not finalised. In the last sitting week of Parliament I asked Senator Richardson whether he would table the consultancy reports on which he had spent $300,000 of taxpayers' money. He said, `I will do it in good time'.

Here we are debating one of the most important issues to face Australia and the Constitution, and we are flying blind because Senator Richardson has not had the courage to put the $300,000 worth of reports on the table of this Parliament so that we can make an objective judgment. I maintain that the reason the Government is being forced to bring this retrospective legislation before this chamber is that it does away with the environmental impact studies. This Government is not prepared to table those consultancy reports because they will not support its argument for World Heritage listing; so it has brought down retrospective legislation to say that such studies are not required.

The Government is clearly running for cover. If it had nothing to hide, Senator Richardson would lay the environmental impact studies on the table. If he is not prepared to do that, surely one out of eight would give him some sort of positive result. But, no, he will not do it. I made an application for those studies under the Freedom of Information Act two weeks ago and I will get them in the next two weeks. If Senator Richardson is not game to put them on the table, I will. I guarantee that I will send them to UNESCO.

This Bill, if passed with the Democrats support, will retrospectively make lawful the unlawful action of seeking a World Heritage listing without having to supply an environmental impact study. It takes away the power of the High Court of Australia and vests it in the World Heritage Committee. It circumvents the trial of live issues properly before the High Court of Australia and sets up a Commonwealth police force. The action of the Commonwealth is directly engineered to undermine the case of the State of Queensland before the issues which are the subject of the current legislation have been fully aired in the High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to write your own speeches; they are better.

—I did write this speech. It is a very good one. I know that its hits right at the heart of the Australian Labor Party. This legislation is retrospectively changing a law while it is before the High Court of Australia. I want to quote what former Senator Chipp, the former Leader of the Australian Democrats, said about retrospective legislation. Unfortunately, none of the Democrats are here. Let us see what Senator Chipp, the founder of the Democrats, said about retrospective legislation. The Bill before us is retrospective legislation, whichever way you look at it. Senator Chipp said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hold the view that once retrospective legislation is regarded as the norm, once the Parliament allows it on one occasion, there is an enormous danger that governments or politicians will follow it in other directions or will similarly legislate in other areas.

I say, as do my colleagues Senator Macklin, who is not here, and Senator Haines, that once penal retrospective legislation becomes normal in our law-making we no longer live in a truly democratic society. It is as serious as that. I agree with Senator Chipp. I did not often agree with him, but I agree with him on this occasion. He also said of retrospective legislation:

Students of history will remember that Adolph Hitler used that measure with devastating effect in Germany. In 1938 he brought in a law that any meeting of Jews had to have the permission of the Prefect of Police of the district, and he dated it back to 1933. If any Jews met anywhere without a permit from the Prefect of Police they were guilty of a criminal offence. Every Jew who had been to a synagogue between 1933 and 1938 was immediately deemed to have committed a criminal offence and was put into a concentration camp. That is what retrospective legislation empowers politicians to do. While I am a member of this Parliament I will fight retrospectivity in every cause.

It is a pity Senator Chipp resigned from the Parliament, because he may have been able to give his Party a bit of backbone, which I do not believe it ever had. If Senator Chipp were here today I wonder whether the Democrats would support the statement that he made. The moment of truth is here for the Democrats. They can establish some principle and integrity in this Parliament by backing the stand on retrospectivity taken by their founder and former leader. If they turn their back on his stand on retrospectivity they will be revealed as members of an insincere party with no principles, desperately trying to stay in Parliament at any cost, trying to attract the support of a narrow political power base.

I warn Senator Macklin that if he votes for this Bill I will be out in the highways and byways of the country areas that he does get a little support from and I will tell the people what he has done. I guarantee that he will have to find another constituency if he wants to get his Senate quota. He certainly will not be getting it from the country areas of Queensland.

I have spent considerable time in this debate addressing myself to legal matters of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, the issue of State rights, the Constitution and the High Court of Australia. But when addressing this legislation we should give consideration to the families that are going to be devastated and the communities that are going to be destroyed. Between 2,000 and 3,000 jobs will be lost. I want all Labor and Democrat senators, sitting here on a minimum of $48,000 a year with a large superannuation entitlement to fall back on, to consider that they are destroying the jobs of their mates-the jobs of their fellow unionists. I hope that they feel proud about it. They are breaking their families up; they are destroying their lives; they are decimating the assets of their families, whose houses are being devalued; they are destroying the future of people who are not traditionally National Party supporters, although I would now say that they will never vote for the Labor party again as long as they live. They are working men and women. They are not members of the farming or grazing communities. They are workers; they are traditional Labor voters. They are the grassroots support that the Government has neglected. Most of them are members of the Australian Workers Union (AWU). I hope that Senator Black has the decency to get up in the Senate and apologise for the actions of the Labor Party. He has been sent here by the AWU faction to support in this Parliament AWU members and workers. I hope that he has the decency to do that. He is going to speak in this debate and I will be very pleased to listen to what he says. I am going to circulate his speech to all the workers who are losing their jobs.
I would like to read into Hansard a copy of a letter that I received from Mr Reg Lockyer. The letter, which was sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), states:
Dear Mr. Hawke,

I am one of the timber workers of Ravenshoe in North Queensland who will be soon out of a job as a result of World Heritage Listing of the Wet Tropics. You made the statement on June the fifth that no person working in the Timber Industry would be disadvantaged. I am beginning to despair of that promise being fulfilled as my time comes closer, as some of my fellow workers in the industry have received only short term and demeaning jobs, such as picking up plastic bags and bottles on the local beaches etc. and by June 1988 will find themselves not unemployed timber-workers, but unemployed council workers with no security whatsoever.

I am a family man with 10 children, in a reasonably well paid job as Logging Manager for a local sawmill, a position which I have held for the past 22 years. All told I have worked in the same industry since 1949; in Ravenshoe where I was born and where I had hoped to work for my entire life, and to live with my family and friends in the industry and place of my choice. Can you please tell me what job you have planned for me, taking into account my age, training, and background and my stated intention to live out my life in Ravenshoe. I would hope that your promise that ``No timber worker would be disadvantaged'' would take into account all that I have mentioned. I know that my comments will be noted, and that you will pass my letter to the minister responsible; Senator Graham Richardson, but like so many of my letters, to practically all of your ministers, who also passed my letters on to Senator Graham Richardson, (I'm sure that he must have a wad of them by now;) not one reply has come my way.
So I'm asking you Mr. Hawke, what job in Ravenshoe do you have for me?
Yours sincerely,
Reg Lockyer
P.S. My family co-operated with the people that you hired to do a socio-economic study. Again you promised a report on this study, but none have materialised.

That is a desperate plea from a family man from the timber areas of north Queensland who is trying to protect his family. I would suspect that that man would have voted Labor all his life. He would have put his trust in the people opposite. But they have betrayed him and sold him down the river.

Since the Labor Party decided to go ahead with the listing, this Parliament and the Australian people have been subject to a barrage of misinformation and subterfuge by Senator Richardson as he has tried to turn public opinion behind the listing. I say to Senator Richardson that he has well and truly missed the boat because, in politics, what was an issue three years ago is dead today. It is a matter of timing and the issue out there now is jobs. People are worried about their jobs. Senator Richardson has used every trick in the book to get publicity. Even last Sunday we saw a feature on Senator Richardson in the comic strip section of the Sunday Mail. One of the main points of interest in the story was that he was sent from a swimming pool for wearing obscene swimming trunks. That is the sort of story that Senator Richardson has to put out to get a bit of popularity.

Senator Richardson issued statements that the logging industry in the World Heritage area was finished. We have been subject to so much misinformation that I am going to take the remaining time that I have in this debate to point out the misrepresentations that Senator Richardson has made to the Senate. And, quite frankly, they are disgraceful. Let me deal with the first piece of misinformation that Senator Richardson gave. He said that the logging industry in the World Heritage area was finished, that thousands of jobs had already been lost and that it was only a matter of time before the industry was closed. Senator Richardson did not tell the Senate that the Queensland Government had reduced of its own volition the timber harvest from 195,000 cubic metres a year to 60,000 cubic metres a year to bring the harvest to a figure that could sustain the logging industry indefinitely. It could employ between 2,000 and 3,000 people. It was a $33m industry that could be sustained. But Senator Richardson did not say that. All we heard from him was misinformation. He said that the logging industry was finished because the number of jobs had already been reduced. That is a blatant mistruth.

On 3 March Senator Richardson made a claim that 45 per cent of the rainforest between Townsville and Cooktown had been logged. He displayed deceit in making that statement, which is quite wrong. The proposed World Heritage area is now clear for all to see.
I seek leave to incorporate a table in Hansard.
