TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This table, prepared by the Queensland Department of Forestry, clearly shows that there are 900,300 hectares of area included within the World Heritage listing and of that the proportion of rainforest logged is 143,000 hectares. Senator Richardson said that 45 per cent had been logged but he did not include 61,400 hectares in timber reserve, 120,100 hectares in national parks, 44,900 hectares in cattle grazing leases and 4,600 hectares freehold and freeholding selections. About 16 per cent of the total area of 900,300 hectares has been logged and 23 per cent of the rainforest has been logged. Senator Richardson pulls in two Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientists to give him some moral support. I feel sorry for those people because they have either been forced into being used as political pawns or have been manipulated by Senator Richardson. Either way they are wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson is responsible for further misinformation. Last week, I think it was, Senator Richardson's attempts to discredit the Queensland Government and the logging industry reached new heights. He claimed that a report made by the Northern Rainforest Management Agency (NORMA) had recommended that the rainforests should not be logged. This report that Senator Richardson quoted from in such an authoritative manner is an internal preliminary report by one scientist on the scientific committee. The report was submitted in incomplete form; it explored a method and did not expose facts. The method included a survey that had been criticised by a leading scientist, Dr Webb, on the pro-heritage side. In no way has this report been endorsed by the NORMA scientific committee. Despite this, the Minister would have us believe that this report is a definitive work supporting his claim and, on this basis, he expects the logging lobby to cave in. More misinformation and more untruths. It has gone on and on. As Senator Richardson loses the debate in his Caucus we hear many people in the Australian Labor Party, as leaks come out, saying, `For goodness sake, let's think about the people, about the workers. Let's put them in front of the bat, the possum and the snake and whatever. All these are important reptiles and creatures, but let's just put the working man and woman in front of these animals even if it is only for pragmatic reasons-those possums and trees cannot vote for us'. We find that Senator Richardson is losing his grip and as someone quite correctly said, come Sunday, when the Labor Party is defeated in New South Wales, Senator Richardson will have a bit of gloss wiped off him. Instead of being a king maker he will be one of the back room boys and people will be whispering in the corridors about him.

In the few remaining minutes that I have I want to clear up a couple of other misrepresentations that Senator Richardson has made. He claimed that the Federal Government is meeting its commitment to compensation to those people disadvantaged by the World Heritage listing. That is a laughable claim. Timber workers in north Queensland have been thrown on the unemployment scrap heap with little regard for their future or that of their families. Senator Richardson said that everyone would receive compensation. I give an example of a couple of people-an example which is quite common in the area of World Heritage listing. Jack and Linda Coleman of Ravenshoe put up their cattle property as security for a sawmill which lies 100 metres within the listing boundaries and is operated by their son John. Under the Government's compensation package mill owners such as John Coleman are not entitled to anything. His parents, who put up their property as security in good faith and in the belief that the timber industry in north Queensland had a healthy future, will now be bankrupted. Time and time again we have heard that the Queensland Government would not co-operate or negotiate. I seek leave to have a telex from the Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The telex read as follows-
NORTHERN RAINFORESTS
As new premier of Queensland, I look forward to working constructively with you on matters of mutual interest to our governments.

One matter requiring urgent attention concerns the confrontationist situation which has emerged as a result of your government's action to proceed with world heritage listing of Queensland's wet tropical rainforests. As indicated in a recent press release, I believe that this matter has been mishandled by your government and that if the current situation is not corrected, there will be serious adverse economic and social consequences.

I strongly urge that your government make no final decisions on this issue until our governments and our officials have had discussions. Once my ministry is finalised and has met, I will be in a position to suggest arrangements for progressing consideration of the rainforest issue.
M. J. AHERN, Premier of Queensland

TALK.START.PARA: —That should lay to rest the claim that the Queensland Government has not been prepared to negotiate. I asked the Premier, Mr Ahern, if he could give me an answer to that telex. He said no, it was a private matter and, to his credit, he was not prepared to give me the answer of the Prime Minister. But I suspect that it was in the negative and he said, `No. We don't want to negotiate, we've gone through with this now and we will go ahead with the World Heritage listing'. So let it never be said in the Senate again that the Queensland Government was not prepared to negotiate. It was prepared to negotiate. The Federal Labor Government washed its hands like Pontius Pilate of the whole negotiating process. It is a disgrace that we have sold out our constitutional rights; sold out our heritage and sold out our High Court. We have put in another police force and the great civil libertarians in the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have done it all retrospectively. They ought to be ashamed of themselves. They have sold out the workers and their Australian Workers Union mates. They do not deserve the support of the working men and women of this nation.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 introduced during the last fortnight's sitting by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). I am very happy to follow my colleague Senator Boswell. From his impassioned speech one can see that he is concerned, as I am, about what this Bill will do to the World Heritage listing area in far north Queensland and to the people who live there.

SPEECH.PARA: If enacted, this piece of legislation will strip Australian courts of the power to determine whether an area of our country is of world heritage value. In effect, the Bill surrenders the right of Australians to challenge planned additions to the World Heritage List. Our justice system exists, amongst other reasons, to protect citizens from the whims of government administration. Yet this Bill seeks to rob Australians of the right to challenge, in our courts, government action relating to World Heritage listing. If the Government has no qualms about negating our rights to challenge on that topic, how long will it be before we are prevented from turning to the courts for an independent assessment of other matters? I wonder where it will end. The World Heritage Committee in Paris is to make the final judgment about whether a nominated portion of Australia has world heritage value. Yet Australia has no influence over the composition of the World Heritage Committee. The Government is prepared to entrust the fate of thousands of Australians, together with huge parcels of our land, to nameless bureaucrats in Europe. Indeed, how can the Hawke Government justify selling out our nation's sovereignty?

This Bill represents a further erosion of States' rights. If it becomes law, it will be another victory for those who wish to see the complete centralisation of power in Canberra. The Bill allows the Government to exercise control over any property which has even a mere nomination pending before the World Heritage Committee or is subject to any Federal inquiry considering the potential world heritage value of the property. Then, of course, there is the system of inspectors who will gather for the Government, data on individuals and their activities. The Government assures us that these inspectors will wear photographic identity cards. They will sometimes require a judicial warrant. But the Government says that that can be obtained from a court created by the Parliament. However, I believe there is an escape clause which allows inspectors to act even without such a warrant. I believe there is no case for such an extension of Commonwealth powers. There is no justification for a bureaucracy of inspectors. It really will be another type of Commonwealth police force. It is a typical case of this Government's bulldozing State governments that are not of its political persuasion. It is trying to squash the Queensland Government's High Court challenge over the north Queensland rainforest issue by introducing this new legislation.

Speaking of the north Queensland rainforest, it was in September last year that I visited the rainforest areas of north Queensland and welcomed the opportunity to study the situation first-hand. I spent a very large part of my visit talking to the people, to the workers who understood only too well that their jobs were at stake. I spoke to the families who were frightened and confused and to the owners of small businesses who fear that the World Heritage listing will drive the timber workers from the towns, leaving them without customers and facing financial ruin. The residents of Ravenshoe, Atherton, Mareeba and several other small towns are understandably terrified at the prospect of World Heritage listing. It is clearly apparent that this Government plans to adopt its usual policy of bowing to the wishes of vocal minority groups to the detriment of other Australians. The wishes of the citizens of north Queensland timber towns count for nothing when balanced against the petulant demands of the conservation lobby groups.

Professor Harris from the James Cook University has undertaken an independent study into the effects of World Heritage listing. He predicts that 1,092 jobs would be lost as a direct result of the listing, with a total of 1,994 jobs lost eventually. Yet how many jobs does the Government propose to create in return? The answer is only 640. The timber towns face a very bleak future if the Federal bid for World Heritage listing is successful. The towns will rapidly die as the residents depart in search of alternative employment. Local businessmen deprived of customers will be forced to close their doors. Those towns are doomed to become little more than ghost towns which, of course, is the real tragedy for Australia.

In recent years many rural towns have died as the scarcity of employment and the lack of industry have driven the inhabitants to cities and major provincial towns in search of a better life for themselves and their families. However, in this case the timber industry and the timber towns have not died a natural death. Rather, they will die because the Hawke Government is so desperate to gain the conservation vote. The timber workers-men who have proudly worked in the industry for many years-are confused and angry. I listened to my colleague Senator Boswell read a letter from Mr Reg Lockyer from the area just outside Ravenshoe. I had the pleasure of meeting him when I was up there last September and I can well understand how upset he and a lot of his workers are about what is happening.

The Federal Government is in effect destroying the lives of those people. Of course, without employment, they are left with no alternative but to leave the towns in which many of them have lived all their lives. They must take their children out of school, uproot their families and begin the search for work in a new field. Of course, the vast majority have only ever worked in the timber industry, and new jobs will not be easy to find. The Federal Government has failed to present viable employment alternatives for these men.

Senator Richardson and others have suggested that tourism will replace the timber industry in terms of economic importance to the area. He claims that to a very large extent the tourism industry will absorb displaced timber workers. I find that suggestion outlandish and it could never seriously be considered as a solution to the unemployment problem. I wonder whether Senator Richardson realises that the majority of these displaced timber workers are over the age of 35. The majority have been employed in the timber industry and timber related industries for most of their working lives. They are simply not interested in, and I do not believe they could be expected to adapt to, jobs in the tourist industry. I heard Senator Boswell say how some of them have had to go down and pick up papers and various objects that have been left on the beach around Cairns. If that is working in the tourist industry, I do not think very much of it. Generally speaking, these workers are not of the type sought for employment in five-star hotels. It is quite dishonest of Senator Richardson to indicate otherwise. Resort managers are interested in attracting young people with a reasonably high standard of education who are eager and able to be trained. It is ludicrous to suggest that retrenched timber workers could be successfully transplanted into such an environment.

I understand that the Government is also in favour of establishing timber plantations in order to absorb retrenched workers. Apparently the maximum number of potential jobs that could be created would be a mere 250, with the cost of providing those jobs running into many millions of dollars. With such drawbacks, the costs of the proposal appear to outweigh the benefits rather heavily.

Senator Boswell has also referred on other occasions to an evaluation prepared by the accountancy firm Touche Ross and Co., which suggests that the Federal Government would be obliged to pay a minimum amount of $60m compensation to the timber industry alone, not to mention the compensation that would have to be paid to the other groups adversely affected by World Heritage listing such as the retrenched workers, the landlords whose property values will plummet and the small business proprietors who will be forced to close their doors as the townspeople depart in search of a new life elsewhere. The figure of $60m may well be the minimum amount which in all fairness the Government should be providing to those people whose lives will be so disrupted by the World Heritage listing. But I very much doubt the Government's willingness or ability to make a financial compensation to such an extent.

That figure of $60m has not been plucked out of the air. It has not been calculated by people who are opposed to World Heritage listing. Sixty million dollars is the figure arrived at by an independent and highly regarded firm of accountants. In effect, the Federal Government is wreaking economic damage worth more than $60m, and I for one have yet to hear that amount or anything like it promised in the form of compensation. Indeed, the $2,500 dislocation allowance being offered to the workers has often hindered rather than helped many. The reason is that apparently the recipients are being told that they are ineligible for unemployment benefit for a period because the $2,500 allowance is regarded as income earned. This Government has no qualms whatsoever about giving with one hand and taking with the other. The $2,500 allowance represents a rather meagre attempt by the Government to ease the pain and uncertainty of retrenchment and dislocation. To discount that payment against the recipients' eligibility for unemployment benefit only adds insult to injury.

One group of citizens in particular has been drastically affected by the cessation of logging. Yet, as far as the Federal Government is concerned, that group does not appear to warrant compensation. I wonder whether the Government and the Labor senators from Queensland are aware that many north Queensland citizens operate small private timber mills as a family business. Those families rely on mills as their chief source of income. I understand that the compensation regulations approved by the Government contains no provision to extend assistance to the owners of private timber mills. So the cessation of logging has resulted in a cessation of income for many families.

If the Federal Government succeeds in ruining the Queensland timber industry, I understand it is highly probable that alternative supplies of timber will need to be imported. In speaking in the Senate on 25 February last to the report of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment I said that timber had to be brought in from other countries. It is worth noting that Senator Richardson is on record as saying that we can afford to save rainforests, but he has not specified whose rainforests. Australia imports about 10 times more rainforest timber than is produced in north Queensland. I believe that it is rather hypocritical to worry about saving our rainforest and yet continue to exploit the rainforests of the Third World.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is. It is the most hypocritical government we have ever had.

—It is very hypocritical indeed. After listening to Senator Boswell's impassioned speech earlier this evening, I am sure that he will agree with what I have said. The Government's reasoning on this issue defies commonsense. On the one hand, it embarks upon huge advertising campaigns exhorting Australians to buy goods made in this country and, on the other, it sets out to destroy a viable local industry which provides an essential raw material. The Government has proceeded down this path because it has accepted, without question, the advice of ill-informed people who have so far failed to produce a shred of evidence to prove that the current logging practices are harmful to the environment. Indeed, Professor Harris, a professor of economics at James Cook University-I mentioned him earlier in my speech-compiled the first independent study of the effects of World Heritage listing on north Queensland rainforests. He maintained that the Federal Government either was misleading Australia about the impact of logging on north Queensland rainforests or intended to mislead the World Heritage Committee about the rainforests' quality. He said that the Government has claimed that the logging will destroy the integrity and heritage listing qualities of the rainforests but that it also claims that, after 100 years of logging, sometimes uncontrolled, the integrity of the forests is still maintained. One has to choose between the two arguments. They cannot both be right; one has to be invalid.

SPEECH.PARA: Logging should be permitted to continue unless the Government is able to produce clear, scientifically based evidence that it compromises long term conservation. The Federal Government has failed to prove that a controlled program of logging is in any way incompatible with conservation. It has produced no evidence to suggest that any species of rainforest flora or fauna is endangered or under threat of extinction. The Hawke Government is guilty of actively seeking to destroy this section of the industry in order to placate the environmentalists who demand that the logged areas be preserved at any cost.

Unfortunately, the environmentalists will not be asked to bear the cost of World Heritage listing. Their jobs are not at risk; their lifestyles are not threatened. They view the issue academically and make impassioned appeals on behalf of the trees. They ignore the plight of the people living in the area. What will become of them? Does the Government plan to put entire towns on the dole? That seems to be what is being done in north Queensland. The residents of the timber towns should not be condemned to rely on government handouts in the form of social welfare. They are proud, industrious people. Many have invested years of personal energy and commitment into making a life for themselves in the area and now they are being forced to stand by and see their efforts wasted and their communities disintegrated in the name of conservation.

I am not against the protection and conservation of genuinely sensitive areas, but over 80 per cent of the wet tropics are already exempt from logging. Senator Richardson and his colleagues have misrepresented the situation. They speak as though there are just a few hectares of rainforest remaining in north Queensland. In fact, the rainforests cover an area of approximately 877,000 hectares and only 156,000 hectares within the proposed World heritage boundary area are zoned for sustained-yield timber harvesting. Even within the designated area, the Queensland Department of Forestry has already shown that it is prepared to set aside from logging an adequately representative area of any section of special significance as regards flora or fauna. The rainforests are being managed effectively by the Forestry Department in conjunction with those responsible for harvesting the timber. The Federal Government is not justified in its criticism of Queensland's record of rainforest management. Successive Queensland governments have managed the area for more than 100 years and the result has been a sensible and effective balance of conservation, preservation and development.
I was interested to read in a newspaper today a statement by the Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland that the Federal Government's heritage policy is a jackboots type of policy. Mr Innes said:
The Federal Government's World Heritage nomination of northern rainforests was fraudulent . . .
That is a pretty wide and strong statement. Unfortunately, of course, it is true. The newspaper article continued:

Mr Innes released copies of the Federal Government's 30-page, December 1987 nomination form in which Canberra said most of the north Queensland rainforest area nominated for listing was in very good condition.
This was contrary to Federal Government claims that listing was necessary because the State Government could not be trusted to manage the valuable and fragile rainforests . . .
I believe that Mr Innes put the case very strongly. He is reported as saying:
Never before in any World Heritage listing in Australia has the Federal Government named the State Government without first reaching agreement with the state on the matter.
This nomination application is a fraud because the State Government has not agreed to anything. There has been no agreement, in fact, there has been virtually no consultation.
In other words, he said:
The Federal Government has used a jackboots approach.

That is putting it fairly strongly. Mr Innes is reported as saying further that the listing is a political ploy. We all know that. Of course, the States that the Federal Government are concerned about are the States of Queensland and Tasmania, neither of which has a Labor government. Of course, after this coming Saturday New South Wales will not have a Labor government either. I believe that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would agree completely with that statement. I also want to say that we have to be careful that the Federal Government does not try to put on the World Heritage List other areas in Queensland such as the Central Highlands, the Gulf Country and the Great Sandy Region, including Stradbroke, Fraser and Moreton islands. Once the Federal Government gets started on a policy of World Heritage listing, goodness only knows where it will stop.

State government foresters plan and oversee rigid logging procedures based on the principles of selective harvesting for sustained yield. This means that about eight to 12 trees per hectare are carefully selected for harvesting. No more than 4,000 hectares of the rainforest area are disturbed by logging at widely dispersed locations in any one year. That is less than half of one per cent of the area proposed for World Heritage nomination. Adequate seed trees are always retained and logged areas will not be recut for about 40 years. Only trees marked by the Department of Forestry officers may be harvested by logging contractors. That is always done in strict accordance with the approved logging plan for the area. Heavy fines are incurred by logging contractors if there is avoidable damage to unmarked trees in the harvesting process. Procedures such as these ensure the continued viability of the industry.

Senator Richardson and his colleagues claim that World Heritage listing will be a boon for north Queensland and that tourists in their thousands will flock from far and wide to admire the rainforests. I maintain that tourists have been doing just that for years without World Heritage listing. I can remember going up to the far north of Queensland about 40 years ago-I was but a little girl, of course. I can remember seeing Lake Barrine and Lake Eacham and the beautiful rainforest that surrounded them. That rainforest still surrounds them to this day. If the rainforest had been so badly treated by the Forestry Department as the Labor Government says there would not be anything left at all for World Heritage listing. Therefore, I do not believe that we need to put such areas on the World Heritage List just to get the tourists there. There is no doubt, as I said, if the forests still have the integrity for World Heritage listing after 100 years of logging, that the industry must indeed be compatible with conservation.

As far as this Bill is concerned, I believe that there is no case for the extension of Commonwealth powers or the new regime of inspectors. As I said before, it will be like another Commonwealth police force. This Government is indeed taking away State rights and undermining our Constitution. I believe that that is something we shall look at. I had a letter from a Minister from the People's Church of Esperance, who said:

Senator Richardson's bill to `prevent Australian courts hearing challenges to Government action under the World Heritage Act' is but another attack on State's rights. If decisions on heritage listings become the province of the World Heritage Committee in Paris, then Australian as a sovereign nation really no longer exists!

That letter came from someone in Western Australia. Before closing, I want to record my opposition to the legislation. Indeed, may I express the hope that when our parties return to government at the next election this legislation will be repealed.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Conservation Legislation-Bicentennial Dance Event-Liquidation of Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd-Alternative Defence Strategies

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make two remarks in my speech on the adjournment this evening. First I wish to express on behalf of the Opposition a very clear dissatisfaction with the way in which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), the Government Whip and the Australian Labor Party have dealt with the debate on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. It is gutless and shameful for them to have gone through the whole process of pulling speakers off the debating list this evening for the simple reason that they were not prepared today to enter into the debate on this significant piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition was supplied with a speakers list on this matter showing Government speakers who were to participate. Either those Government speakers have been too dilatory to have their speeches ready or they have been prepared to play ducks and drakes with the way in which this chamber is managed.

I appreciate that some Government senators will particularly want to speak when the Senate is being broadcast tomorrow. However, they will find their task a little more difficult than would otherwise have been the case, given the fact that they think they can present to the Opposition a speakers list and then at will pull their speakers off the list-in order to reschedule them for what they regard as a more convenient time tomorrow or because they are too incompetent to have their speeches ready on their legislation, programmed to suit their ends and according to their timetable, in a way which they think is of maximum advantage to them. They will find that that is an extremely short-sighted attitude if they think they can manage a political debate in that fashion. I make it quite clear that we are most concerned about being supplied by the Government with a lengthy speakers list only to find that the Government's speakers simply have been dropped off the list when it suits its convenience.

The main matter which I want to speak on tonight is something quite different. In fact, I want to talk about an activity which has taken place as part of the bicentennial celebrations in Australia this year. I believe it is one of the really great events reflecting cultural life in Australia. I refer to the premier a couple of nights ago in Melbourne of the Australian Bicentennial Dance Event, which goes by the title of Vast. This is an extraordinary production which brings together a number of Australian dance companies under the artistic direction of Graeme Murphy, the Artistic Director of the Sydney Dance Company.

This is a modern ballet which has been choreographed and directed by Graeme Murphy in association with Janet Vernon, the Associate Director of the event. It is danced to the music of Barry Conyngham, who is probably the most distinguished and exciting Australian composer at the moment, in a production designed by Andrew Carter. It brings together the Australian Dance Theatre, whose artistic director is Leigh Warren, the Queensland Ballet, whose artistic director is Harold Collins, the Sydney Dance Company, under the artistic direction of Graeme Murphy, and the West Australian Ballet, under the artistic direction of Barry Moreland. It has been put together with the assistance of Mr Peter Sarah from the Australian Bicentennial Authority, who is responsible for the Authority's arts program, and Catherine Williams, the general manager of the National Bicentennial Dance Event.

The music, which, as I said, has been composed specifically for this purpose by Barry Conyngham, was played at the opening night by the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra, the concert master being Barbara Gilby and the conductor being the distinguished Australian conductor John Hopkins. The Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra will play the Barry Conyngham score in Adelaide and in Melbourne; in Brisbane the music will be played by the Queensland Symphony Orchestra; and in Perth and in Sydney it will be played by the Western Australian Symphony Orchestra.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very fine orchestra.

—As Senator Cook says, a very fine orchestra. I shall have a little more to say about Western Australia's participation in this matter in a moment. I think it is quite exciting that dance companies from Western Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia have been brought together and that concert orchestras from Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia have been brought together. The whole production comprises the artistic work of some 69 separate Australian dancers. It is my belief that of all the current artistic undertakings in Australia, Australian dance is probably the most exciting and the one art form which most clearly, I believe, puts Australia as a world leader in a modern cultural activity. The reviews which the ballet Vast has received have been uniformly ones of praise. Helen Thomson, the dance critic of the Australian, wrote this in the 7 March edition of that newspaper:

SPEECH.PARA: Crucial to the success of the dance is Barry Conyngham's magnificent musical score, written before Murphy began the choreography and performed excitingly by the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra under the baton of John Hopkins. There appears to be a particularly solid conjunction of talent between Conyngham and Murphy, where both music and movement give the fullest significance to the imagination.

She goes on particularly to point out the dance roles of Janet Vernon, Ross Philip and Brett Roberts in a particular group called The Family which appears in each of the three scenes of the Murphy ballet which are entitled `The Sea', `The Centre' and `The Cities'. Although I think it is invidious to pick out the activities of three particular dancers in the cast of some 69 performers, I certainly agree that that praise is worthwhile. John Cargher writing in the Bulletin of 15 March was also very effusive in his praise and in his comments. I regard John Cargher as perhaps one of the most interesting and significant art, music and dance critics in Australia. He praises a number of features of the performance. He says:
The set designs by Andrew Carter are all that Sydney Nolan's never are: beautiful, if abstract, artistically flawless and, most importantly, effective as a stage picture.

He goes on to praise Kenneth Rayner's lighting and the impact of Jennifer Irwin's costumes throughout the performance. The design may be that of Andrew Carter, and it is a very great design, but it is interesting to note that in fact the Western Australians participated yet again in that the Western Australian Opera was responsible for the actual construction of the sets. Speaking of Murphy, Cargher says:

. . . his inventiveness with `vast' numbers of dancers instead of dozens produced some spectacular effects. The use of blue-draped bodies to create the waves of the ocean was good, but not particularly original, but the wonderful images of static bodies flowing into ever more beautiful friezes as man emerges from the crab-like creatures of the deep are inspired. And the final tableau is sheer genius.
That is a comment which I certainly endorse, having seen the performance. Further on in his review he says:
. . . no possible fault can be found with even one of the 69 dancers and . . . their styles do not clash . . .
He concludes his review by saying:

You could not get dancers trained by Martha Graham or Merce Cunningham or Pina Bausch to blend as these do. From basic ballet you can step up or down into any other dance form, while training in modern dance alone restricts the dancer in his or her repertoire. The lesson of VAST is that for once Australia's isolation is a positive asset. Incest in dance training has paid off handsomely in this case.

It is perhaps rare that one takes any time in the Parliament to actually try to analyse what is happening in Australian modern cultural and artistic performances. In the dance companies around Australia we have a group of young men and women-in terms of performers, choreographers, musicians, set designers, costume designers, lighting specialists and the people responsible for making the designs and bringing them to life on the stage-who are world leaders and certainly the equal of any in the dance companies that can be found anywhere around the world.

Vast has been a considerable gamble on the part of a number of people. It was a gamble on the part of the Australian Bicentennial Authority in that it was prepared to underwrite a great deal of this activity. It was a gamble on the part of Graeme Murphy who I think is outstandingly one of the great artists in Australia today. It was a gamble on the part of the dance companies in South Australia, Queensland, Sydney and Western Australia. It was a gamble on the part of the symphony orchestras in Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia to try to put together something which had never been done before, and that is to amalgamate four quite different and quite separate companies and to try to bring them together in a celebration of Australian dance, an event which took place initially at the Palais Theatre in St Kilda and which will tour around most of the States of Australia, including performances in the Australian Capital Territory. The bringing together of many choreographers, of many people involved in the artistic side, the design side, the lighting side and, above all, perhaps the musical side is a great and exciting adventure. Vast has been a spectacular success in terms of the celebration of modern art and modern art forms in Australia.

I wanted to take this opportunity in the Senate quite simply to place on record, both as somebody who is particularly interested in Australian dance and also as the shadow Minister responsible for the arts, words of praise and commendation for the hundreds of people involved and the thousands of hours which must have gone into bringing this spectacular event together in the one place and with such outstanding success. I think all too often we as Australians fail to acknowledge the success of our artists unless somehow they are seen overseas and praised overseas. We do not tend to praise our own people performing in our own country to our own audiences to anywhere near the extent that we should. I think those people who have been involved in the creation, the performance and, indeed, the organisation of this vast and spectacular event deserve to be recognised and accorded the highest praise by people.

I hope that many honourable senators who have the opportunity to see this performance will take the chance presented to them, for they will see in Australia something which is the equivalent of anything they would see anywhere in the world. I think it will very much encourage their pride and their respect for the artistic abilities which are inherent in a large number of people in Australia and which deserve far greater public recognition than is usually accorded them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unions are forever attacked for having too much power. Critics claim they abuse it to the harm of employers, workers and the community generally. They are pictured as overprivileged groups taking from society much more than they give to it. Opponents call for the greater use of law against them. Those disputing the need for unions say that the bad old days when management exploited the labour force have long since passed. The law now gives workers ample protection against oppression. Employees are better served by bargaining directly with their employers than by relying on unions to negotiate at industry level. Capital is different from the past, understands the needs of labour and is solicitous of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Events surrounding the liquidation of the Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd in Melbourne in February 1988 show how wrong this way of thinking is. Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd went into voluntary liquidation on 29 February 1988. It peremptorily dismissed its workers the same day. It gave them their weekly take-home pay, but not the amount owing for rostered days off, sick leave and accrued holiday pay with a 17.5 per cent loading. This amounts to $248,920. It owes its employees $6,861 taken from their wages for superannuation. These sums are listed in its report as to affairs. Amounts owed to individual workers include figures such as $5,640.65, $4,365, $4,187.72, $4,159.64. A big proportion of the amounts owed falls between $2,000 and $4,000.

Well over 100 men are involved. Among them are people with mortgages to meet, with periodic payments to make, with families to feed, house and educate. All have a living standard to maintain. They are hardworking men anxious to ply their trade. Without warning they have been left jobless. Money rightfully theirs has been denied them. They are left facing the dole and debt. The workers were outraged by what was done to them. They had been killing stock that day. They ran whatever carcasses were awaiting dressing on the chain into chillers. This was to preserve them. They then set up a picket. Nothing was to go into or out of the abattoirs until they were paid what was due to them.

The workers were employed by Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd. They had to look to it for their wages. However, the animals that that company had them kill belonged to others. Those other companies were not going to pay those who had processed their stock but they were going to obtain possession of it from them. Metro Meat Ltd, Helvistan Consolidated (Victoria) Pty Ltd and Mohrs Refrigerated Transport Pty Ltd were three companies using the premises of Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd on the 29 February 1988. They reacted quickly to the situation. On 1 March 1988 Metro Meats wrote a letter to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Wally Curran,
Secretary,
A.M.I.E.U.
62 Lygon Street,
CARLTON. 3053.
Dear Wally,
Re: Industrial Dispute-Oakleigh Abattoirs
Please be advised, Metro Meat Limited, (Mayfair) currently contract kill pigs at the above Abattoir.
Yesterday, 29th February, 1988, Oakleigh Abattoirs went into Liquidation. As a result of this the A.M.I.E.U. employees of the Abattoir, were terminated.
Metro Meat Limited (Mayfair) has a substantial amount of stock in Chillers at Oakleigh Abattoirs, some of which was killed on Friday 19th February, 1988, which is deteriorating rapidly.
There are also 375 pigs, killed Monday 29th February, 1988, which will have to be moved out urgently to avoid spoiling of product.
In addition to the above there are approximately 30 live pigs on the premises that are losing condition and will need to be killed in the very near future to save the product.

As Metro Meat Limited are not involved in the dispute between the A.M.I.E.U. and Oakleigh Abattoirs, I am seeking your intervention to allow Metro Meat Limited, to cross the picket line that has been set up by A.M.I.E.U. members to remove all of our stock from the premises of Oakleigh Abattoirs, before further deterioration occurs.
Should you wish to contact me I will be available by telephoning our Dandenong Office on 792 0504.
Yours sincerely,
Mike Gallagher
(Manager, Domestic Meat)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March Cooper Korbl & Co., solicitors acting on behalf of the three companies, wrote two letters to the union. I seek leave to incorporate those two letters in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
March 2, 1988
BY HAND
The Secretary,
Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union,
62 Lygon Street,
Carlton.
Dear Sir,
RE: OAKLEIGH ABATTOIRS

We act on behalf of Metro Meat Ltd, which carries on its business under the name or style `Mayfair Fresh Pork' from premises situated, inter alia, at the Oakleigh Abattoirs in North Road, Huntingdale.
As you are aware the Oakleigh Abattoirs are conducted by a company named Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd. That company provides a killing and processing service for our clients' pigs.
At present our client has the following property to which it is entitled to immediate delivery at the Oakleigh Abattoirs premises:
(a) 375 pig carcasses situated in the chiller; and
(b) 30 live pigs.

This property is extremely valuable. The carcasses have an extremely short shelf life. By Friday of this week they will be commercially worthless. In the meantime the property continue to lose value as a result of processes of gradual deterioration. Further the carcasses have been sold under the terms of agreements which required delivery to have been made earlier this week.

Your Union currently has a picket line outside the abattoirs. The effect of this picket line is to prevent any property, including our clients property, from leaving the premises. Your Union has physically prevented our clients attempts to remove its property from the premises and has caused them to suffer substantial losses already. These losses will escalate as the hours pass.
All of this is well known to you and was the subject of a letter to you from our client yesterday, a copy of which is attached.

Whatever dispute your Union may have with the proprietor of the Oakleigh Abattoirs is irrelevant to the position in which our clients presently find themselves. The actions of your Union are causing serious loss and damage and unless those actions cease immediately our clients will have no alternative but to obtain appropriate relief by way of injunction from either the Supreme Court or the Federal Court together with an associated claim for damages. In this connection we would refer you to the judgment of Murphy J. in Dollar Sweets Pty Ltd v. The Federated Confectioners Association of Australia (1986) V.R. 383.

Unless we receive your undertaking by 2.15 this afternoon we propose to make an application to the Court for appropriate protective orders. If your Union wishes to be heard in opposition to the grant of any such injunctions then this letter serves as notice of our clients' intentions to make application this afternoon.
Yours faithfully,
March 2, 1988
The Secretary,
Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union
62 Lygon Street,
CARLTON.
Dear Sir,
RE: OAKLEIGH ABATTOIRS

We act on behalf of Helvistan Consolidated (Vic.) Pty Ltd and Mohrs Refrigerated Transport Pty Ltd. Helvistan carries on its business under the name or style ``Mohrs Meat'' from premises situated, inter alia, at the Oakleigh Abattoirs in North Road, Huntingdale. Mohrs Refrigerated Transport Pty Ltd is the owner of, inter alia, meat vans which are used in conjunction with the business of Mohrs Meat.
As you are aware the Oakleigh Abattoirs are conducted by a company named Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd. That company provides a killing and processing service for our clients' cattle.
At present our client, Mohrs Meat, has the following property to which it is entitled to immediate delivery at the Oakleigh Abattoirs premises:
(a) 281 carcasses of beef situated in the chiller;
(b) 33 live cattle; and
(c) 280 hides.

The hides are worth some $20,000. Furthermore the carcasses of beef and the hides have an extremely short shelf life. By Friday of this week they will be commercially worthless. In the meantime the property continues to lose value as a result of processes of gradual deterioration. Both the meat and the hides have been sold under the terms of agreements which required delivery to have been made earlier this week.

Your Union currently has a picket line outside the abattoirs. The effect of this picket line is to prevent any property, including our clients property, from leaving the premises. Your Union has physically prevented our clients attempts to remove its property from the premises and has caused them to suffer substantial losses already. These losses will escalate as the hours pass.
So far as Mohrs Refrigerated Transport Pty Ltd is concerned it has four meat vans presently located on the premises. The actions of your Union have prevented those trucks from leaving the premises.

Whatever dispute your Union may have with the proprietor of the Oakleigh Abattoirs is irrelevant to the position in which our clients presently find themselves. The actions of your Union are causing serious loss and damage and unless those actions cease immediately our clients will have no alternative but to obtain appropriate relief by way of injunction from either the Supreme Court or the Federal Court together with an associated claim for damages. In this connection we would refer you to the judgment of Murphy J. in Dollar Sweets Pty Ltd v. The Federated Confectioners Association of Australia (1986) V.R. 383.

Unless we receive your undertaking by 2.15 this afternoon we propose to make an application to the Court for appropriate protective orders. If your Union wishes to be heard in opposition to the grant of any such injunctions then this letter serves as notice of our clients' intentions to make application this afternoon.
Yours faithfully,

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The threat of legal action contained in the solicitors' letters had great substance. The law did allow the companies to seek rapid relief by way of injunction. It did afford them an action for damages. The picket line was lifted. Rapid relief afforded the companies by the law is not available to the workers. They will wait a lengthy time for payment of such part of their entitlement as is ultimately paid to them. In the meantime they must meet their commitments as best they can.

SPEECH.PARA: None of the letters reflect any sympathy for the workers deprived of money and jobs. What wrongs they have suffered is not of concern to those whose stock they had processed. If they are beggared so be it. It is natural for the clients of Cooper Korbl & Co. to be concerned about their stock. However, the tone of the letters does nothing to justify the workers' faith in those who benefited from their labour. True, they were not employed by those companies, but they had slaughtered and dressed and chilled their beasts for sale. Surely that deserves some recognition.

The voluntary winding up of Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd on 29 February 1988 demonstrates some unhappy truths. The workers were treated by various companies in a way which does nothing to dispel the belief that, but for unions and the legislation they have encouraged over the years, employees would still work under nineteenth century conditions. The law provides more rapid relief for companies denied their goods than for workers denied their wages. Unions are much confined by the law. Their ability to take industrial action within the law is non-existent. Capital is still capable of apathy in the face of labour's distress. Unity of labour is the hope of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak about the need for a debate in this country on alternative security, alternative defence. One characteristic of the defence debate since the release of the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the White Paper has been the renewal of threat perceptions in the minds of the Australian public either for political reasons or to boost defence wish list thinking. Perhaps it is also to get more money for the defence forces and to improve the readiness of the armed forces-a thing which has preoccupied Opposition speakers on this subject for the last year or so and also various journalists representing the same interest. The practice has been either to play on Soviet intentions in the Pacific since the fishing agreement with Kiribati there and then Mikhail Gorbachev's speech in Vladivostok in July 1986 or to stress the implications of the Fiji coup last year in terms of the alleged unreadiness of the Australian Defence Force to intervene should that have been required.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently there was an alarmist feature article in the Australian by Peter Young-on 29 February-entitled, `Invasion. How we lost to 250'. This was a worst case scenario exercise in which Australia was attacked by forces from a Muslim country called Missouria which resulted in the capture of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The article ended:

Only a worse case scenario perhaps, but it is the stuff around which most of Australia's defence exercises are played out, except that we always win against an obliging enemy who limits his actions to the comforting credible threats that our forces have been scaled down to meet.

The only thing that the article did not explain was why anyone would want to capture the Cocos Islands and in fact what would be done with them once they were captured. White Australians have been fed threat scenarios for 200 years. It started with fortifications in our harbours to keep out the French and the Russians in the nineteenth century. Later we worried about the yellow peril to the north. Now we rate Indonesia and the Soviet Union as the greatest threats according to the most recent threat poll carried out by the Australian on 6 November 1987. The same poll recorded that almost two-thirds of Australians believe that our defence forces are inadequate to defend national interests. This is an apparent increase of 7 per cent in voter dissatisfaction since the defence White Paper was released in March last year. However, a Government-Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd poll in January this year indicated that only 53 per cent of people surveyed still believed that Australia could not defend itself effectively, a fact which apparently disappointed the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who said that although it showed that the defence debate had changed significantly since the 1960s and early 1970s he was disappointed that 53 per cent of Australians still believed that Australia was unable to defend itself.

Having taken little interest in defence issues for many years some politicians are more inclined simply to rattle on about the Soviet threat as if nothing had changed since the Menzies years and to play on our ignorance of the Pacific by pretending the Soviets are on our doorstep when in fact they are largely confined to the far north-west of the Pacific with only Cam Ranh Bay as a forward base between Vladivostok and the Red Sea. The United States Navy still refers to the Pacific as an American lake and has always used ANZUS to pursue a strategy of denial with regard to the Soviet Union. The islands of the South Pacific are strongly pro-Western and Christian with little interest in close ties to the Soviet Union, let alone the economic model there, while the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations are positively hostile to the Soviet Union. Soviet standing in Asia has been a disaster for over 20 years since it lost influence in China and Indonesia, got embroiled in Afghanistan and discredited itself in South East Asia by supporting the old warriors in Vietnam after 1975.

As for communism, Australia had far more reason to be hysterical 20 or 30 years ago when we were fed the domino theory about insurgencies in Malaysia or the war in Vietnam, even if the problem there was nationalism, not the spread of communism masterminded by the Kremlin. The sooner we start drumming up the spectre of the Cold War and put our minds to the current realities of power in the region, the sooner we can address ourselves to the real issues of security and defence which we usually manage to avoid. The problem is that none of these traditional approaches to Australia's security takes account of three other vital factors-threat perceptions, the nature of modern war, alternative approaches to international conflict resolution.

Since the last invasion of Australia in 1788 the new arrivals have always been terrified that someone else would come and take the land that they had already taken from the Aboriginal people. This fear led to the notion of forward defence; that is, in order to have a great and powerful friend to protect us, Australians would have to go and fight their allies' enemies anywhere else in the world. That is why Australians have fought in the Sudan, the Boer War, the Boxer Rebellion, and under the British flag in the Middle East, North Africa and Europe. When Singapore fell in 1942 we turned to the United States, and fought in Korea and Vietnam.

It was not until 1952 that we learned that the Japanese had come and checked out Australia in 1942 by going as far as Sydney Harbour in their submarines, and bombing Darwin, Broome and Port Hedland, but had decided that Australia was too difficult to invade. They had to turn away because they were obviously preoccupied with their war effort elsewhere. The myth has been perpetuated, however, that without the United States we would have been occupied by Imperial Japan. However, the Japanese war records show that that was not the case.

In the post-Vietnam era we have the doctrine of self-reliance. Unfortunately, it is not true self-reliance because we are still part of a military alliance or, rather, a nuclear alliance-and a potentially offensive one at that. However, in 1951 when the ANZUS Treaty was signed, it was never intended to be a nuclear alliance. However, that is what it has become by stealth and by a whole range of secret agreements.

The Government admits that there is no perceivable threat to Australia-and that there has not been for many years. Indeed, in 1986 a retired air marshal observed that if there were not a threat to Australia's defence Australians would invent one. He actually used the term `an invasion paranoia'. That was from someone in a military establishment.

The Australian defence forces operate in a vacuum, precisely because there is no threat. As Paul Dibb noted in his review, `Australia is one of the most secure countries in the world'. Later he commented:
Australia thus faces no identifiable direct military threat and there is every prospect that our favourable security circumstances will continue.
He also observed:
Part of the difficulty of defining national security interests rests in the fact that we face no identifiable threat or prospect of threat to focus our concerns.

Most wars break out because of threat perceptions. There is a conflict situation and the two sides arm, with both suspecting the other of malevolent intentions. Many military thinkers and many older people still live with the memory of the Second World War, while Air Force strategists have made a great song and dance about air power since the Israeli attack on Egypt in June 1967. What they ignore is that the nature of modern warfare has changed in the last 40 years and that the June war scenario bears no relevance to the Australian situation.

Before 1945 most wars were fought in what we call the First World. Countries declared war and invaded another country. There have been about 150 wars fought since 1945, and almost all of them have been in Africa, Asia and Latin America. Few wars are now declared, and many drag on for years, like the forgotten wars of Africa-Eritrea since 1962, or Namibia since 1966. Only 15 per cent of wars since 1945 have been conventional, with the armies of two or more countries fighting each other across borders after having declared war. The other 85 per cent have involved the attempted overthrow of colonial governments, or have come about from tribal, religious or ethnic reasons, frequently of an internal nature. Indeed, as a Singapore commentator, Sinathamby Rajaratnam, once put it, `the Third World War is a cumulation of little wars rather than one big one'. He said:

Though the form is new, it is basically a war between the great powers and one fought for the realisation of their ambitions and the promotion of their national interests. However, this is not obvious because in this new world war, the great powers are invisible.

These long, drawn-out conflicts can be largely attributed to the fortunes of the international arms trade and the tendency of guerilla warfare outside the colonial environment to be a failure because it lacks an effective end game. Australia is one of the players because we too want our share of the arms trade cake. The Cooksey report, which we have never discussed in this chamber, recommended that Australia double its defence exports-the justification being that we sell very little compared with the big players in the arms bazaar. Such an argument holds little water when all other countries take this line-and who can blame them when the arms trade is now reputed to be the world's second largest trading concern? As the percentage controlled by the United States and the Soviet Union declines, more countries enter the game, Singapore and Indonesia in our own region, or countries such as Brazil, South Korea and particularly China in the last year.

Given this situation, it would obviously make more sense if Australia were not only to disentangle itself from bloc thinking and stand on its own two feet, but also to take advantage of its own unique geostrategic position and adopt a posture of defensive defence. If wars often start because of threat perceptions, then countries wishing to reduce threat levels in the world can do so by going for a non-offensive defence strategy, rather like Switzerland, Yugoslavia and Albania.

In modern warfare the advantage lies with the defence, around a ratio of 3:1. A country can spend millions of dollars on a new warship but it might get sunk by an Exocet. It can order powerful new tanks but they might be destroyed by the latest anti-tank weapons. New planes cost millions to buy but can be shot down by missiles. If countries would put the emphasis on defensive equipment they would feel more secure, while not threatening their neighbours.

On the other hand, suppose we were to indulge the defence wish list of some members of the Opposition and their friends in the military. Australia would spend several billion dollars on an aircraft carrier or a few nuclear submarines. What would our neighbours think or, more importantly, what would they do? Recently we have had the spectacle of India, with a couple of aircraft carriers and a nuclear submarine, likely to get another carrier and six more nuclear submarines. Voices are immediately raised by Indian Ocean neighbours like Australia and Indonesia which want similar weapons even though it is conceded that India is not a threat. India justifies the build-up of its navy because of conflict with China and Pakistan-although it is hard to see why a naval build-up is necessary, and so it goes on. Soon we shall hear mutterings about Japan as it forges ahead with the expansion of its armed forces which, because of its peace constitution, are not officially armed forces. They are allegedly self-defence forces, even if Japan now has the ninth largest defence budget in the world, and before long at the present rate will have the third largest defence budget-even keeping within its constitutional allowance of one per cent of its total budget.

If we want to pre-empt conflict situations, we need to promote regional security and understanding. Security in the Asia-Pacific region means economic security for most of the people in the area. The more their governments spend on arms, the less there is for health, education, housing, water, energy and employment. If Australia wants regional security it should spend more on economic aid instead of military aid to our neighbours and do more to promote regional understanding by getting Australians over their cultural hang-up about being an extension of Europe or North America. Instead, we should consider ourselves as part of the Asia-Pacific region. Our overseas aid is now running at 0.36 per cent of the GDP or half what we used to aim for, the figure set by the United Nations many years ago. Australia is getting lower and lower on the list of contributing countries, and is nearer to the mean list, rather than the list of countries that show some social responsibility. We claim to be economically in a mess but we still rate as the eighth wealthiest country in the world-and certainly we are wealthy compared with our neighbours.

As we know only too well, the more we spend on weapons, the more insecure we feel. We need a much wider definition of security, one that goes far beyond the purchase of military hardware or toys for the boys. Australia took an active part in the disarmament and development conference in New York last year but we have to translate those perceptions into the Australian consciousness and the reality into funding allocations.

The third area we ignore concerns means other than resorting to war for resolving conflicts. We must focus on non-violent conflict resolution. The scenarios always seem to skip over this stage and there is a tendency to jeer at the idea of strengthening international institutions like the World Court or the United Nations (UN). I have referred before to the fact that in 1985 Australia spent only $21,400 on training diplomats in negotiating skills but, as with business, if we could put far more energy into training personnel in negotiating and language skills, it would help a great deal in the long run and would have far reaching ramifications. If we can spend $1 to $2m training one air force pilot, we should be able to spend far more on training our diplomats at a pre-emptive conflict resolution level. We also need to do more to promote cultural understanding in the region, as one of the reasons for the fear in this country is our lack of understanding of our neighbours. That is why I have criticised the merciless budget cuts applied to Radio Australia, which has done so much to promote an understanding of Australia in the Asia-Pacific region. Steps such as promoting Radio Australia are just as valuable as buying military hardware or training defence personnel. In fact, they are probably worth a lot more.

Little attention is paid in the community to developing conflict resolution skills beyond the family, neighbourhood or corporate level. Children are taught that wars resolve international conflicts when, in fact, they rarely do. We do not learn about the Sweden-Finland war of 1919 over the Aland Islands or the more recent Argentina-Chile war over the islands in the Beagle Channel off Cape Horn, because they never happened. Both disputes were resolved by negotiation and arbitration-one through the World Court and the other through the services of a third party. In the case of the Argentine-Chile conflict, it was the Pope who came in as a mediator.

We take our legal disputes to court to avoid open warfare, so to speak, but we ignore the mechanisms that exist at the international level. It is time we paid much more attention to them. These mechanisms need to be better known and strengthened. The defence forces have given occasional support to international peacekeeping exercises but, if we are to maintain them, I feel we could offer them much more training in peacekeeping, as other nations do, before sending them to Cyprus, the Middle East or wherever the UN has a role. If we do not train them we will end up with a situation like that of Israel today, where troops trained to fight cannot respond to the unrest in Gaza and on the West Bank because no one has taught them how to respond to that kind of agitation other than by shooting and bashing people up. The same goes for the British in Northern Ireland. They have not been taught anything about non-violent resistance. That would be a great help to all of the parties concerned.

I note that the 1981 Katter report, Threats to Australia's Security: Their nature and probability, recommended a future inquiry into the diplomatic and other non-military means of avoiding deterioration of Australia's relations with any country to such a level that the country sought to address its grievances by armed force. Perhaps our media, where they bother to employ defence specialists, could consider these possible scenarios before rushing straight into worst case scenarios of terrorism on Australian soil. We need to consider the causes of war in the last part of the twentieth century and ways in which we can avoid war as a result.

Economic insecurity is an obvious problem. The continuation of colonialism is another, as we can see so readily in New Caledonia. Post-colonial conflicts to our north would include East Timor and West Papua. Australia could offer its services if we had sufficiently trained personnel to help resolve other regional conflicts if the opportunity were to present itself. Examples might include Burma, Sri Lanka or Indo-China as well as continuing the offer of personnel for a UN force in Namibia when South Africa finally accepts the verdict of history and accepts United Nations Resolution 435. I hope that in future when we discuss defence debates, instead of emotional cold war sabre rattling and claptrap about Libyans in the Pacific or scenarios about Soviet threats to Australia via Cam Ranh Bay and deliberate misrepresentations about the whereabouts and nature of the Soviet forces in the Pacific, we shall hear more reflection on these other areas pertaining to security and conflict resolution. This is why my office has arranged a series of seminars around Australia which we have called `Just Defence' or defence which is just, meaning defence of defence, so that we can raise community interest in these issues and one day extend them to the military, as has been done in Europe and North America.

Having just participated in a tour of northern defence establishments by a sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, it is very clear that what we can aspire to in defence of our own shores is good intelligence gathering and surveillance operations. Obviously we need to be aware of what is going on in our region. Therefore, we need lots of patrol boats, for example, so that we can check on movements in our coastal areas and move against illegal fishing vessels and, more importantly, drug runners. For the same reasons, we need air patrols. I cannot see why the Royal Australian Air Force is not doing this work instead of the Government paying private contractors to do our defence coastwatch. Could it be that our own Air Force is tailored to meet the strategic needs of our ally rather than to suit our own local security needs?

Frequently the defence sub-committee was told how difficult a particular area of Australia's top end would be to defend, but it needs to be pointed out every time that the same area would be much more difficult to attack. Successful invasion of Australia would be extremely difficult. We need to be wary of low and medium level harassments and be prepared to deal with them by negotiation rather than through force. But I believe that the purchase of long-range fighter bombers, with mid-air refuelling for example, is inconsistent with our real security needs and is a misspending of the defence dollar. As I said earlier, I believe that security needs in our region can be much better met by being actively good neighbours-that is, peacemakers rather than potential warmongers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had been my intention to sit out the adjournment debate in my office. I started to do so, but in listening to the debate I heard a contribution by Senator Puplick in which he made some remarks about Government senators not speaking on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, which was before the Parliament this evening. I came into the chamber and invited Senator Puplick to remind the Senate that I had spoken for the Government, but he declined to do so or did not hear me. I just wish to inform the Senate that I did speak for the Government. I followed Senator Puplick. Perhaps Senator Puplick was so pleased with his own speech that he did not realise that I followed him. I spoke before and after the dinner break. I think that any further remarks on whether Government senators were due to speak or did not speak should be left to the Whips and the managers and I shall do that, but I advise the Senate that I did speak on that legislation.

—I want to pass some remarks in relation to the comments made by Senator Puplick about the speakers list. He made certain claims which I say are incorrect. That is my first point. Secondly, if Senator Puplick has some complaint with the arrangements made about the speakers list I would have thought that he would have had enough confidence in his own Whip to take the matter up with the Whip who represents the Opposition side of this House. If there is any complaint from the Whip on the other side, we will certainly discuss it at the Whips meeting in the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to make one or two remarks in closing for the Government in view of the observations made in the adjournment debate by the three speakers who spent the longest time on their feet. I think for someone who is married to a former ballet dancer, the remarks Senator Puplick made about Vast, the Graeme Murphy inspired ballet spectacular financed by the Australian Bicentennial Authority, invite some cross chamber approval and agreement. Certainly, I think the oratorical pas de deux of Senator Puplick in praise of Vast is justified. I have not as yet had a chance to view it, but it is on my social calendar and I have read the reviews.

SPEECH.PARA: However, what was otherwise a very generous and useful contribution was spoilt, I believe, by the somewhat petty and vindictive intrusion at the beginning of Senator Puplick's contribution when he reflected on the contribution of the Whips of this chamber. It is true that the Whips have a practical day to day job of making this chamber work. They are the wheels that grease the debate in here. No party in this chamber has a mortgage on asserting that it is never guilty of using the forms of this chamber best to present its views, and Senator Puplick's remarks that the Government is playing ducks and drakes on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 I think are not justified. Tomorrow we will see, given the notice of motion that Senator Chaney gave today at the beginning of proceedings, that ducks and drakes will be played in this chamber by the Opposition. That will be designed to accord specifically with the fact that the proceedings of the Senate are broadcast on that day.

Senator Cooney made some remarks about Oakleigh Abattoirs Pty Ltd, which went into voluntary liquidation. I sympathise with his remarks and observations. I have, like Senator Cooney, been witness on many occasions to a company going into liquidation and all the creditors gathering when the employees of that company are the ones who suffer destitution or loss of earnings in a real way, which cripples them. Senator Cooney's comment that all creditors are treated equally is true. One does not diminish the financial blow to companies where they are creditors and a business that owes them money has gone bankrupt or into liquidation. It is a significant blow to those companies. Usually one finds that company creditors have other business activities and are able to survive in some form or other. But employees have an exclusive dependency upon a liquidated or bankrupt company which they are not able to lay off in terms of other business and the damage done to them individually is quite extensive. Senator Cooney's concluding remarks that this once again vindicates the need for unions in Australia to protect just this sort of thing is, I think, valid.

Senator Vallentine maintained her speaking quota tonight by giving us 25 minutes of her views on what she started out to call regional security but which, of course, were her views on defence. It turns out that she is holding a series of seminars around Australia and I wish her well in that respect. However, I do not think I can allow tonight's contribution to pass without the observation that Kim Beazley, the Minister for Defence in this Government, has done more for causing an informed, literate and intelligent debate on defence in this country than almost any other Minister since Federation. The doctrine of self-reliance that he has propounded is now spread widely throughout the community. He has created a climate in which Senator Vallentine is able to make here expressions of opinion. If it had not been for the pioneering trailblazing initiatives by Kim Beazley, the Labor Minister for Defence, we would not have had a situation in which Senator Vallentine may have even been considered for election let alone able to make her observations.

I think one of the things that have to be answered is her claim that the Government admits there is no threat. I do not think that is true. It is not a situation in which Beazley and this Government have been screwed down and forced to come clean about a fact that they are trying to conceal. That is not the context in which the no threat scenario has been propounded. What has happened is that, in setting down a logical list of strategic interests, the non-existence of an immediate threat has been identified. Our strategic concerns have been developed with that in mind, along with a series of other considerations. I think that is something that Senator Vallentine ought to take into consideration. I notice that, other than a series of rhetorical flourishes, she has not called upon this Government to follow a specific program. I do not think any further remarks are necessary from me in that regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.13 p.m.
