QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of money in view of a statement by the Premier of Queensland, Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen that Brisbane will boast the world's largest building through the activities of an Australian-Korean consortium before the end of 1990 for the project is expected to come from overseas sources.
(2) Do the financial arrangements for the building come within the Australian Government's foreign investment guidelines.
(3) Who are the directors of Mainsel Investments.
(4) Who are the directors of Youngchange Constructions.

(5) In view of the fact that further office space is scheduled for the building, what effect will this further proliferation have in the already overdeveloped office market area on: (a) the building industry, and small contractors already engaged on office building enterprises suspect in their viability; and (b) small business in the retail and commercial areas already located in the Central Brisbane shopping district.

(6) In view of fears expressed by environmentalists that the building will cause huge shadows to be cast over much of central Brisbane for much of each and every day, what powers are enjoyed by the Commonwealth to monitor and control such major schemes in capital cities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As there are no specific foreign investment policy guidelines relating to the source of funding for foreign investment proposals, information on the funding of the proposal was not sought by Foreign Investment Review Board officials from the consortium.
(2) Financial arrangements relating to foreign investment proposals are not normally a matter for consideration under the government's foreign investment policy.
(3) I understand, on the basis of information provided by the parties that the current directors of Mainsel Investment are
(4) the directors of Youchang (not Youngchange) Construction are
(5) It is not clear that the Brisbane retail market is overcrowded. Brisbane retail industry representatives do not consider the market for retail space to be oversupplied.

Ultimately the inclusion of retail space in the Brisbane Central Place proposal is a commercial decision. It would follow a successful trend occurring in major Australian and overseas cities to locate retail space amongst office and hotel accommodation close to a major transport terminal. The effect on the Australian economy is likely to be a substantial positive one, particularly for the construction industry.

(6) Vacancy rates for both prime and secondary office space in Brisbane are reported to be extremely low. Construction of any additional space will tend to reduce the rate of office space price increases. It will stimulate the building and associated supply industries at a time when activity was otherwise expected to decline slightly. By providing additional office accommodation the development could well improve the viability of existing retail outlets.

The overall impact on small businesses located in the Central Brisbane shopping district and providing retail and commercial facilities is difficult to assess. While some dislocation in trading patterns might occur many small businesses will benefit substantially from the additional inflow of demand generated by such a large hotel, office and retail facility.

(7) The Commonwealth's power to control such major schemes in state capital cities is limited. Where a development proposal comes within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act, the Government may have powers under the Act's provisions; if so the provisions of the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act might also be involved. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act may also apply to `major schemes in capital cities' should such schemes require approval under the Commonwealth's foreign investment policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (i) Does the Minister's Department's Annual Report 1986-87 state, at page 57 ``The major business tax reforms arising out of the Tax Summit-imputation company tax system, capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, and the foreign tax credits system-are now in place. In a number of cases, the Department was able to bring about changes to their final design in the interests of industry development''.
(ii) What specific changes did the Department ``bring about'' for each of the above taxation changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (ii) The consultative process that occurred at the departmental level during the development of the tax reform package involved detailed and extensive communication with the Treasury on a wide range of tax issues insofar as they impacted on industry.

While Treasury of course had the prime carriage for the formulation of the tax package, my Department provided comments on a number of issues of relevance to its responsibilities, particularly in relation to the impact of any changes to the tax system on business costs, efficiency and investment. QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 26 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When is it likely that a national policy in respect of occupational noise control will have been developed (see Answer to Question No. 1628, Senate Hansard, 26 May 1987, p. 2959).

(2) When is it likely that the Minister will be able to report to Parliament on the feasibility of incorporating the diversity of noise types and sources, of abatement strategies and of responsible jurisdictions within a single national policy on noise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Occupational noise control lies essentially within the jurisdiction of the Minister for Industrial Relations, who is responsible for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I understand that noise induced hearing loss is a priority issue for the National Commission and that a proposal for a national strategy on noise is being prepared. This strategy will comprise elements of assessment and prevention. A national information strategy is also being developed.

The Australian Deafness Council is administering a Noise Induced Hearing Loss Campaign which is being jointly funded by my Department and the National Commission. The Campaign aims to increase knowledge, alter attitudes and give skills by which knowledge is acquired by employers and employees. This will be done by:
Information dissemination-video, audio and written material to target groups specified;
problem identification-workplace visits and consultations, informal noise testing and assistance with problem solving.
(2) Officers of the National Acoustic Laboratories are preparing the material needed to examine the feasibility of developing a national policy on any or all of the following:

This involves analysing the scientific justification for recommendations on noise levels and the compilation and analysis of a comprehensive set of the relevant State regulations and national and international standards. The task is very complex because the material is extensive and needs to be obtained from many sources.

At this early stage, it is difficult to estimate how much work is involved or what delays will be encountered in obtaining material. It is likely to be at least one year before a report and set of recommendations will be completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When does the Government intend to rectify the most unfair situation which exists in the Defence Services where a single member of the forces is on the prescribed list of persons who are exempt from the Medicare levy, but as soon as he or she marries, the member of the Services loses that benefit and has to pay half the levy.
(2) Is this state of affairs doubly iniquitous in view of the fact that the Service person's working spouse pays the normal full levy also.

(3) Is it a fact that injustices like this have been a contributing factor to the disastrously high level of resignations we are witnessing from our armed forces during the lifetime of this Labor Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Any Government decision to amend the provisions of the Medicare levy legislation is a matter for decision by the Treasurer and I suggest your question be directed to him.

(2) This aspect was considered by the Treasurer when the original legislation was presented to the House and there is provision to claim an exemption from the half levy if the member can demonstrate that the spouse was not a dependant. However, I suggest you redirect your question to the Treasurer as the matter of establishing whether a spouse is dependent rests with the Commissioners of Taxation who come within the Treasurer's area of responsibility.
(3) I am unaware that the present Medicare levy is an injustice, nor do I agree that the resignation rate is at a disastrously high level.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 15 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When the increase in tariffs under harmonized tariff were announced, were affected importers advised that they would have to re-apply to remain in the 2 percent bracket.
(2) How any applications have been received.
(3) How many of these applications have been processed to date (14 December 1987).
(4) How long will it take to clear the balance and is extra staff being used to clear all the applications that have been received to date before 31 December 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: At the completion of the normal public enquiry process, the report of the IAC into the Harmonized System was released on 16 July 1986. It contained two options and detailed the duty rates applicable under each.

The Government announced the adoption of option two on 23 September 1986. As a consequence importers and professional advisers of importers on Customs matters had available to them details of rate changes at that time. Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No.2) 1987 which passed through the Senate on 15 December 1987 incorporated 8 changes as a result of established compelling industry cases.

In anticipation of industry's concerns about duty increases under the Harmonized Tariff importers were advised by a Customs Notice on 26 May 1987 that Tariff Concession applications would be considered, and prompted early lodgment in order that any resulting concessions might be in place by 1.1.88.
The specific questions however, appear to relate primarily to continuation of Tariff Concession Orders and in answer to those questions.

(1) The only legal basis for removing levels of Industries Assistance, enacted by Parliament, is through the legal provisions contained in Part XVA of the Customs Act for granting Tariff Concession Orders. The importing and local manufacturing communities are well aware of these provisions.

In June 1987 importers were advised that most current Tariff Concessions would be translated across into the Harmonized system substantially unchanged. Some references would not be converted due to non-usage, lack of information to reclassify or because the substantive rate was now 2 percent or lower. Some other references would undergo rewording. Any importers affected by the changes and requiring continuation of concessional entry were urged to reapply as soon as possible so that any resulting concessions might be in place by 1.1.88.

(2) It is not possible to differentiate between normal applications for Tariff Concession Orders and those arising from increases due to introduction of the Harmonized Tariff or other tariff changes. Overall applications in 1987 totalled some 2,885 (6 per cent higher than in 1986).

(3) This information is not available. However as at 31 December 1987 there were 1935 applications with an average time since receival of 26 weeks. There is no indication that consideration of applications has been delayed by the introduction of the Harmonized Tariff.

(4) It is not possible to predict. The processing time of Tariff Concession applications is largely dependent on the quality of the submission. All Tariff Concession workload is being managed within existing staff levels.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What plans does the Federal Government have to re-develop land it owns on the west side of Tapley's Hill Road, adjacent to Adelaide Airport.
(2) Will the land temporarily be for sporting use; if so, which particular sports are being considered.
(3) Will the land be sold to the private sector or retained in government ownership.
(4) Will competitive tenders be called for any work to be carried out at the site.
(5) What consultations have been held with the State and Local Government or with residents of the area as to the impact of such a development in the area.

(6) When will the Government make a firm announcement of its plans; will it be this month (December 1987), as stated by the director of Adelaide Airport in the Adelaide Advertiser of 15 December 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) 16 hectares of the land on the west side of Tapley's Hill Road, adjacent to Adelaide Airport is leased to the West Beach Trust for development of a low par golf course. The balance of 35 hectares is currently utilised for horse agistment and outdoor advertising.
The Master Plan for Adelaide Airport requires that all of this land be retained by the Commonwealth for a parallel runway, if required.

As from 1 January 1988, responsibility for the operation of Adelaide Airport and development of any future business activities there, was transferred to the Federal Airports Corporation. Any proposal to utilise this land in the interim is now therefore a matter for consideration by the FAC.

The 35 hectares was recently the subject of public tender by the Department of Transport and Communications, inviting expressions of public interest for developing the land as a Sporting and Recreational Reserve for a 20 (twenty) year term.

A proposal for a Cable Water Ski Park was selected by this process and was announced in the Commonwealth Gazette of 9 December 1987. This proposal has since been rejected by the Department however, on the grounds that the development could jeopardize the safety of aircraft at Adelaide Airport, by attracting birdlife.

I understand that further specialist advice on the potential bird hazard is being sought. I can assure the Senate that the Department will not permit any development which would jeopardize the safety of the public.

(5) The proposed development and tender process were the subject of agenda items at the June, August and November meetings of the Adelaide Airport Consultative Committee on which State and Local Government had representation.

Additionally, a major pre-requisite of the tender was that any proposal must satisfy the development and environmental constraints as detailed in the study of the area conducted by Kinhill Stearns and published in May 1985 for the West Beach Trust.
(6) The FAC will make a firm announcement of its plans only when the Department is fully satisfied that any proposed development will not jeopardize public safety.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 18 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are claims made in the article in `New Scientist' of 10 January 1985, entitled `Australia's Chemical War Tests', correct; if so, (a) what is the date, place, and type of each chemical weapons test carried out in Australia; and (b) which country or countries carried out each test.

(2) Did Australia join with Britain, the United States and Canada in a formal agreement to co-operate in the research, development and testing of chemical and biological weapons; if so, what is the full text of that agreement.

(3) As a result of defoliant testing, did Australia produce a report entitled `Defoliation of Tropical Rain Forest' in the 1960s; if so, (a) what were the findings of that report; and (b) in what ways were those findings applied in the Vietnam War.

(4) Was chemical and/or biological weapons research, development and testing taking place in Australia at the time the `New Scientist' article was written; if so, what were the details of any such programs, where did they take place, and which parties were involved, Australian and foreign.

(5) Are programs referred to in (4) above taking place at present; if so, what are the details of any such programs, where are they taking place, and which parties are involved, Australian and foreign.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Reference has been made to the subject article in the past. I refer the honourable senator to the answer to House of Representatives question No. 331, published in Hansard of 10 September 1985, page 376.

(2) It would appear that the article is alluding to the Basic Standardisation Agreement to which the Australian Army became a signatory in 1963. The armies of the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada are the other signatories. One of the many articles covered by the agreement is consideration of the standardisation between member armies in the field of defence against biological and chemical weapons. Australian Government policy does not permit activity to develop an offensive capability in biological or chemical warfare. I am willing to provide the honourable senator with a copy of the text of the agreement.

(3) Defoliation experiments on jungle vegetation in Tropical Lowland Evergreen Forests were carried out near Innisfail, in Northern Queensland in 1966 by the Australian Defence Scientific Service. The defoliating effects of `Diquat' and `Tordon', singly, in admixture and in conjunction with dimethyl-sulphoxide (DMSO) were investigated. It was found that DMSO increased the rate of action in all cases, and acceptable defoliation was obtained from some ternary mixtures within one month. The presence of `Tordon' minimised regrowth at least over six months. The findings were published in May 1967 in a report entitled `The Defoliation of Tropi-cal Rainforest in the Innisfail Area, Northern Australia, During 1966'. A copy of the report has been placed in the Parliamentary Library. The findings contributed to the clearing of the defensive perimeter of the Australian Task Force at Nui Dat.
(4) and (5) No. See answer to (2) above.

Until April 1982 there was a Technical Sergeant (USAF) working as an administration clerk. After April 1982 the administration position has been filled by an Australian civilian (see 2 (a) (iii) above).
(3) (a) (1) Solar Optical telescope in the near ultra- violet to near infrared spectrum (3650A to 1100A). The equipment was designed and manufactured in the USA for the USAF.

(2) Eight fixed frequency solar radio telescopes (245, 410, 610, 1415, 2695, 4995, 8800 and 15400 MHz) and a swept frequency (30 to 80 MHz) solar radio telescope. Equipment designed and manufactured in the USA for the USAF.

(2) A pyrheliometer to measure solar irradiance as part of a site survey to establish suitable sites to measure waves which penetrate through the sun's visible interior. Equipment installed by NOAO (National Optical Astronomy Observatories) USA. Equipment constructed in USA by NOAO.
(3) Computer equipment and modem to collect and transmit images of the sun to the Space Environment Services Center (SESC), Boulder, Colorado, (a branch of NOAA). Equipment constructed in the USA.
(4) (a) Normal Telecom telephone, telex and fax facilities within Australia.
(b) (1) Data go to US/RAN HE Holt Naval Communication Base Exmouth via dedicated Telecom telephone land line and then by three satellite links (2 military, one civilian) to the US.
Data from 3 (b) (3) are sent via Telecom telephone line and OTC to Boulder, Colorado, USA.
Data from 3 (b) (2) in the form of magnetic tapes are sent via Australian post to NOAO USA.

(b) (2) The data are sent to the Air Force Global Weather Center (AFGWC) at Omaha, Nebraska, USA via the link described in 4 (b) (1). The data are relayed by AFGWC to the Forecast branch of the Space Environment Services Centre (SESC) for the purpose of issuing forecasts of solar activity, ionospheric and space environment conditions to non-military organisations. (6) IPS Weekly Reports of Solar Geophysical Conditions, Department of Administrative Services, Sydney; IPS Daily Recorded Telephone Report of Solar-Geophysical Conditions, Department of Administrative Services, Sydney; Preliminary Report and Forecast of Solar Geophysical Data published by the NOAA-USAF Space Environment Services Centre, Boulder, Colorado; Solar-Geophysical Data Prompt Reports published by NOAA Environmental Data and Information Services, Boulder, Colorado, USA; Solar-Geophysical Data Comprehensive Reports, published by NOAA Environmental Data and Information Services, Boulder, Colorado, USA.
(a) Ref 4 (b) (1) above. Archival data are sent to NOAA Boulder, Colorado via the US Mail service. A US post office is located on the US/RAN naval base at Exmouth.

(b) (ba) in real time, yes; (bb) 0 to 1 hour, yes; (bc) 1 to 3 hours, yes; (bd) 3 to 8 hours, no; (be) 8 to 12 hours, no; (bf) 12 to 24 hours, no; (bg) 1 to 7 days, no; (bh) 7 days to 1 month, no; (bi) 1 to 6 months, yes; (bj) 6 months to 1 year, yes.

(8) All messages describing solar activity are sent in real time 7 (ba). The quantity of data sent is dependent on the solar activity at that particular time. So it could vary from less than 1% to greater than 80% of total data sent out during a day.

Data sent as 7 (bb) and 7 (bc) are routine messages describing the solar activity or lack of activity and would total about 40 messages per day. Data sent as 7 (bi) and 7 (bj) are data sent to archives at the Data Archive section of the Space Environment Labs NOAA, Boulder, Colorado, USA. These are all the optical and radio data collected at the observatory. These data are a matter of public record.
(10) Yes, there is a small effect on atmospheric density, comparable with day/night variation in magnitude.
(11) (a) No. Effects are generally small and can be offset by mid-course correction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 17 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister agree that as a result of section 73a of the Superannuation Act 1976, people whose sole source of income is a Commonwealth Superannuation Invalidity Pension deciding to stand for local government election face a financial disincentive if elected; if not, why not; if so, what action will be taken to rectify the situation.

(2) Does the Minister accept that people living on a Commonwealth Superannuation Invalidity Pension should have money deducted from their pension on a dollar for dollar basis where the amount of earnings derived from personal exertion (in this case fees and allowances received as a member of a local council) exceeds the prescribed limit as set out in the Act; if so, why.

(3) Does the Minister agree that, in effect, such pensioners are financially disadvantaged by the provisions of the Act as it now stands; if not, why not; if so, what action is being taken to address this matter.

(4) Does the Minister believe that there should be this financial disincentive which effectively discourages invalid pensioners from contesting local government elections because their pensions are reduced as a result of fees and allowances earned as local councillors; if so, why; if not, how and when will he have the relevant section of the Superannuation Act 1976 amended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No, I do not agree that retired Commonwealth employees whose sole source of income is a Commonwealth Superannuation Invalidity Pension payable under the Superannuation Act 1976 face a financial disincentive if elected at local government elections. If paid any fees and/or allowances, they will have an increase in their income.

(2) I accept that persons living on Commonwealth Superannuation Invalidity Pensions have money deducted from their pensions on a dollar for dollar basis where the amount of earnings derived from personal exertion plus invalidity benefits exceeds the prescribed limit.

Invalidity pensions payable under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme have always been based on the premise that the recipient is unfit for work. Therefore, the Scheme should not, in principle, provide invalidity benefits to invalidity retirees who are able to gain paid employment. Nevertheless it was recognised that it may be unreasonable and counter-productive not to permit some paid employment without pensions being affected; for example, employment as part of a rehabilitation program.

The government considered that the limit specified in the legislation would protect persons in receipt of low levels of invalidity pension and allow all invalidity pensioners to earn a small amount of additional income without affecting their pension payments. The limit is the greater of 75 per cent of updated pre-retirement salary and a dollar amount which currently is $20,669 per annum and is increased each July in line with movements in the Consumer Price Index.

Invalidity pensions would only be reduced when the limit was exceeded by the total of earnings from personal exertion, the invalidity pension payable and, if applicable, the additional pension that would have been payable had a member not chosen to receive a lump sum of contributions plus interest.

(3) and (4) I do not agree that such pensioners are financially disadvantaged or subject to financial disincentive by the provision of the Act as it now stands for reasons given in 1 above. It would be inappropriate for the invalidity retirement provisions of the Superannuation Act 1976 to provide an unrestricted taxpayer-financed supplement to those persons who undertake paid employment, whether those persons are elected to local government or have other employment.

If the rate of remuneration for such persons is small, as would normally be commensurate with the duties that could be undertaken by invalidity retirees, the reduction in pension, if any, will also be small.

However, some full-time local government councillors have onerous duties and are paid accordingly. I understand Brisbane City Council pays its full-time aldermen $42,000 per annum. If invalidity retirees were earning such sums, I consider that it is only right and proper that their invalidity pensions be reduced accordingly or even cancelled altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1200), Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice regarding Rothwells Ltd:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) Have any Commonwealth Ministers, Departmental officials or officials of any Commonwealth Statutory Authorities been involved in discussions concerning the package put together to support Rothwells Merchant Bank?

(ii) Can the Minister advise the Senate what part the State Government of Western Australia is playing in the arrangements and what obligations have been entered into by the State Government and its instrumentalities?
(iii) What role, if any, is being played by the Commonwealth or any of its instrumentalities?
(iv) Is the Commonwealth in any way directly or indirectly assuming any responsibility or liability?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer in response to the honourable senator's question:

(i) As far as I am aware no Commonwealth Ministers or officials of Departmental or Statutory Authorities were involved in the organisation of the package put together by parties in Western Australia to support Rothwells. There have been, however, some communications between certain of the parties involved in the package and the Commonwealth aimed at informing the latter of developments; in particular, the Reserve Bank of Australia has been informed on a regular basis on banking aspects of the arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 December 1987 (Hansard, page 2652), Senator Parer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the taxation aspects of a proposed joint venture in the Soviet Union for an alumina refinery. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed joint venture referred to by Senator Parer involves the staged construction of a 1 million tonne alumina refinery and a half-million tonne aluminium smelter in the Soviet Far East. The Australian company concerned is currently conducting a feasibility study of the proposal which will determine if the project proceeds and in what form.

Under Soviet legislation dealing with the establishment and operation of joint ventures in the USSR with participation of Soviet bodies, joint ventures are exempt from Soviet tax on profit for two years from the date the joint venture begins making a profit. After the initial two years of profit making, joint ventures pay Soviet taxes at the rate of 30 per cent on their profit, net of any reinvested funds. Any profits repatriated to Australia by the Australian partner would face a further 20 per cent withholding tax.

The Australian participant company will have to pay Soviet tax on profits earned in this joint venture after a two-year tax holiday and on any remitted profits will also pay Australian tax under the foreign tax credit system. The Soviet Union is not being given special consideration in tax matters compared with the rest of the world. Any advantages to the Australian participating company would be purely commercial advantages, and not taxation advantages granted by Australia.
